72.letter of intent: any letter expressing an intention to take (or forgo) some action
72.investment letter: a letter of intent saying that a letter security is being bought for investment and not for resale; avoids need for SEC registration
72.pastoral: a letter from a pastor to the congregation
72.love letter: a personal letter to a loved one expressing affection
72.dead letter: mail that can neither be delivered nor returned
72.open letter: a letter of protest; addressed to one person but intended for the general public
72.invitation: a request (spoken or written) to participate or be present or take part in something
72.encyclical: a letter from the pope sent to all Roman Catholic bishops throughout the world
72.personal letter: a letter dealing with personal affairs

719.knitting machine: a textile machine that makes knitted fabrics
719.throstle: a spinning machine formerly used to twist and wind fibers of cotton or wool continuously
719.serger: a sewing machine that overcasts the raw edges of a fabric with a V-shaped stitch
719.spinning frame: spinning machine that draws, twists, and winds yarn
719.spinning machine: a textile machine for spinning yarn and thread
719.high-warp loom: a handloom in which the warp is carried vertically; for weaving tapestry
719.spinning jenny: an early spinning machine with multiple spindles
719.loom: a textile machine for weaving yarn into a textile
719.spinning wheel: a small domestic spinning machine with a single spindle that is driven by hand or foot
719.low-warp-loom: a handloom in which the warp is carried horizontally; for weaving tapestry
719.willow: a textile machine having a system of revolving spikes for opening and cleaning raw textile fibers
719.figure loom: a loom for weaving figured fabrics
719.Jacquard loom: a loom with an attachment for forming openings for the passage of the shuttle between the warp threads; used in weaving figured fabrics
719.sewing machine: a textile machine used as a home appliance for sewing

726.bulge: something that bulges out or is protuberant or projects from its surroundings
726.taper: a convex shape that narrows toward a point
726.wart: any small rounded protuberance (as on certain plants or animals)
726.corrugation: a ridge on a corrugated surface
726.frontal eminence: either prominence of the frontal bone above each orbit
726.umbo: a slight rounded elevation where the malleus attaches to the eardrum
726.convex shape: a shape that curves or bulges outward
726.head: the tip of an abscess (where the pus accumulates)
726.mogul: a bump on a ski slope
726.caput: a headlike protuberance on an organ or structure
726.palatine raphe: the seam at the middle of the hard palate
726.occipital protuberance: prominence on the outer surface of the occipital bone
726.camber: a slight convexity (as of the surface of a road)
726.raphe: a ridge that forms a seam between two parts
726.jag: a sharp projection on an edge or surface
726.widow's peak: a V-shaped point in the hairline in the middle of the forehead
726.projection: any solid convex shape that juts out from something
726.tail: any projection that resembles the tail of an animal
726.entasis: a slight convexity in the shaft of a column; compensates for the illusion of concavity that viewers experience when the sides are perfectly straight
726.salient: (military) the part of the line of battle that projects closest to the enemy
726.keel: a projection or ridge that suggests a keel
726.cusp: small elevation on the grinding surface of a tooth
726.tongue: any long thin projection that is transient

662.glass eye: prosthesis consisting of an artificial eye made of glass
662.obturator: a prosthesis used to close an opening (as to close an opening of the hard palate in cases of cleft palate)
662.monofocal lens implant: a lens with a single focus that is used after cataract surgery to provide clear distance vision
662.prosthesis: corrective consisting of a replacement for a part of the body
662.implant: a prosthesis placed permanently in tissue
662.breast implant: an implant for cosmetic purposes to replace a breast that has been surgically removed
662.dental implant: an implant that replaces a natural tooth
662.artificial joint: a metal or plastic part that is surgically implanted to replace a natural joint (possibly elbow or wrist but usually hip or knee)
662.artificial heart: a pump that replaces the natural heart
662.accommodating lens implant: a lens implant containing a hinge that allows for both near and far vision (thus mimicking the natural lens of a young person)
662.multifocal lens implant: a type of lens implant that contains several rings with a common center and adjusts for near or far vision; the eye is in focus for near and far vision simultaneously
662.peg: a prosthesis that replaces a missing leg
662.penile implant: an implant that creates an artificial erection
662.heart valve: an implant that replaces a natural cardiac valve
662.Jarvik heart: a kind of artificial heart that has been used with some success
662.lens implant: a clear plastic lens that is implanted in the eye; usually done when the natural lens has been removed in a cataract operation
662.shunt: implant consisting of a tube made of plastic or rubber; for draining fluids within the body

153.flotation: financing a commercial enterprise by bond or stock shares
153.banking: transacting business with a bank; depositing or withdrawing funds or requesting a loan etc.
153.arbitrage: a kind of hedged investment meant to capture slight differences in price; when there is a difference in the price of something on two different markets the arbitrageur simultaneously buys at the lower price and sells at the higher price
153.leverage: investing with borrowed money as a way to amplify potential gains (at the risk of greater losses)
153.finance: the commercial activity of providing funds and capital
153.home banking: banking in which transactions are conducted by means of electronic communication (via telephone or computer)
153.risk arbitrage: arbitrage involving risk; as in the simultaneous purchase of stock in a target company and sale of stock in its potential acquirer; if the takeover fails the arbitrageur may lose a great deal of money
153.investing: the act of investing; laying out money or capital in an enterprise with the expectation of profit
153.high finance: large and complex financial transactions (often used with the implication that those individuals or institutions who engage in them are unethical)
153.foreign direct investment: investing in United States businesses by foreign citizens (often involves stock ownership of the business)

26.capitulation: a summary that enumerates the main parts of a topic
26.epanodos: recapitulation of the main ideas of a speech (especially in reverse order)
26.overview: a general summary of a subject
26.summary: a brief statement that presents the main points in a concise form
26.recapitulation: a summary at the end that repeats the substance of a longer discussion
26.outline: a sketchy summary of the main points of an argument or theory
26.condensation: a shortened version of a written work
26.argument: a summary of the subject or plot of a literary work or play or movie
26.roundup: a summary list; as in e.g.
26.curriculum vitae: a summary of your academic and work history
26.summation: a concluding summary (as in presenting a case before a law court)
26.compendium: a concise but comprehensive summary of a larger work
26.line score: a summary of the scoring in a game (usually in tabular form)
26.epitome: a brief abstract (as of an article or book)
26.brief: a condensed written summary or abstract

130.bubble gum dermatitis: an allergic contact dermatitis developed around the lips of children who chew bubble gum
130.poison sumac: dermatitis resulting from contact with a poison sumac plant
130.schistosome dermatitis: a sensitization reaction to repeated invasion of the skin by cercariae of schistosomes
130.contact dermatitis: a delayed type of allergic reaction of the skin resulting from skin contact with a specific allergen (such as poison ivy)
130.Rhus dermatitis: contact dermatitis resulting from contact with plants of the genus Toxicodendron
130.poison ivy: dermatitis resulting from contact with the poison ivy plant
130.hypericism: a severe dermatitis of herbivorous domestic animals attributable to photosensitivity from eating Saint John's wort
130.dermatitis: inflammation of the skin; skin becomes itchy and may develop blisters
130.seborrheic dermatitis: a chronic skin disease associated with seborrhea and greasy scales on the scalp or eyelids or other parts of the skin
130.neurodermatitis: dermatitis in which localized areas (especially the forearms or back of the neck or outer part of the ankle) itch persistently; cause is unknown
130.poison oak: dermatitis resulting from contact with a poison oak plant
130.diaper rash: dermatitis of the thighs and buttocks of infants; supposedly caused by ammonia in the urine in the child's diapers
130.atopic dermatitis: a severe form of dermatitis characterized by atopy
130.cradle cap: a dermatitis of the scalp that is common in infants

744.schnorrer: (Yiddish) a scrounger who takes advantage of the generosity of others
744.panhandler: a beggar who approaches strangers asking for money
744.Lazarus: the diseased beggar in Jesus' parable of the rich man and the beggar
744.derelict: a person without a home, job, or property
744.starveling: someone who is starving (or being starved)
744.beggarman: a man who is a beggar
744.moocher: someone who mooches or cadges (tries to get something free)
744.pauper: a person who is very poor
744.beggarwoman: a woman who is a beggar
744.beggar: a pauper who lives by begging

167.class struggle: conflict between social or economic classes (especially between the capitalist and proletariat classes)
167.tug-of-war: any hard struggle between equally matched groups
167.Indian Mutiny: discontent with British administration in India led to numerous mutinies in 1857 and 1858; the revolt was put down after several battles and sieges (notably the siege at Lucknow)
167.insurgency: an organized rebellion aimed at overthrowing a constituted government through the use of subversion and armed conflict
167.mutiny: open rebellion against constituted authority (especially by seamen or soldiers against their officers)
167.intifada: an uprising by Palestinian Arabs (in both the Gaza Strip and the West Bank) against Israel in the late 1980s and again in 2000
167.drug war: conflict between law enforcement and those who deal in illegal drugs
167.strife: bitter conflict; heated often violent dissension
167.dogfight: a violent fight between dogs (sometimes organized illegally for entertainment and gambling)
167.brawl: a noisy fight in a crowd
167.rumble: a fight between rival gangs of adolescents
167.in-fighting: conflict between members of the same organization (usually concealed from outsiders)
167.discord: strife resulting from a lack of agreement
167.war: an active struggle between competing entities
167.turf war: a bitter struggle for territory or power or control or rights
167.battering: the act of subjecting to strong attack
167.Peasant's Revolt: a widespread rebellion in 1381 against poll taxes and other inequities that oppressed the poorer people of England; suppressed by Richard II
167.duel: a prearranged fight with deadly weapons by two people (accompanied by seconds) in order to settle a quarrel over a point of honor
167.shock: the violent interaction of individuals or groups entering into combat
167.pacification: actions taken by a government to defeat insurgency
167.rebellion: organized opposition to authority; a conflict in which one faction tries to wrest control from another
167.conflict: an open clash between two opposing groups (or individuals); --Thomas Paine
167.feud: a bitter quarrel between two parties
167.vendetta: a feud in which members of the opposing parties murder each other
167.beating: the act of overcoming or outdoing
167.countercurrent: actions counter to the main group activity
167.gunfight: a fight involving shooting small arms with the intent to kill or frighten
167.fencing: the art or sport of fighting with swords (especially the use of foils or epees or sabres to score points under a set of rules)
167.fight: the act of fighting; any contest or struggle
167.trench warfare: a struggle (usually prolonged) between competing entities in which neither side is able to win

589.rudderpost: a vertical post at the forward edge of a rudder that enables the rudder to pivot
589.queen post: vertical tie post in a roof truss
589.column: (architecture) a tall vertical cylindrical structure standing upright and used to support a structure
589.stanchion: any vertical post or rod used as a support
589.gatepost: either of two posts that bound a gate
589.whipping post: post formerly used in public to which offenders are tied to be whipped
589.lally: support column consisting of a steel cylinder filled with concrete
589.hinging post: the gatepost on which the gate is hung
589.shutting post: the gatepost against which the gate closes
589.stake: a strong wooden or metal post with a point at one end so it can be driven into the ground
589.newel post: the post at the top or bottom of a flight of stairs; it supports the handrail
589.caryatid: a supporting column carved in the shape of a person
589.bollard: a strong post (as on a wharf or quay or ship for attaching mooring lines)
589.stump: (cricket) any of three upright wooden posts that form the wicket
589.upright: a vertical structural member as a post or stake
589.hop pole: a tall pole to support the wires on which the hop plant is trained
589.carrick bitt: either of a pair of strong posts that support a windlass on a ship's deck
589.king post: post connecting the crossbeam to the apex of a triangular truss
589.riding bitt: one of the large bitts used to secure the cable of a dropped anchor
589.newel: the central pillar of a circular staircase
589.pilaster: a rectangular column that usually projects about a third of its width from the wall to which it is attached
589.pile: a column of wood or steel or concrete that is driven into the ground to provide support for a structure
589.stile: an upright that is a member in a door or window frame
589.standard: an upright pole or beam (especially one used as a support)
589.atlas: a figure of a man used as a supporting column
589.support column: a column that supports a heavy weight
589.hitching post: a fixed post with a ring to which a horse can be hitched to prevent it from straying
589.corner post: a square post supporting a structural member at the corner of a building
589.jamb: upright consisting of a vertical side member of a door or window frame
589.goalpost: one of a pair of posts (usually joined by a crossbar) that are set up as a goal at each end of a playing field
589.maypole: a vertical pole or post decorated with streamers that can be held by dancers celebrating May Day
589.shaft: (architecture) upright consisting of the vertical part of a column
589.lamppost: a metal post supporting an outdoor lamp (such as a streetlight)
589.post: an upright consisting of a piece of timber or metal fixed firmly in an upright position
589.sheet pile: a pile in a row of piles driven side by side to retain earth or prevent seepage

477.needlework: work (such as sewing or embroidery) that is done with a needle
477.lace making: the act or art of making handmade lace
477.handicraft: a craft that requires skillful hands
477.arts and crafts: the arts of decorative design and handicraft
477.blind stitching: stitching that is not easily seen or noticed

351.inflorescence: the flowering part of a plant or arrangement of flowers on a stalk
351.flower cluster: an inflorescence consisting of a cluster of flowers
351.spike: (botany) an indeterminate inflorescence bearing sessile flowers on an unbranched axis
351.raceme: usually elongate cluster of flowers along the main stem in which the flowers at the base open first
351.panicle: compound raceme or branched cluster of flowers
351.corymb: flat-topped or convex inflorescence in which the individual flower stalks grow upward from various points on the main stem to approximately the same height; outer flowers open first
351.flower head: a shortened compact cluster of flowers so arranged that the whole gives the effect of a single flower as in clover or members of the family Compositae
351.scorpioid cyme: a cyme with flowers or branches alternating in opposite ranks
351.thyrse: a dense flower cluster (as of the lilac or horse chestnut) in which the main axis is racemose and the branches are cymose
351.cymule: a small cyme, generally with few flowers
351.cyme: more or less flat-topped cluster of flowers in which the central or terminal flower opens first
351.umbel: flat-topped or rounded inflorescence characteristic of the family Umbelliferae in which the individual flower stalks arise from about the same point; youngest flowers are at the center

138.serial monogamy: a succession of short monogamous relationships (as by someone who undergoes multiple divorces)
138.spinsterhood: the state of being a spinster (usually an elderly unmarried woman)
138.polyandry: having more than one husband at a time
138.marital status: the condition of being married or unmarried
138.monogamy: having only one spouse at a time
138.mesalliance: a marriage with a person of inferior social status
138.cuckoldom: the state of a husband whose wife has committed adultery
138.exogamy: marriage to a person belonging to a tribe or group other than your own as required by custom or law
138.misalliance: an unsuitable alliance (especially with regard to marriage)
138.civil union: a voluntary union for life (or until divorce) of adult parties of the same sex
138.endogamy: marriage within one's own tribe or group as required by custom or law
138.marriage of convenience: a marriage for expediency rather than love
138.polygyny: having more than one wife at a time
138.monandry: the state of having only one husband at a time
138.bachelorhood: the state of being an unmarried man
138.open marriage: a marriage in which each partner is free to enter into extraneous sexual relationships without guilt or jealousy from the other
138.polygamy: having more than one spouse at a time
138.common-law marriage: a marriage relationship created by agreement and cohabitation rather than by ceremony
138.marriage: the state of being a married couple voluntarily joined for life (or until divorce)
138.widowhood: the state of being a widow who has not remarried
138.sigeh: a Shiite tradition of temporary marriage permitted in Iran that allows a couple to specify the terms of their relationship; can last from a few minutes to 99 years
138.bigamy: having two spouses at the same time
138.monogyny: having only one wife at a time

415.dunce: a stupid person; these words are used to express a low opinion of someone's intelligence
415.space cadet: someone who seems unable to respond appropriately to reality (as if under the influence of some narcotic drug)
415.fathead: a man who is a stupid incompetent fool
415.simpleton: a person lacking intelligence or common sense
415.schlemiel: (Yiddish) a dolt who is a habitual bungler
415.stupid: a person who is not very bright
415.berk: a stupid person who is easy to take advantage of
415.schnook: (Yiddish) a gullible simpleton more to be pitied than despised
415.fool: a person who lacks good judgment
415.Pantaloon: a buffoon in modern pantomimes; the butt of jokes
415.subnormal: a person of less than normal intelligence
415.idiot savant: person who is mentally retarded in general but who displays remarkable aptitude in some limited field (usually involving memory)
415.twerp: someone who is regarded as contemptible
415.wally: a silly and inept person; someone who is regarded as stupid
415.mongoloid: a person suffering from Down syndrome (no longer used technically in this sense)
415.square: someone who doesn't understand what is going on
415.sheep: a timid defenseless simpleton who is readily preyed upon

502.Yamamoto: Japanese admiral who planned the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941 (1884-1943)
502.flag officer: a senior naval officer above the rank of captain
502.lieutenant commander: a commissioned officer in the Navy ranking above a lieutenant and below a commander
502.commodore: a commissioned naval officer who ranks above a captain and below a rear admiral; the lowest grade of admiral
502.captain: the naval officer in command of a military ship
502.lieutenant: an officer holding a commissioned rank in the United States Navy or the United States Coast Guard; below lieutenant commander and above lieutenant junior grade
502.commissioned naval officer: a commissioned officer in the navy
502.admiral: the supreme commander of a fleet; ranks above a vice admiral and below a fleet admiral
502.rear admiral: an admiral junior to a vice admiral
502.vice admiral: an admiral ranking below a full admiral and above a rear admiral
502.Perry: United States commodore who led the fleet that defeated the British on Lake Erie during the War of 1812; brother of Matthew Calbraith Perry (1785-1819)
502.Drake: English explorer and admiral who was the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe and who helped to defeat the Spanish Armada (1540-1596)
502.Nelson: English admiral who defeated the French fleets of Napoleon but was mortally wounded at Trafalgar (1758-1805)
502.ensign: a person who holds a commissioned rank in the United States Navy or the United States Coast Guard; below lieutenant junior grade
502.commander: a commissioned naval officer who ranks above a lieutenant commander and below a captain
502.Bligh: British admiral; was captain of the H.M.S. Bounty in 1789 when part of the crew mutinied and set him afloat in an open boat; a few weeks later he arrived safely in Timor 4,000 miles away (1754-1817)
502.lieutenant junior grade: an officer holding a commissioned rank in the United States Navy or United States Coast Guard; below lieutenant and above ensign
502.fleet admiral: an admiral of the highest rank

664.Iceland spar: a transparent calcite found in Iceland and used in polarizing microscopes
664.plagioclase: any of a series of triclinic feldspars that form rocks
664.albite: a widely distributed feldspar that forms rocks
664.feldspar: any of a group of hard crystalline minerals that consist of aluminum silicates of potassium or sodium or calcium or barium
664.spar: any of various nonmetallic minerals (calcite or feldspar) that are light in color and transparent or translucent and cleavable
664.orthoclase: a white or colored monoclinic feldspar
664.calcite: a common mineral consisting of crystallized calcium carbonate; a major constituent of limestone
664.anorthite: rare plagioclastic feldspar occurring in many igneous rocks
664.moonstone: a transparent or translucent gemstone with a pearly luster; some specimens are orthoclase feldspar and others are plagioclase feldspar
664.alabaster: a hard compact kind of calcite

220.blood-brain barrier: a mechanism that creates a barrier between brain tissues and circulating blood; serves to protect the central nervous system
220.mechanism: a natural object resembling a machine in structure or function
220.indirect transmission: a transmission mechanism in which the infectious agent is transferred to the person by a fomite of vector
220.direct transmission: a transmission mechanism in which the infectious agent is transferred directly into the body via touching or biting or kissing or sexual intercourse or by droplets entering the eye or nose or mouth
220.vector-borne transmission: indirect transmission of an infectious agent that occurs when a vector bites or touches a person
220.curtain: any barrier to communication or vision
220.airborne transmission: a transmission mechanism in the which the infectious agent is spread as an aerosol and usually enters a person through the respiratory tract
220.transmission mechanism: any mechanism whereby an infectious agent is spread from a reservoir to a human being
220.bar: a submerged (or partly submerged) ridge in a river or along a shore
220.vehicle-borne transmission: indirect transmission of an infectious agent that occurs when a vehicle (or fomite) touches a person's body or is ingested
220.biological clock: an innate mechanism in living organisms that controls the periodicity of many physiological functions
220.barrier: anything serving to maintain separation by obstructing vision or access

496.wing shooting: shooting game birds that are flying (on the wing)
496.murder: unlawful premeditated killing of a human being by a human being
496.homicide: the killing of a human being by another human being
496.hit: a murder carried out by an underworld syndicate
496.lynching: putting a person to death by mob action without due process of law
496.assassination: murder of a public figure by surprise attack
496.honor killing: an ancient tradition still sometimes observed; a male member of the family kills a female relative for tarnishing the family image
496.drive-by shooting: shooting someone from a car as it is driven past the victim
496.Little Bighorn: a battle in Montana near the Little Bighorn River between United States cavalry under Custer and several groups of Native Americans (1876); Custer was pursuing Sioux led by Sitting Bull; Custer underestimated the size of the Sioux forces (which were supported by Cheyenne warriors) and was killed along with all his command
496.mariticide: the murder of a husband by his wife
496.Alamo: a siege and massacre at a mission in San Antonio in 1836; Mexican forces under Santa Anna besieged and massacred American rebels who were fighting to make Texas independent of Mexico
496.contract killing: a murder carried out on agreement with a hired killer
496.dry-gulching: the act of killing from ambush
496.chance-medley: an unpremeditated killing of a human being in self defense
496.uxoricide: the murder of a wife by her husband
496.slaughter: the savage and excessive killing of many people
496.filicide: the murder of your own son or daughter
496.parricide: the murder of your own father or mother
496.bloodshed: the shedding of blood resulting in murder
496.drive-by killing: homicide committed by shooting from a moving automobile
496.regicide: the act of killing a king
496.shoot-down: murder by shooting someone down in cold blood

273.popinjay: an archaic term for a parrot
273.lovebird: small African parrot noted for showing affection for their mates
273.macaw: long-tailed brilliantly colored parrot of Central America and South America; among the largest and showiest of parrots
273.cockatoo: white or light-colored crested parrot of the Australian region; often kept as cage birds
273.budgerigar: small Australian parakeet usually light green with black and yellow markings in the wild but bred in many colors
273.sulphur-crested cockatoo: white cockatoo with a yellow erectile crest
273.lory: small brightly colored Australasian parrots having a brush-tipped tongue for feeding on nectar and soft fruits
273.parrot: usually brightly colored zygodactyl tropical birds with short hooked beaks and the ability to mimic sounds
273.pink cockatoo: white Australian cockatoo with roseate tinged plumage
273.African grey: commonly domesticated grey parrot with red-and-black tail and white face; native to equatorial Africa
273.Carolina parakeet: extinct parakeet whose range extended far into the United States
273.parakeet: any of numerous small slender long-tailed parrots
273.cockateel: small grey Australian parrot with a yellow crested head

39.locus: the specific site of a particular gene on its chromosome
39.locus of infection: the specific site in the body where an infection originates
39.back: the part of something that is furthest from the normal viewer
39.outstation: a station in a remote or sparsely populated location
39.vantage: place or situation affording some advantage (especially a comprehensive view or commanding perspective)
39.position: the particular portion of space occupied by something
39.antigenic determinant: the site on the surface of an antigen molecule to which an antibody attaches itself
39.stand: the position where a thing or person stands
39.lie: position or manner in which something is situated
39.pitch: a vendor's position (especially on the sidewalk)
39.landmark: the position of a prominent or well-known object in a particular landscape
39.stage left: the part of the stage on the actor's left as the actor faces the audience
39.close quarters: a situation of being uncomfortably close to someone or something
39.post: the position where someone (as a guard or sentry) stands or is assigned to stand
39.active site: the part of an enzyme or antibody where the chemical reaction occurs
39.vantage point: a place from which something can be viewed
39.bridgehead: a defensive post at the end of a bridge nearest to the enemy
39.half-mast: a position some distance below the top of a mast to which a flag is lowered in mourning or to signal distress
39.front: the part of something that is nearest to the normal viewer
39.lead: (baseball) the position taken by a base runner preparing to advance to the next base
39.cabstand: a place where taxis park while awaiting customers
39.pride of place: the first or highest or most important or most ostentatious place
39.meteorological observation post: one of a network of observation posts where meteorological data is recorded
39.site: physical position in relation to the surroundings
39.stage right: the part of the stage on the actor's right as the actor faces the audience
39.right: location near or direction toward the right side; i.e. the side to the south when a person or object faces east
39.pole position: the most favorable position at the start of a race
39.wing: (in flight formation) a position to the side and just to the rear of another aircraft
39.anomaly: (astronomy) position of a planet as defined by its angular distance from its perihelion (as observed from the sun)
39.left: location near or direction toward the left side; i.e. the side to the north when a person or object faces east
39.restriction site: the specific sites at which a restriction enzyme will cleave DNA
39.station: (nautical) the location to which a ship or fleet is assigned for duty
39.lookout: an elevated post affording a wide view

393.WASP: a white person of Anglo-Saxon ancestry who belongs to a Protestant denomination
393.White: a member of the Caucasoid race

393.Bahraini: a native or inhabitant of Bahrain
393.white trash: (slang) an offensive term for White people who are impoverished
393.Canaanite: a member of an ancient Semitic people who occupied Canaan before it was conquered by the Israelites
393.Palestinian: a descendant of the Arabs who inhabited Palestine
393.Aryan: (according to Nazi doctrine) a Caucasian person of Nordic descent (and not a Jew)
393.paleface: (slang) a derogatory term for a white person (supposedly used by North American Indians)
393.Qatari: a native or inhabitant of Qatar
393.Saudi: a native or inhabitant of Saudi Arabia
393.Abkhaz: a member of the Circassian people who live to the east of the Black Sea
393.whitey: (slang) offensive names for a White man
393.Omani: a native or inhabitant of Oman

393.Sumerian: a member of a people who inhabited ancient Sumer

198.cyber-terrorism: an assault on electronic communication networks

73.pseudohallucination: an image vivid enough to be a hallucination but recognized as unreal

297.White House: the chief executive department of the United States government

549.complement: a word or phrase used to complete a grammatical construction

126.auxiliary verb: a verb that combines with another verb in a verb phrase to help form tense, mood, voice, or condition of the verb it combines with

677.Girondist: a member of the moderate republican party that was in power during the French Revolution; the Girondists were overthrown by their more radical rivals the Jacobins
677.hacker: a programmer who breaks into computer systems in order to steal or change or destroy information as a form of cyber-terrorism
677.Bolshevik: emotionally charged terms used to refer to extreme radicals or revolutionaries

677.Sanchez: Venezuelan master terrorist raised by a Marxist-Leninist father; trained and worked with many terrorist groups (born in 1949)

221.navel orange: seedless orange enclosing a small secondary fruit at the apex
221.tangerine: any of various deep orange mandarins grown in the United States and southern Africa

728.etymological dictionary: a dictionary giving the historical origins of each word
728.onomasticon: a list of proper nouns naming persons or places
728.unabridged dictionary: a dictionary that has not been shortened by the omitting terms or definitions; a comprehensive dictionary
728.glossary: an alphabetical list of technical terms in some specialized field of knowledge; usually published as an appendix to a text on that field
728.thesaurus: a book containing a classified list of synonyms
728.pocket dictionary: a dictionary that is small enough to carry in your pocket
728.Oxford English Dictionary: an unabridged dictionary constructed on historical principles
728.desk dictionary: an abridged dictionary of a size convenient to hold in the hand
728.bilingual dictionary: a dictionary giving equivalent words in two languages
728.spell-checker: an electronic dictionary in a word processor that can be used to catch misspelled words
728.word finder: a thesaurus organized to help you find the word you want but cannot think of
728.vocabulary: a listing of the words used in some enterprise
728.wordbook: a reference book containing words (usually with their meanings)
728.dictionary: a reference book containing an alphabetical list of words with information about them
728.learner's dictionary: a dictionary specially written for those learning a foreign language
728.gazetteer: a geographical dictionary (as at the back of an atlas)

642.scrupulousness: conformity to high standards of ethics or excellence
642.probity: complete and confirmed integrity; having strong moral principles
642.artlessness: ingenuousness by virtue of being free from artful deceit
642.candor: the quality of being honest and straightforward in attitude and speech
642.sincerity: the quality of being open and truthful; not deceitful or hypocritical

338.evangelicalism: stresses the importance of personal conversion and faith as the means of salvation
338.predestinarianism: the belief or doctrine of predestinarians
338.Romanism: the beliefs and practices of the Catholic Church based in Rome
338.Albigensianism: a Christian movement considered to be a medieval descendant of Manichaeism in southern France in the 12th and 13th centuries; characterized by dualism (asserted the coexistence of two mutually opposed principles, one good and one evil); was exterminated for heresy during the Inquisition
338.Protestantism: the theological system of any of the churches of western Christendom that separated from the Roman Catholic Church during the Reformation
338.Calvinism: the theological system of John Calvin and his followers emphasizing omnipotence of God and salvation by grace alone
338.Baptistic doctrine: any of various doctrines closely related to Anabaptism
338.Wesleyanism: evangelical principles taught by John Wesley
338.Christian Science: religious system based on teachings of Mary Baker Eddy emphasizing spiritual healing
338.Unitarianism: Christian doctrine that stresses individual freedom of belief and rejects the Trinity
338.Lutheranism: teachings of Martin Luther emphasizing the cardinal doctrine of justification by faith alone
338.Trinitarianism: Christian doctrine stressing belief in the Trinity
338.Seventh-Day Adventism: Adventism that is strongly Protestant and observes Saturday as the Sabbath
338.Tractarianism: principles of the founders of the Oxford movement as expounded in pamphlets called `Tracts for the Times'
338.Presbyterianism: the doctrines and practices of the Presbyterian Church: based in Calvinism
338.Anabaptism: a Protestant movement in the 16th century that believed in the primacy of the Bible, baptised only believers, not infants, and believed in complete separation of church and state
338.fundamentalism: the interpretation of every word in the sacred texts as literal truth
338.Anglicanism: the faith and doctrine and practice of the Anglican Church
338.Mennonitism: system of beliefs and practices including belief in scriptural authority; plain dress; adult baptism; foot washing; restriction of marriage to members of the group
338.Puritanism: the beliefs and practices characteristic of Puritans (most of whom were Calvinists who wished to purify the Church of England of its Catholic aspects)
338.Eastern Catholicism: the beliefs and practices of any of the eastern Catholic Churches based in Constantinople or Antioch or Alexandria or Moscow or Jerusalem
338.Adventism: any Christian religion that believes the second coming of Christ is imminent
338.Congregationalism: system of beliefs and church government of a Protestant denomination in which each member church is self-governing
338.Anglo-Catholicism: a doctrine and practice within the Church of England emphasizing the Catholic tradition
338.Christianity: a monotheistic system of beliefs and practices based on the Old Testament and the teachings of Jesus as embodied in the New Testament and emphasizing the role of Jesus as savior
338.revivalism: an attempt to reawaken the evangelical faith
338.Catholicism: the beliefs and practices of a Catholic Church
338.Donatism: a schismatic Christian religion in northern Africa from the 4th to the 7th century; held that only those who led a blameless life belonged in the church or could administer the sacraments
338.Methodism: the religious beliefs and practices of Methodists characterized by concern with social welfare and public morals
338.pentecostalism: the principles and practices of Pentecostal religious groups; characterized by religious excitement and talking in tongues
338.Arminianism: 17th century theology (named after its founder Jacobus Arminius) that opposes the absolute predestinarianism of John Calvin and holds that human free will is compatible with God's sovereignty
338.Mormonism: the doctrines and practices of the Mormon Church based on the Book of Mormon

404.Canada thistle: European thistle naturalized in United States and Canada where it is a pernicious weed
404.stemless carline thistle: stemless perennial having large flowers with white or purple-brown florets nestled in a rosette of long spiny leaves hairy beneath; of alpine regions of southern and eastern Europe
404.cotton thistle: biennial Eurasian white hairy thistle having pale purple flowers; naturalized in North America
404.field thistle: stout North American thistle with purplish-pink flower heads
404.Spanish oyster plant: a golden thistle of southwestern Europe cultivated for its edible sweet roots and edible leaves and stalks; its yellow flowers are used as a substitute for saffron
404.welted thistle: European biennial introduced in North America having flower heads in crowded clusters at ends of branches
404.plume thistle: any of numerous biennial to perennial herbs with handsome purple or yellow or occasionally white flower heads
404.thistle: any of numerous plants of the family Compositae and especially of the genera Carduus and Cirsium and Onopordum having prickly-edged leaves
404.golden thistle: any of several spiny Mediterranean herbs of the genus Scolymus having yellow flower heads
404.European woolly thistle: woolly thistle of western and central Europe and Balkan Peninsula
404.common carline thistle: Eurasian thistle growing in sand dunes and dry chalky soils
404.melancholy thistle: perennial stoloniferous thistle of northern Europe with lanceolate basal leaves and usually solitary heads of reddish-purple flowers
404.woolly thistle: thistle of western North America having white woolly leaves
404.musk thistle: Eurasian perennial naturalized in eastern North America having very spiny white cottony foliage and nodding musky crimson flower heads; valuable source of nectar
404.carline thistle: a thistle of the genus Carlina
404.bull thistle: European thistle with rather large heads and prickly leaves; extensively naturalized as a weed in the United States
404.blessed thistle: annual of Mediterranean to Portugal having hairy stems and minutely spiny-toothed leaves and large heads of yellow flowers

320.garden: a plot of ground where plants are cultivated
320.plot: a small area of ground covered by specific vegetation
320.topiary: a garden having shrubs clipped or trimmed into decorative shapes especially of animals
320.bed: a plot of ground in which plants are growing
320.tea garden: a public garden where tea is served

320.sunken garden: a garden set below the level of the ground surrounding it
320.landscaping: a garden laid out for esthetic effect
320.hotbed: a bed of earth covered with glass and heated by rotting manure to promote the growth of plants
320.turnip bed: a bed in which turnips are growing
320.rose bed: a flower bed in which roses are growing
320.formal garden: a garden laid out on regular lines with plants arranged in symmetrical locations or in geometrical designs

320.rock garden: a garden featuring rocks; usually alpine plants
320.market garden: a garden where fruit and vegetables are grown for marketing

320.seedbed: a bed where seedlings are grown before transplanting
320.asparagus bed: a bed in which asparagus is growing
320.roof garden: a garden on a flat roof of a building
320.parterre: an ornamental flower garden; beds and paths are arranged to form a pattern
320.pot farm: a plot of ground where marijuana is grown and harvested (often hidden in a national forest)
320.flowerbed: a bed in which flowers are growing
320.hop garden: a garden where hops are grown
320.tulip bed: a flowerbed in which tulips are growing

713.gun smoke: smoke created by the firing of guns
713.smoke: a cloud of fine particles suspended in a gas
713.diffuse nebula: a cluster of stars within an intricate cloud of gas and dust
713.fogbank: a large mass of fog on the sea (as seen from a distance)

713.cloud: any collection of particles (e.g., smoke or dust) or gases that is visible

713.aerosol: a cloud of solid or liquid particles in a gas
713.nebula: an immense cloud of gas (mainly hydrogen) and dust in interstellar space

114.polysemy: the ambiguity of an individual word or phrase that can be used (in different contexts) to express two or more different meanings
114.implicitness: inexplicitness as a consequence of being implied or indirect
114.ambiguity: unclearness by virtue of having more than one meaning
114.elusiveness: the quality of being difficult to grasp or pin down
114.vagueness: unclearness by virtue of being poorly expressed or not coherent in meaning
114.twilight zone: the ambiguous region between two categories or states or conditions (usually containing some features of both)
114.obscureness: the quality of being unclear or abstruse and hard to understand
114.inscrutability: the quality of being impossible to investigate
114.noise: incomprehensibility resulting from irrelevant information or meaningless facts or remarks
114.opacity: incomprehensibility resulting from obscurity of meaning
114.unclearness: incomprehensibility as a result of not being clear
114.haziness: vagueness attributable to being not clearly defined
114.impenetrability: incomprehensibility by virtue of being too dense to understand
114.unintelligibility: incomprehensibility as a consequence of being unintelligible
114.illegibility: the quality of writing (print or handwriting) that cannot be deciphered
114.inexplicitness: unclearness by virtue of not being explicit

251.emotional state: the state of a person's emotions (especially with regard to pleasure or dejection)
251.state: a state of depression or agitation
251.quality of life: your personal satisfaction (or dissatisfaction) with the cultural or intellectual conditions under which you live (as distinct from material comfort)

251.mourning: state of sorrow over the death or departure of a loved one
251.gratification: state of being gratified or satisfied

532.suer: someone who petitions a court for redress of a grievance or recovery of a right

652.Sarcoscypha coccinea: a discomycete that is a harbinger of spring; the fruiting body is thin and tough and saucer-shaped (about the size of quarter to a half dollar) with a deep bright red upper surface and a whitish exterior
652.Urnula craterium: an urn-shaped discomycete with a nearly black interior

652.Peziza domicilina: a discomycetous fungus of the genus Peziza; the fragile fruiting body is a ghostly white but stains yellow when broken; favors strongly alkaline habitats
652.Rufous rubber cup: a common name for a variety of Sarcosomataceae
652.Caloscypha fulgens: an early spring variety of discomycete with yellow to orange yellow lining of the cup
652.Leotia lubrica: a discomycete that develops in clusters of slippery rubbery gelatinous fruiting bodies that are dingy yellow to tan in color
652.ascomycete: any fungus of the class Ascomycetes (or subdivision Ascomycota) in which the spores are formed inside an ascus
652.devil's cigar: a common name for a variety of Sarcosomataceae
652.charred pancake cup: a common name for a variety of Sarcosomataceae
652.Clavicipitaceae: any of various mushrooms of the class Ascomycetes
652.Jafnea semitosta: the fruiting bodies of this discomycete have a firm texture and long retain their cup shape; the pale brown interior blends with the color of dead leaves
652.blood cup: a scarlet European fungus with cup-shaped ascocarp
652.black felt cup: a common name for a variety of Sarcosomataceae
652.discomycete: any fungus that is a member of the subclass Discomycetes
652.winter urn: a common name for a variety of Sarcosomataceae
652.Galiella rufa: the cup-shaped fruiting body of this discomycete has a jellylike interior and a short stalk

267.Garibaldi: Italian patriot whose conquest of Sicily and Naples led to the formation of the Italian state (1807-1882)

267.swing voter: a voter who has no allegiance to any political party and whose unpredictable decisions can swing the outcome of an election one way or the other

267.freedman: a person who has been freed from slavery
267.countrywoman: a woman from your own country
267.compatriot: a person from your own country
267.voter: a citizen who has a legal right to vote

122.stockpile: a storage pile accumulated for future use
122.slagheap: pile of waste matter from coal mining etc
122.compost heap: a heap of manure and vegetation and other organic residues that are decaying to become compost
122.pile: a collection of objects laid on top of each other
122.dunghill: a heap of dung or refuse

52.herring gull: large gull of the northern hemisphere
52.kittiwake: small pearl-grey gull of northern regions; nests on cliffs and has a rudimentary hind toe
52.skimmer: gull-like seabird that flies along the surface of the water with an elongated lower mandible immersed to skim out food

52.great skua: large brown skua of the northern Atlantic
52.black-backed gull: white gull having a black back and wings
52.gull: mostly white aquatic bird having long pointed wings and short legs
52.coastal diving bird: gull family; skimmer family; jaeger family; auk family
52.larid: long-winged web-footed aquatic bird of the gull family
52.mew: the common gull of Eurasia and northeastern North America

212.hadrosaur: any of numerous large bipedal ornithischian dinosaurs having a horny duck-like bill and webbed feet; may have been partly aquatic
212.corythosaur: duck-billed dinosaur with nasal passages that expand into a crest like a hollow helmet
212.styracosaur: an unusual ceratopsian dinosaur having many large spikes around the edge of its bony frill and a long nose horn; late Cretaceous
212.psittacosaur: primitive dinosaur actually lacking horns and having only the beginning of a frill; long hind limbs and short forelimbs; may have been bipedal
212.edmontosaurus: duck-billed dinosaur from Canada found as a fossilized mummy with skin
212.ankylosaur: having the back covered with thick bony plates; thought to have walked with a sprawling gait resembling a lizard's
212.triceratops: huge ceratopsian dinosaur having three horns and the neck heavily armored with a very solid frill
212.pachycephalosaur: bipedal herbivore having 10 inches of bone atop its head; largest boneheaded dinosaur ever found
212.anatotitan: one of the largest and most famous duck-billed dinosaurs
212.bone-headed dinosaur: bipedal herbivorous dinosaurs with bony crowns
212.ornithischian: herbivorous dinosaur with a pelvis like that of a bird
212.Edmontonia: heavily armored and highly spiked dinosaur with semi-upright posture
212.trachodon: large duck-billed dinosaur of the Cretaceous period
212.ceratopsian: any of several four-footed herbivorous dinosaurs with enormous beaked skulls; of the late Cretaceous in North America and Mongolia
212.stegosaur: herbivorous ornithischian dinosaur with a row of bony plates along its back and a spiked tail probably used as a weapon

605.fore-and-aft sail: any sail not set on a yard and whose normal position is in a fore-and-aft direction

281.absolute zero: (cryogenics) the lowest temperature theoretically attainable (at which the kinetic energy of atoms and molecules is minimal); 0 Kelvin or -273.15 centigrade or -459.67 Fahrenheit
281.simmer: temperature just below the boiling point
281.basal body temperature: body temperature in the morning before rising or moving about or eating anything
281.fieriness: the heat or the color of fire
281.dew point: the temperature at which the water vapor in the air becomes saturated and condensation begins
281.temperature: the degree of hotness or coldness of a body or environment (corresponding to its molecular activity)
281.lukewarmness: a warmness resembling the temperature of the skin
281.body temperature: temperature of the body; normally 98.6 F or 37 C in humans; usually measured to obtain a quick evaluation of a person's health
281.chill: coldness due to a cold environment
281.cool: the quality of being at a refreshingly low temperature
281.absolute temperature: temperature measured on the absolute scale
281.warmth: the quality of having a moderate degree of heat
281.chilliness: the property of being moderately cold
281.boiling point: the temperature at which a liquid boils at sea level

123.mouse button: a push button on the mouse

671.chop: a tennis return made with a downward motion that puts backspin on the ball

757.conidium: an asexually produced fungal spore formed on a conidiophore
757.ragweed pollen: pollen of the ragweed plant is a common allergen

757.pollinium: a coherent mass of pollen grains (as in orchids)
757.megaspore: larger of the two types of spore produced in heterosporous plants; develops in ovule into a female gametophyte
757.basidiospore: a sexually produced fungal spore borne on a basidium
757.chlamydospore: thick-walled asexual resting spore of certain fungi and algae
757.aeciospore: spore of a rust fungus formed in an aecium

531.biopiracy: biological theft; illegal collection of indigenous plants by corporations who patent them for their own use
531.pilferage: the act of stealing small amounts or small articles

531.petit larceny: larceny of property having a value less than some amount (the amount varies by locale)

531.plunderage: the act of plundering (especially the embezzlement of goods on shipboard)

154.dotted line: a line made up of dots or dashes; often used to indicate where you are supposed to sign a contract

380.Hindu calendar: the lunisolar calendar governing the religious life of Hindus; an extra month is inserted after every month in which there are two new moons (once every three years)
380.Jewish calendar: (Judaism) the calendar used by the Jews; dates from 3761 BC (the assumed date of the Creation of the world); a lunar year of 354 days is adjusted to the solar year by periodic leap years
380.Islamic calendar: the lunar calendar used by Muslims; dates from 622 AD (the year of the Hegira); the beginning of the Muslim year retrogresses through the solar year completing the cycle every 32 years
380.Gregorian calendar: the solar calendar now in general use, introduced by Gregory XIII in 1582 to correct an error in the Julian calendar by suppressing 10 days, making Oct 5 be called Oct 15, and providing that only centenary years divisible by 400 should be leap years; it was adopted by Great Britain and the American colonies in 1752
380.solar calendar: a calendar based on solar cycles
380.Revolutionary calendar: the calendar adopted by the first French Republic in 1793 and abandoned in 1805; dates were calculated from Sept. 22, 1792
380.Julian calendar: the solar calendar introduced in Rome in 46 b.c. by Julius Caesar and slightly modified by Augustus, establishing the 12-month year of 365 days with each 4th year having 366 days and the months having 31 or 30 days except for February
380.Roman calendar: the lunar calendar in use in ancient Rome; replaced by the Julian calendar in 46 BC
380.calendar: a system of timekeeping that defines the beginning and length and divisions of the year
380.lunar calendar: a calendar based on lunar cycles
380.church calendar: a calendar of the Christian year indicating the dates of fasts and festivals
380.lunisolar calendar: a calendar based on both lunar and solar cycles

704.Rain-in-the-Face: a chief of the Sioux; he was with Sitting Bull and others at the Battle of Little Bighorn (1876) when General Custer's troops were massacred (1835-1905)

644.nuclear rocket: a rocket engine in which a nuclear reactor is used to heat a propellant

90.prowler: someone who prowls or sneaks about; usually with unlawful intentions

668.thermionic emission: the emission of electrons from very hot substances

741.algin: a gum used especially as a thickener or emulsifier

285.strike: a group's refusal to work in protest against low pay or bad work conditions
285.go-slow: a form of protest by workers in which they deliberately slow down in order to cause problem from their employers

285.protest march: occasion when you can express opposition by marching (usually on some government institution) without a license
285.direct action: a protest action by labor or minority groups to obtain their demands

285.hunger strike: a voluntary fast undertaken as a means of protest

60.deputy: a member of the lower chamber of a legislative assembly (such as in France)

257.dysplasia: abnormal development (of organs or cells) or an abnormal structure resulting from such growth

257.monostotic fibrous dysplasia: fibrous dysplasia of bone confined to a single bone

225.stringency: a state occasioned by scarcity of money and a shortage of credit
