132.portal system: system of veins that carry blood from the abdominal organs to the liver
132.vascular system: the vessels and tissue that carry or circulate fluids such as blood or lymph or sap through the body of an animal or plant
132.digestive system: the system that makes food absorbable into the body
132.endoskeleton: the internal skeleton; bony and cartilaginous structure (especially of vertebrates)
132.lymphatic system: the interconnected system of spaces and vessels between body tissues and organs by which lymph circulates throughout the body
132.plastron: (zoology) the part of a turtle's shell forming its underside
132.immune system: a system (including the thymus and bone marrow and lymphoid tissues) that protects the body from foreign substances and pathogenic organisms by producing the immune response

263.control operation: an operation that controls the recording or processing or transmission of interpretation of data
263.monadic operation: an operation with exactly one operand
263.multiplex operation: an operation in which two or more activities are interleaved
263.printing operation: an operation that controls the printing or display of information
263.logic operation: an operation that follows the rules of symbolic logic
263.stovepiping: retrieval of information from unconnected databases; the situation that exists when it is necessary to climb out of one database in order to climb down into another; sometimes used for protection against wandering hackers
263.fragmentation: (computer science) the condition of a file that is broken up and stored in many different locations on a magnetic disk
263.concurrent operation: two or more operations performed at the same time (or within a give interval)
263.synchronous operation: operations that are initiated predictably by a clock
263.storage: (computer science) the process of storing information in a computer memory or on a magnetic tape or disk
263.serial operation: the sequential execution of operations one after another
263.computer operation: an elementary operation that a computer is designed and built to perform
263.retrieval: (computer science) the operation of accessing information from the computer's memory
263.carriage return: the operation that prepares for the next character to be printed or displayed as the first character on a line
263.threshold operation: an operation performed on operands in order to obtain the value of a threshold function
263.floating-point operation: an arithmetic operation performed on floating-point numbers
263.dyadic operation: an operation on exactly two operands
263.fixed-cycle operation: an operation that is completed in a specified number of regularly timed execution cycles
263.operation: (computer science) data processing in which the result is completely specified by a rule (especially the processing that results from a single instruction)
263.parallel operation: the simultaneous execution of two or more operations
263.line feed: the operation that prepares for the next character to be printed or displayed on the next line
263.majority operation: a threshold operation in which each operand is 0 or 1; output is 1 if and only if more than half the operands have the value 1
263.new line: the operation that prepares for the next character to be printed or displayed as the first character on the next line
263.sort: an operation that segregates items into groups according to a specified criterion
263.search: an operation that determines whether one or more of a set of items has a specified property
263.asynchronous operation: operations that occur without a regular or predictable time relation to other events
263.access: (computer science) the operation of reading or writing stored information
263.auxiliary operation: a operation performed by off-line equipment not under the control of the central processing unit
263.boolean operation: an operation that follows the rules of Boolean algebra; each operand and the result take one of two values
263.disk access: memory access to the computer disk on which information is stored

745.question: an instance of questioning

735.chasuble: a long sleeveless vestment worn by a priest when celebrating Mass

505.deinocheirus: lightly built medium-sized theropod with long limbs and neck
505.saurischian: herbivorous or carnivorous dinosaur having a three-pronged pelvis like that of a crocodile
505.coelophysis: one of the oldest known dinosaurs; late Triassic; cannibalistic

505.barosaur: a dinosaur that could grow to be as tall as a building five stories tall
505.herrerasaur: a kind of theropod dinosaur found in Argentina
505.Mononychus olecranus: a turkey-sized long-legged fossil 75 million years old found in the Gobi Desert having bird-like fused wrist bones and keeled breastbone and a long tail resembling a dinosaur's; short forelimbs end in a single claw instead of wings; classification as bird or dinosaur is in dispute

505.struthiomimus: small light-boned toothless dinosaur resembling an ostrich in size and proportions

505.ceratosaur: primitive medium-sized theropod; swift-running bipedal carnivorous dinosaur having grasping hands with sharp claws and a short horn between the nostrils; Jurassic in North America
505.ornithomimid: lightly built medium-sized dinosaur having extremely long limbs and necks with small heads and big brains and large eyes
505.theropod: any of numerous carnivorous dinosaurs of the Triassic to Cretaceous with short forelimbs that walked or ran on strong hind legs
505.apatosaur: huge quadrupedal herbivorous dinosaur common in North America in the late Jurassic
505.megalosaur: gigantic carnivorous bipedal dinosaur of the Jurassic or early Cretaceous in Europe

574.Cyrillic alphabet: an alphabet derived from the Greek alphabet and used for writing Slavic languages (Russian, Bulgarian, Serbian, Ukrainian, and some other Slavic languages)

197.European water shrew: widely distributed Old World water shrew

567.First Crusade: a Crusade from 1096 to 1099; captured Jerusalem and created a theocracy there
567.Okinawa: a campaign in the closing days of World War II in the Pacific (April to June 1945); in savage close-quarter fighting United States marines and regular army troops took the island from the Japanese; considered the greatest victory of the Pacific campaign for the Americans

567.Dardanelles: the unsuccessful campaign in World War I (1915) by the English and French to open a passage for aid to Russia; defeated by the Turks

567.Fifth Crusade: a Crusade under papal control from 1218 to 1221 that achieved military victories but failed when dissension arose over accepting the terms they had been offered

567.Petersburg: the final campaign of the American Civil War (1864-65); Union forces under Grant besieged and finally defeated Confederate forces under Lee
567.expedition: a military campaign designed to achieve a specific objective in a foreign country

567.Sixth Crusade: a Crusade from 1228 to 1229 led by the Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II who fell ill and was excommunicated by the Pope; by negotiation Frederick II was able to crown himself king of Jerusalem

534.crank call: a hostile telephone call (from a crank)

12.forked lightning: a form of lightning that moves rapidly in a zigzag path with one end divided (fork-like)

391.granulocyte: a leukocyte that has granules in its cytoplasm
391.leukocyte: blood cells that engulf and digest bacteria and fungi; an important part of the body's defense system
391.plasmablast: the precursor of a plasma cell
391.monocyte: a type of granular leukocyte that functions in the ingestion of bacteria
391.basophil: a leukocyte with basophilic granules easily stained by basic stains
391.B cell: a lymphocyte derived from bone marrow that provides humoral immunity; it recognizes free antigen molecules in solution and matures into plasma cells that secrete immunoglobulin (antibodies) that inactivate the antigens
391.myelocyte: an immature leukocyte normally found in bone marrow
391.myeloblast: a precursor of leukocytes that normally occurs only in bone marrow
391.T cell: a small lymphocyte developed in the thymus; it orchestrates the immune system's response to infected or malignant cells
391.microphage: a neutrophil that ingests small things (as bacteria)
391.helper T cell: T cell with CD4 receptor that recognizes antigens on the surface of a virus-infected cell and secretes lymphokines that stimulate B cells and killer T cells; helper T cells are infected and killed by the AIDS virus
391.monoblast: a large immature monocyte normally found in bone marrow
391.eosinophil: a leukocyte readily stained with eosin
391.plasma cell: a cell that develops from a B lymphocyte in reaction to a specific antigen; found in bone marrow and sometimes in the blood
391.killer T cell: T cell with CD8 receptor that recognizes antigens on the surface of a virus-infected cell and binds to the infected cell and kill it
391.lymphocyte: an agranulocytic leukocyte that normally makes up a quarter of the white blood cell count but increases in the presence of infection
391.neutrophil: the chief phagocytic leukocyte; stains with either basic or acid dyes

747.sheep dip: a liquid mixture containing pesticides in which sheep are dipped to kill parasites
747.larvacide: an insecticide that kills the larvae of insects
747.arsenical: a pesticide or drug containing arsenic
747.spray: a pesticide in suspension or solution; intended for spraying

747.parathion: a colorless and odorless toxic oil used as an insecticide

747.insecticide: a chemical used to kill insects

595.appendicular skeleton: the part of the skeleton that includes the pectoral girdle and the pelvic girdle and the upper and lower limbs

233.stacks: storage space in a library consisting of an extensive arrangement of bookshelves where most of the books are stored

597.retardation: the extent to which something is delayed or held back

597.pause: a time interval during which there is a temporary cessation of something
597.absence: the time interval during which something or somebody is away
597.delay: time during which some action is awaited
597.halftime: an intermission between the first and second half of a game
597.letup: a pause during which things are calm or activities are diminished
597.interim: the time between one event, process, or period and another
597.time interval: a definite length of time marked off by two instants

597.command processing overhead time: (computer science) the processing time required by a device prior to the execution of a command

597.interregnum: the time between two reigns, governments, etc.

597.lead time: the time interval between the initiation and the completion of a production process

597.entr'acte: the interlude between two acts of a play
597.seek time: (computer science) the time it takes for a read/write head to move to a specific data track
597.processing time: the time it takes to complete a prescribed procedure
597.blackout: a suspension of radio or tv broadcasting
597.cycle: an interval during which a recurring sequence of events occurs
597.relaxation time: the time constant of an exponential return of a system to equilibrium after a disturbance
597.orbit period: the time it takes to complete one full orbit around a celestial body

698.long fly: a gymnastic exercise involving a long leap from a vaulting horse

256.Wiesenthal: Austrian investigator of Nazi war crimes (born in 1908)

256.ombudsman: a government appointee who investigates complaints by private persons against the government

347.countertenor: the highest adult male singing voice

347.baritone: the second lowest adult male singing voice
347.soprano: the highest female voice; the voice of a boy before puberty
347.tenor: the adult male singing voice above baritone

347.bass: the lowest adult male singing voice

641.volatile storage: computer storage that is erased when the power is turned off
641.erasable programmable read-only memory: (computer science) a read-only memory chip that can be erased by ultraviolet light and programmed again with new data
641.scratchpad: (computer science) a high-speed internal memory used for temporary storage of preliminary information
641.read-only memory: (computer science) memory whose contents can be accessed and read but cannot be changed
641.flash memory: nonvolatile storage that can be electrically erased and programmed anew
641.magnetic bubble memory: a nonvolatile storage device that holds information in the form of bubbles on a thin film of magnetic silicate; no longer used in most computers
641.non-volatile storage: computer storage that is not lost when the power is turned off
641.magnetic core memory: (computer science) a computer memory consisting of an array of magnetic cores; now superseded by semiconductor memories
641.random-access memory: the most common computer memory which can be used by programs to perform necessary tasks while the computer is on; an integrated circuit memory chip allows information to be stored or accessed in any order and all storage locations are equally accessible
641.CD-ROM: a compact disk that is used with a computer (rather than with an audio system); a large amount of digital information can be stored and accessed but it cannot be altered by the user
641.real storage: the main memory in a virtual memory system
641.virtual memory: (computer science) memory created by using the hard disk to simulate additional random-access memory; the addressable storage space available to the user of a computer system in which virtual addresses are mapped into real addresses

6.pill bottle: a small bottle for holding pills

6.bota: a wine bottle made of leather

84.cud: food of a ruminant regurgitated to be chewed again

324.medium: someone who serves as an intermediary between the living and the dead

65.breach of warranty: a breach that occurs when an item is deficient according to the terms of a warranty
65.anticipatory breach: a breach of contract committed prior to the time of required performance
65.breach of trust: violation (either through fraud or negligence) by a trustee of a duty that equity requires of him
65.disappointment: an act (or failure to act) that disappoints someone
65.breach: a failure to perform some promised act or obligation
65.breach of contract: a breach of a legal duty; failure to do something that is required in a contract
65.breach of promise: failure to keep a promise (of marriage)
65.breach of the covenant of warranty: a failure of the seller's guarantee of good title
65.partial breach: a breach that does not destroy the value of the contract but can give rise to a claim for damages

648.insanity: relatively permanent disorder of the mind
648.Pick's disease: a progressive form of presenile dementia found most often in middle-aged and elderly women and characterized by degeneration of the frontal and temporal lobes with loss of intellectual ability and transitory aphasia
648.alcoholic dementia: dementia observed during the last stages of severe chronic alcoholism; involves loss of memory for recent events although long term memory is intact
648.irrationality: the state of being irrational; lacking powers of understanding
648.senile dementia: dementia of the aged; results from degeneration of the brain in the absence of cerebrovascular disease
648.dementia: mental deterioration of organic or functional origin
648.presenile dementia: dementia with onset before the age of 65
648.derangement: a state of mental disturbance and disorientation
648.Alzheimer's disease: a progressive form of presenile dementia that is similar to senile dementia except that it usually starts in the 40s or 50s; first symptoms are impaired memory which is followed by impaired thought and speech and finally complete helplessness

456.bewilderment: confusion resulting from failure to understand
456.dilemma: state of uncertainty or perplexity especially as requiring a choice between equally unfavorable options
456.double bind: (psychology) an unresolvable dilemma; situation in which a person receives contradictory messages from a person who is very powerful
456.half-cock: confusion resulting from lack of preparation
456.confusion: a mental state characterized by a lack of clear and orderly thought and behavior
456.disorientation: confusion (usually transient) about where you are and how to proceed; uncertainty as to direction
456.perplexity: trouble or confusion resulting from complexity
456.daze: confusion characterized by lack of clarity
456.jamais vu: the experience of being unfamiliar with a person or situation that is actually very familiar; associated with certain types of epilepsy
456.mystery: something that baffles understanding and cannot be explained

660.algidity: prostration characterized by cold and clammy skin and low blood pressure
660.hypovolemic shock: shock caused by severe blood or fluid loss
660.collapse: an abrupt failure of function or complete physical exhaustion
660.obstructive shock: shock caused by obstruction of blood flow
660.shock: (pathology) bodily collapse or near collapse caused by inadequate oxygen delivery to the cells; characterized by reduced cardiac output and rapid heartbeat and circulatory insufficiency and pallor
660.distributive shock: shock caused by poor distribution of the blood flow
660.nervous breakdown: a severe or incapacitating emotional disorder
660.sunstroke: sudden prostration due to exposure to the sun or excessive heat
660.insulin shock: hypoglycemia produced by excessive insulin in the system causing coma
660.nervous exhaustion: an emotional disorder that leaves you exhausted and unable to work
660.heatstroke: collapse caused by exposure to excessive heat
660.heat exhaustion: a condition marked by dizziness and nausea and weakness caused by depletion of body fluids and electrolytes

172.youth culture: young adults (a generational unit) considered as a cultural class or subculture
172.mods: a youth subculture that began in London in the early 1960s; a working-class movement with highly stylized dress and short hair; listened to rhythm and blues music and travelled on motor scooters
172.rockers: originally a British youth subculture that evolved out of the teddy boys in the 1960s; wore black leather jackets and jeans and boots; had greased hair and rode motorcycles and listened to rock'n'roll; were largely unskilled manual laborers
172.beat generation: a United States youth subculture of the 1950s; rejected possessions or regular work or traditional dress; for communal living and psychedelic drugs and anarchism; favored modern forms of jazz (e.g., bebop)
172.punks: a youth subculture closely associated with punk rock music in the late 1970s; in part a reaction to the hippy subculture; dress was optional but intended to shock (plastic garbage bags or old school uniforms) and hair was dyed in bright colors (in Mohican haircuts or sometimes spiked in bright plumes)
172.teddy boys: a British youth subculture that first appeared in the 1950s; mainly from unskilled backgrounds, they adopted a pseudo-Edwardian dress code and rock'n'roll music; proletarian and xenophobic, they were involved in race riots in the United Kingdom
172.hip-hop: an urban youth culture associated with rap music and the fashions of African-American residents of the inner city
172.subculture: a social group within a national culture that has distinctive patterns of behavior and beliefs
172.Rastafari: (Jamaica) a Black youth subculture and religious movement that arose in the ghettos of Kingston, Jamaica, in the 1950s; males grow hair in long dreadlocks and wear woolen caps; use marijuana and listen to reggae music
172.youth subculture: a minority youth culture whose distinctiveness depended largely on the social class and ethnic background of its members; often characterized by its adoption of a particular music genre
172.skinheads: a youth subculture that appeared first in England in the late 1960s as a working-class reaction to the hippies; hair was cropped close to the scalp; wore work-shirts and short jeans (supported by suspenders) and heavy red boots; involved in attacks against Asians and football hooliganism
172.psychedelia: the subculture of users of psychedelic drugs
172.suburbia: suburbanites considered as a cultural class or subculture
172.flower people: a youth subculture (mostly from the middle class) originating in San Francisco in the 1960s; advocated universal love and peace and communes and long hair and soft drugs; favored acid rock and progressive rock music

20.renal failure: inability of the kidneys to excrete wastes and to help maintain the electrolyte balance
20.renal insufficiency: insufficient excretion of wastes by the kidneys
20.glomerulonephritis: nephritis marked by inflammation of the glomeruli of the kidney; characterized by decreased production of urine and by the presence of blood and protein in the urine and by edema
20.uropathy: any pathology of the urinary tract
20.chronic renal failure: renal failure that can result from a variety of systemic disorders
20.polyuria: renal disorder characterized by the production of large volumes of pale dilute urine; often associated with diabetes
20.polycystic kidney disease: kidney disease characterized by enlarged kidneys containing many cysts; often leads to kidney failure
20.nephrosclerosis: kidney disease that is usually associated with hypertension; sclerosis of the renal arterioles reduces blood flow that can lead to kidney failure and heart failure
20.acute renal failure: renal failure associated with burns or other trauma or with acute infection or obstruction of the urinary tract

503.maleness: the properties characteristic of the male sex

655.fleur-de-lis: (heraldry) charge consisting of a conventionalized representation of an iris

655.ordinary: (heraldry) any of several conventional figures used on shields

368.inflationary spiral: an episode of inflation in which prices and wages increase at an increasing rate and currency rapidly loses value
368.cost-pull inflation: inflation caused by an increase in the costs of production
368.deflationary spiral: an episode of deflation in which prices and wages decrease at an increasing rate and currency gains in value
368.consumption: (economics) the utilization of economic goods to satisfy needs or in manufacturing
368.economic growth: steady growth in the productive capacity of the economy (and so a growth of national income)
368.inflation: a general and progressive increase in prices
368.market forces: the interaction of supply and demand that shapes a market economy
368.conspicuous consumption: buying expensive services and products in order to flaunt your wealth
368.demand: the ability and desire to purchase goods and services
368.economic process: any process affecting the production and development and management of material wealth
368.stagflation: a period of slow economic growth and high unemployment (stagnation) while prices rise (inflation)
368.demand-pull inflation: inflation caused by an increase in demand or in the supply of money
368.reflation: inflation of currency after a period of deflation; restore the system to a previous state
368.globalization: growth to a global or worldwide scale
368.disinflation: a reduction of prices intended to improve the balance of payments
368.spiral: a continuously accelerating change in the economy
368.deflation: a contraction of economic activity resulting in a decline of prices
368.supply: offering goods and services for sale

666.contact: (electronics) a junction where things (as two electrical conductors) touch or are in physical contact
666.joint: junction by which parts or objects are joined together
666.terminal: a contact on an electrical device (such as a battery) at which electric current enters or leaves
666.rabbet joint: a joint formed by fitting together two rabbeted boards
666.spot weld: each of the welds made by welding at a separate point
666.tee hinge: a hinge that looks like the letter T when it is opened; similar to a strap hinge except that one strap has been replaced by half of a butt hinge that can be mortised flush into the stationary frame
666.junction barrier: a junction unit for connecting 2 cables without the need for plugs
666.p-n junction: the junction between a p-type semiconductor and an n-type semiconductor
666.strap hinge: a hinge with two long straps; one strap is fastened to the surface of a moving part (e.g., a door or lid) and the other is fastened to the adjacent stationary frame
666.dovetail: a mortise joint formed by interlocking tenons and mortises
666.distributor point: a contact in the distributor; as the rotor turns its projecting arm contacts them and current flows to the spark plugs
666.negative pole: the terminal of a battery that is connected to the negative plate
666.short circuit: accidental contact between two points in an electric circuit that have a potential difference
666.toggle joint: a joint made by two arms attached by a pivot; used to apply pressure at the two ends by straightening the joint
666.miter joint: joint that forms a corner; usually both sides are bevelled at a 45-degree angle to form a 90-degree corner
666.butt weld: a butt joint that is welded
666.knuckle joint: a joint allowing movement in one plane only
666.tongue and groove joint: a mortise joint made by fitting a projection on the edge of one board into a matching groove on another board
666.butt joint: a joint made by fastening ends together without overlapping
666.hinge: a joint that holds two parts together so that one can swing relative to the other
666.scarf joint: a joint made by notching the ends of two pieces of timber or metal so that they will lock together end-to-end
666.weld: a metal joint formed by softening with heat and fusing or hammering together
666.anode: the negatively charged terminal of a voltaic cell or storage battery that supplies current
666.ball-and-socket joint: a joint that can rotate within a socket
666.butt hinge: a hinge mortised flush into the edge of the door and jamb
666.positive pole: the terminal of a battery that is connected to the positive plate
666.electrical contact: contact that allows current to pass from one conductor to another
666.wiper: contact consisting of a conducting arm that rotates over a series of fixed contacts and comes to rest on an outlet
666.seam: joint consisting of a line formed by joining two pieces
666.sound bow: contact (the part of a bell) against which the clapper strikes
666.fell: seam made by turning under or folding together and stitching the seamed materials to avoid rough edges
666.mortise joint: a joint made by inserting tenon on one piece into mortise holes in the other
666.fish joint: a butt joint formed by bolting fish plates to the sides of two rails or beams
666.splice: a junction where two things (as paper or film or magnetic tape) have been joined together
666.lap joint: joint made by overlapping two ends and joining them together
666.tread: the part (as of a wheel or shoe) that makes contact with the ground
666.thermojunction: a junction between two dissimilar metals across which a voltage appears

313.cytochrome: (biochemistry) a class of hemoprotein whose principal biological function is electron transfer (especially in cellular respiration)
313.hemoprotein: a conjugated protein linked to a compound of iron and porphyrin
313.lipoprotein: a conjugated protein having a lipid component; the principal means for transporting lipids in the blood
313.high-density lipoprotein: a lipoprotein that transports cholesterol in the blood; composed of a high proportion of protein and relatively little cholesterol; high levels are thought to be associated with decreased risk of coronary heart disease and atherosclerosis
313.lectin: any of several plant glycoproteins that act like specific antibodies but are not antibodies in that they are not evoked by an antigenic stimulus
313.cytochrome c: the most abundant and stable cytochrome; involved in energy transfer
313.mucoid: any of several glycoproteins similar to mucin
313.erythropoietin: a glycoprotein secreted by the kidneys that stimulates the production of red blood cells
313.hemoglobin: a hemoprotein composed of globin and heme that gives red blood cells their characteristic color; function primarily to transport oxygen from the lungs to the body tissues
313.oxyhemoglobin: the bright red hemoglobin that is a combination of hemoglobin and oxygen from the lungs
313.glycoprotein: a conjugated protein having a carbohydrate component
313.low-density lipoprotein: a lipoprotein that transports cholesterol in the blood; composed of moderate amount of protein and a large amount of cholesterol; high levels are thought to be associated with increased risk of coronary heart disease and atherosclerosis
313.mucin: a nitrogenous substance found in mucous secretions; a lubricant that protects body surfaces
313.cluster of differentiation 4: a glycoprotein that is found primarily on the surface of helper T cells
313.conjugated protein: a protein complex combining amino acids with other substances
313.myoglobin: a hemoprotein that receives oxygen from hemoglobin and stores it in the tissues until needed
313.cluster of differentiation 8: a membrane glycoprotein that is found primarily on the surface of cytotoxic T cells
313.very low density lipoprotein: large lipoproteins rich in triglycerides; VLDLs circulate through the blood giving up their triglycerides to fat and muscle tissue until the VLDL remnants are modified and converted into LDL

95.surface noise: noise produced by the friction of the stylus of a record player moving over the rotating record
95.jitter: small rapid variations in a waveform resulting from fluctuations in the voltage supply or mechanical vibrations or other sources
95.background noise: extraneous noise contaminating sound measurements that cannot be separated from the desired signal
95.clutter: unwanted echoes that interfere with the observation of signals on a radar screen
95.background radiation: radiation coming from sources other than those being observed
95.white noise: a noise produced by a stimulus containing all of the audible frequencies of vibration
95.noise: electrical or acoustic activity that can disturb communication
95.crosstalk: the presence of an unwanted signal via an accidental coupling
95.background: extraneous signals that can be confused with the phenomenon to be observed or measured
95.fadeout: a gradual temporary loss of a transmitted signal due to electrical disturbances
95.static: a crackling or hissing noise caused by electrical interference

37.bunk bed: beds built one above the other

37.deathbed: the bed on which a person dies

37.cot: a small bed that folds up for storage or transport

37.marriage bed: the bed shared by a newly wed couple
37.four-poster: a bed with posts at the four corners that can be used to support a canopy or curtains
37.bedroom furniture: furniture intended for use in a bedroom

37.sickbed: the bed on which a sick person lies
37.bunk: a long trough for feeding cattle

81.guestroom: a bedroom that is kept for the use of guests

115.eight: the cardinal number that is the sum of seven and one

96.Treasury: negotiable debt obligations of the United States government which guarantees that interest and principal payments will be paid on time
96.noncallable bond: a bond containing a provision that the holder cannot redeem the security before a specific date (usually at maturity)
96.convertible bond: a bond that can be converted to other securities under certain conditions
96.bond issue: bonds sold by a corporation or government agency at a particular time and identifiable by date of maturity
96.Treasury note: securities with maturities of 1 to 10 years; sold for cash or in exchange for maturing issues or at auction
96.revenue bond: a bond issued by an agency that is commissioned to finance public works; revenue from the public property is used to pay off the bond
96.performance bond: a bond given to protect the recipient against loss in case the terms of a contract are not filled; a surety company assumes liability for nonperformance
96.zero coupon bond: a bond that is issued at a deep discount from its value at maturity and pays no interest during the life of the bond; the commonest form of zero-coupon security
96.unsecured bond: the ability of a customer to obtain goods or services before payment, based on the trust that payment will be made in the future
96.Premium Bond: a government bond that bears no interest or capital gains but enters the holder into lotteries
96.post-obit bond: a bond made by a reversioner to secure a loan; payable out of his reversion
96.utility bond: a bond issued to finance the construction of public utility services
96.municipal bond: a bond issued by a state or local government
96.Treasury bill: a short-term obligation that is not interest-bearing (it is purchased at a discount); can be traded on a discount basis for 91 days
96.registered bond: a bond whose owner is recorded on the books of the issuer; can be transferred to another owner only when endorsed by the registered owner
96.bond: a certificate of debt (usually interest-bearing or discounted) that is issued by a government or corporation in order to raise money; the issuer is required to pay a fixed sum annually until maturity and then a fixed sum to repay the principal
96.Treasury bond: a debt instrument with maturities of 10 years or longer
96.coupon bond: a bond issued with detachable coupons that must be presented to the issuer for interest payments
96.corporate bond: a bond issued by a corporation; carries no claim to ownership and pays no dividends but payments to bondholders have priority over payments to stockholders
96.savings bond: non-negotiable government bond; cannot be bought and sold once the original purchase is made
96.secured bond: a bond that is back by collateral
96.government bond: a bond that is an IOU of the United States Treasury; considered the safest security in the investment world
96.junk bond: a (speculative) bond with a credit rating of BB or lower; issued for leveraged buyouts and other takeovers by companies with questionable credit

21.buff: a soft thick undyed leather from the skins of e.g. buffalo or oxen

147.banking game: any gambling game in which bets are laid against the gambling house or the dealer
147.lucky dip: a game in which prizes (e.g., candies or coins) are concealed in a container and for a small sum a player can draw one out at random
147.throw: casting an object in order to determine an outcome randomly

147.superfecta: a bet that you can pick the first four finishers in a race in the right order
147.exacta: a bet that you can pick the first and second finishers in the right order

147.lottery: players buy (or are given) chances and prizes are distributed by casting lots
147.parlay: a series of wagers in which the winnings from one wager are used as a stake for the subsequent wagers
147.place bet: a bet that a horse will finish a race no worse than second

147.flip: the act of flipping a coin
147.parimutuel: betting where winners share the total amount wagered
147.raffle: a lottery in which the prizes are goods rather than money

754.sewing-machine operator: someone who sews by operating a sewing machine

754.fitter: someone who fits a garment to a particular person

295.eye operation: any surgical procedure involving the eyes
295.laser trabecular surgery: eye surgery that makes many tiny laser burns in an area that will increase the drainage of aqueous humor
295.vitrectomy: a surgical procedure that removes the vitreous humor and replace it with saline solution
295.phacoemulsification: extracapsular surgery for cataracts in which ultrasonic sound breaks the cortex and nucleus of the lens into small fragments that are then vacuumed away through a small tube
295.filtration surgery: eye surgery that opens a passage allowing excess aqueous humor to drain into surrounding tissues; a treatment for glaucoma
295.intracapsular surgery: cataract surgery in which the entire lens is removed
295.laser-assisted subepithelial keratomileu: a refractive surgery procedure that reshapes the cornea
295.laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis: a refractive surgery procedure that reshapes the cornea
295.extracapsular surgery: cataract surgery in which only the front of the lens is removed; the back of the lens capsule remains intact and provides support for the lens implant
295.iridotomy: a surgical procedure that makes an incision in the iris of the eye in order to enlarge the pupil or to treat closed-angle glaucoma
295.radial keratotomy: radial pattern of incisions in the cornea that cause the cornea to bulge; performed to correct myopia
295.iridectomy: an eye operation that treats closed-angle glaucoma by surgical removal of part of the iris of the eye
295.cataract surgery: eye surgery that involves removing all or part of the lens and replacing it with an intraocular lens implant
295.cyclodestructive surgery: an eye operation that treats glaucoma by destroying the ciliary body with a laser

260.mercury cell: a primary cell consisting of a zinc anode and a cathode of mercury oxide and an electrolyte of potassium hydroxide
260.Clark cell: a form of voltaic cell once used as a standard for electromotive force
260.Leclanche cell: voltaic cell that produces approximately 1.5 volts
260.cell: a device that delivers an electric current as the result of a chemical reaction
260.storage cell: a cell that can be recharged
260.dry cell: a small Leclanche cell containing no free liquid; the electrolyte is a paste and the negative zinc pole forms the container of the cell; used in flashlights, portable radios, etc.
260.electrolytic cell: a cell containing an electrolyte in which an applied voltage causes a reaction to occur that would not occur otherwise (such as the breakdown of water into hydrogen and oxygen)
260.solar cell: a cell that converts solar energy into electrical energy
260.wet cell: a primary voltaic cell having a liquid electrolyte
260.standard cell: a primary cell used as a standard of electromotive force
260.fuel cell: cell that produces electricity by oxidation of fuel (hydrogen and oxygen or zinc and air); often used in electric cars
260.voltaic cell: an electric cell that generates an electromotive force by an irreversible conversion of chemical to electrical energy; cannot be recharged

71.burl: a large rounded outgrowth on the trunk or branch of a tree

141.particle: a function word that can be used in English to form phrasal verbs
141.preposition: a function word that combines with a noun or pronoun or noun phrase to form a prepositional phrase that can have an adverbial or adjectival relation to some other word
141.indefinite article: a determiner (as `a' or `some' in English) that indicates nonspecific reference
141.determiner: one of a limited class of noun modifiers that determine the referents of noun phrases
141.personal pronoun: a pronoun expressing a distinction of person
141.coordinating conjunction: a conjunction (like `and' or `or') that connects two identically constructed grammatical constituents
141.reflexive pronoun: a personal pronoun compounded with -self to show the agent's action affects the agent
141.relative pronoun: a pronoun (as `that' or `which' or `who') that introduces a relative clause referring to some antecedent
141.pronoun: a function word that is used in place of a noun or noun phrase
141.demonstrative pronoun: a pronoun that points out an intended referent
141.function word: a word that is uninflected and serves a grammatical function but has little identifiable meaning
141.anaphoric pronoun: a pronoun that refers to an antecedent
141.subordinating conjunction: a conjunction (like `since' or `that' or `who') that introduces a dependent clause
141.definite article: a determiner (as `the' in English) that indicates specificity of reference
141.article: (grammar) a determiner that may indicate the specificity of reference of a noun phrase
141.conjunction: an uninflected function word that serves to conjoin words or phrases or clauses or sentences
141.reciprocal pronoun: a pronoun or pronominal phrase (as `each other') that expresses a mutual action or relationship between the individuals indicated in the plural subject

192.reserve: something kept back or saved for future use or a special purpose

464.left: a turn toward the side of the body that is on the north when the person is facing east

725.analytical review: an auditing procedure based on ratios among accounts and tries to identify significant changes
725.debit: an accounting entry acknowledging sums that are owing

725.review: (accounting) a service (less exhaustive than an audit) that provides some assurance to interested parties as to the reliability of financial data
725.register: a book in which names and transactions are listed

725.control account: an account that shows totals of amounts entered in a subsidiary ledger

82.radio interferometer: radio telescope that uses interference patterns from two antennas instead of a parabolic antenna

740.adaptability: the ability to change (or be changed) to fit changed circumstances
740.capability: the quality of being capable -- physically or intellectually or legally
740.overkill: the capability to obliterate a target with more weapons (especially nuclear weapons) than are required
740.penetration: the ability to make way into or through something

740.interoperability: (computer science) the ability to exchange and use information (usually in a large heterogeneous network made up of several local area networks)
740.competence: the quality of being adequately or well qualified physically and intellectually
740.contractility: the capability or quality of shrinking or contracting, especially by muscle fibers and even some other forms of living matter
740.flexibility: the quality of being adaptable or variable
740.antenna: sensitivity similar to that of a receptor organ
740.sensitivity: the ability to respond to affective changes in your interpersonal environment
740.lycanthropy: (folklore) the magical ability of a person to assume the characteristics of a wolf

740.firepower: (military) the relative capacity for delivering fire on a target
740.wiggle room: flexibility of interpretation or of options
740.envelope: the maximum operating capability of a system (especially an aircraft)
740.military capability: capability in terms of personnel and materiel that affect the capacity to fight a war
740.astringency: the ability to contract or draw together soft body tissues to check blood flow or restrict secretion of fluids
740.proficiency: the quality of having great facility and competence
740.physical ability: the ability to perform some physical act; contrasting with mental ability
740.totipotency: the ability of a cell to give rise to unlike cells and so to develop a new organism or part
740.operating capability: the capability of a technological system to perform as intended
740.perceptiveness: the quality of insight and sympathetic understanding
740.ability: the quality of being able to perform; a quality that permits or facilitates achievement or accomplishment
