658.diminution: the statement of a theme in notes of lesser duration (usually half the length of the original)
658.inversion: (counterpoint) a variation of a melody or part in which ascending intervals are replaced by descending intervals and vice versa
658.canto: the highest part (usually the melody) in a piece of choral music
658.theme song: a melody that recurs and comes to represent a musical play or movie
658.descant: a decorative musical accompaniment (often improvised) added above a basic melody
658.motif: a theme that is repeated or elaborated in a piece of music
658.glissando: a rapid series of ascending or descending notes on the musical scale
658.leitmotiv: a melodic phrase that accompanies the reappearance of a person or situation (as in Wagner's operas)
658.secondo: the second or lower part of a duet (especially a piano duet)
658.statement: (music) the presentation of a musical theme
658.theme: (music) melodic subject of a musical composition
658.accompaniment: a musical part (vocal or instrumental) that supports or provides background for other musical parts
658.figured bass: a bass part written out in full and accompanied by numbers to indicate the chords to be played
658.flourish: (music) a short lively tune played on brass instruments
658.tune: a succession of notes forming a distinctive sequence
658.swoop: (music) rapid sliding up or down the musical scale
658.variation: a repetition of a musical theme in which it is modified or embellished
658.voice part: a part written for a singer
658.ground bass: a short melody in the bass that is constantly repeated
658.augmentation: the statement of a theme in notes of greater duration (usually twice the length of the original)
658.signature: a melody used to identify a performer or a dance band or radio/tv program
658.bass: the lowest part in polyphonic music

145.leech: carnivorous or bloodsucking aquatic or terrestrial worms typically having a sucker at each end
145.archiannelid: small primitive marine worm lacking external segmentation and resembling polychaete larvae
145.polychaete: chiefly marine annelids possessing both sexes and having paired appendages (parapodia) bearing bristles
145.helminth: worm that is parasitic on the intestines of vertebrates especially roundworms and tapeworms and flukes
145.beard worm: slender animal with tentacles and a tubelike outer covering; lives on the deep ocean bottom
145.pinworm: small threadlike worm infesting human intestines and rectum especially in children
145.planarian: free-swimming mostly freshwater flatworms; popular in laboratory studies for the ability to regenerate lost parts
145.worm: any of numerous relatively small elongated soft-bodied animals especially of the phyla Annelida and Chaetognatha and Nematoda and Nemertea and Platyhelminthes; also many insect larvae
145.taenia: tapeworms parasitic in humans which uses the pig as its intermediate host
145.nematode: unsegmented worms with elongated rounded body pointed at both ends; mostly free-living but some are parasitic
145.Guinea worm: parasitic roundworm of India and Africa that lives in the abdomen or beneath the skin of humans and other vertebrates
145.fluke: parasitic flatworms having external suckers for attaching to a host
145.acanthocephalan: any of various worms living parasitically in intestines of vertebrates having a retractile proboscis covered with many hooked spines
145.earthworm: terrestrial worm that burrows into and helps aerate soil; often surfaces when the ground is cool or wet; used as bait by anglers
145.sagitta: any arrowworm of the genus Sagitta
145.eelworm: any of various small free-living plant-parasitic roundworms
145.sea mouse: any of several large worms having a broad flattened body with a mat of coarse hairs covering the back
145.echinococcus: tapeworms whose larvae are parasitic in humans and domestic animals
145.medicinal leech: large European freshwater leech formerly used for bloodletting
145.oligochaete: hermaphroditic terrestrial and aquatic annelids having bristles borne singly along the length of the body
145.annelid: worms with cylindrical bodies segmented both internally and externally
145.bloodworm: a segmented marine worm with bright red body; often used for bait
145.common roundworm: intestinal parasite of humans and pigs
145.vinegar eel: minute eelworm that feeds on organisms that cause fermentation in e.g. vinegar
145.flatworm: parasitic or free-living worms having a flattened body
145.arrowworm: any worm of the Chaetognatha; transparent marine worm with horizontal lateral and caudal fins and a row of movable curved spines at each side of the mouth
145.filaria: slender threadlike roundworms living in the blood and tissues of vertebrates; transmitted as larvae by biting insects
145.schistosome: flatworms parasitic in the blood vessels of mammals
145.liver fluke: flatworm parasitic in liver and bile ducts of domestic animals and humans
145.trichina: parasitic nematode occurring in the intestines of pigs and rats and human beings and producing larvae that form cysts in skeletal muscles
145.ribbon worm: soft unsegmented marine worms that have a threadlike proboscis and the ability to stretch and contract
145.hookworm: parasitic bloodsucking roundworms having hooked mouth parts to fasten to the intestinal wall of human and other hosts
145.lugworm: marine worms having a row of tufted gills along each side of the back; often used for fishing bait
145.horseleech: any of several large freshwater leeches
145.Fasciolopsis buski: fluke that is parasitic on humans and swine; common in eastern Asia
145.tapeworm: ribbonlike flatworms that are parasitic in the intestines of humans and other vertebrates

478.vascular ray: a sheet of vascular tissue separating the vascular bundles
478.midrib: the vein in the center of a leaf
478.cambium: a formative one-cell layer of tissue between xylem and phloem in most vascular plants that is responsible for secondary growth
478.tracheid: long tubular cell peculiar to xylem
478.vascular bundle: a unit strand of the vascular system in stems and leaves of higher plants consisting essentially of xylem and phloem
478.vein: any of the vascular bundles or ribs that form the branching framework of conducting and supporting tissues in a leaf or other plant organ
478.phloem: (botany) tissue that conducts synthesized food substances (e.g., from leaves) to parts where needed; consists primarily of sieve tubes
478.stele: the usually cylindrical central vascular portion of the axis of a vascular plant
478.xylem: the woody part of plants: the supporting and water-conducting tissue, consisting primarily of tracheids and vessels
478.sieve tube: tube formed by cells joined end-to-end through which nutrients flow in flowering plants and brown algae
478.vascular tissue: tissue that conducts water and nutrients through the plant body in higher plants

266.trotter: foot of a pig or sheep especially one used as food
266.lobate foot: a bird's foot having separate toes each with membranous flaps along the sides
266.hoof: the foot of an ungulate mammal
266.webfoot: a foot having the toes connected by folds of skin
266.forepaw: front paw; analogous to the human hand
266.hand: terminal part of the forelimb in certain vertebrates (e.g. apes or kangaroos); - Springfield (Mass.) Union
266.webbed foot: a bird's foot with folds of skin between the toes
266.cloven foot: a hoof divided into two parts at its distal extremity (as of ruminants or swine)
266.zygodactyl foot: a bird's foot having the first and fourth toes of each foot directed backward and the second and third forward
266.heterodactyl foot: a bird's foot having the first and second toes of each foot directed backward and the third and fourth forward
266.paw: a clawed foot of an animal especially a quadruped
266.animal foot: the pedal extremity of vertebrates other than human beings
266.forefoot: a front foot of a quadruped
266.fossorial foot: foot adapted for digging as in moles
266.hindfoot: a rear foot of a quadruped

239.religious trance: a trance induced by intense religious devotion; does not show reduced bodily functions that are typical of other trances
239.coma: a state of deep and often prolonged unconsciousness; usually the result of disease or injury
239.electrosleep: unconsciousness brought about by the passage of a low voltage electric current through the brain
239.hepatic coma: coma that can occur in severe cases of liver disease
239.forgetfulness: unawareness caused by neglectful or heedless failure to remember
239.unconsciousness: a state lacking normal awareness of the self or environment
239.unselfconsciousness: the quality of being not self-conscious; unawareness of yourself or of others' views of yourself
239.nitrogen narcosis: confused or stuporous state caused by high levels of dissolved nitrogen in the blood
239.narcosis: unconsciousness induced by narcotics or anesthesia
239.semicoma: a mild comatose state; a coma from which the person can be roused by appropriate stimuli
239.semitrance: a trancelike state in which the person can follow instructions but voluntary action is weak or absent
239.automatic pilot: a cognitive state in which you act without self-awareness
239.trance: a state of mind in which consciousness is fragile and voluntary action is poor or missing; a state resembling deep sleep
239.diabetic coma: coma that can develop in inadequately treated cases of diabetes mellitus
239.hypnotic trance: a trance induced by the use of hypnosis; the person accepts the suggestions of the hypnotist
239.unknowingness: unconsciousness resulting from lack of knowledge or attention

434.angina pectoris: a heart condition marked by paroxysms of chest pain due to reduced oxygen to the heart
434.heart failure: inability of the heart to pump enough blood to sustain normal bodily functions
434.premature ventricular contraction: irregularity of cardiac rhythm; recurrent occurrences can be a precursor of ventricular fibrillation
434.cardiovascular disease: a disease of the heart or blood vessels
434.heart block: recurrent sudden attacks of unconsciousness caused by impaired conduction of the impulse that regulates the heartbeat
434.congestive heart failure: inability to pump enough blood to avoid congestion in the tissues
434.mitral valve prolapse: cardiopathy resulting from the mitral valve not regulating the flow of blood between the left atrium and left ventricle of the heart
434.cerebral aneurysm: an aneurysm of the carotid artery
434.coronary thrombosis: obstruction of blood flow in a coronary artery by a blood clot (thrombus)
434.ventricular fibrillation: fibrillation of heart muscles resulting in interference with rhythmic contractions of the ventricles and possibly leading to cardiac arrest
434.aortic stenosis: abnormal narrowing of the aortic valve
434.flutter: abnormally rapid beating of the auricles of the heart (especially in a regular rhythm); can result in heart block
434.portal hypertension: increase in blood pressure in the veins of the portal system caused by obstruction in the liver (often associated with alcoholic cirrhosis), causing enlargement of the spleen and collateral veins
434.atrial fibrillation: fibrillation of the muscles of the atria of the heart
434.abdominal aortic aneurysm: an aneurysm of the abdominal aorta associated with old age and hypertension
434.heart attack: a sudden severe instance of abnormal heart function
434.coronary occlusion: occlusion of a coronary artery caused either by progressive atherosclerosis or by a blood clot
434.secondary hypertension: hypertension that is secondary to another disease
434.coronary heart disease: a heart disease due to an abnormality of the arteries that supply blood and oxygen to the heart
434.rheumatic heart disease: heart disease caused by recurrent episodes of rheumatic fever; characterized by changes in the myocardium or scarring of the heart valves that reduce the power of the heart to pump blood
434.mitral stenosis: obstruction or narrowing of the mitral valve (as by scarring from rheumatic fever)
434.valvular heart disease: heart disease caused by stenosis of the cardiac valves and obstructed blood flow or caused by degeneration and blood regurgitation
434.hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: a disorder in which the heart muscle is so strong that it does not relax enough to fill with the heart with blood and so has reduced pumping ability
434.aneurysm: a cardiovascular disease characterized by a saclike widening of an artery resulting from weakening of the artery wall
434.essential hypertension: persistent and pathological high blood pressure for which no specific cause can be found
434.cardiac arrhythmia: an abnormal rate of muscle contractions in the heart
434.intracranial aneurysm: an aneurysm of a cranial artery
434.tachycardia: abnormally rapid heartbeat (over 100 beats per minute)
434.ventricular aneurysm: a localized dilation or protrusion on the wall of the left ventricle of the heart (occurring after a myocardial infarction)
434.cardiomyopathy: a disorder (usually of unknown origin) of the heart muscle (myocardium)
434.malignant hypertension: severe hypertension that runs a rapid course and damages the inner linings of the blood vessels and the heart and spleen and kidneys and brain
434.orthostatic hypotension: low blood pressure occurring in some people when they stand up
434.high blood pressure: a common disorder in which blood pressure remains abnormally high (a reading of 140/90 mm Hg or greater)
434.white-coat hypertension: temporary rise in blood pressure in the doctor's office
434.circulatory failure: failure of the cardiovascular system to supply adequate amounts of blood to body tissues
434.gallop rhythm: cardiac rhythm characterized by the presence of an extra sound; can indicate a heart abnormality

580.spironolactone: a synthetic corticosteroid (trade name Aldactone) used to treat hypertension
580.estrogen: a general term for female steroid sex hormones that are secreted by the ovary and responsible for typical female sexual characteristics
580.steroid hormone: any hormone affecting the development and growth of sex organs
580.progestin: any of a group of steroid hormones that have the effect of progesterone
580.anabolic steroid: any of a group of synthetic steroid hormones used to stimulate muscle and bone growth; more than 100 have been developed and each requires a prescription to be used legally in the United States; sometimes used illicitly by athletes to increase their strength
580.norethynodrel: a progesterone derivative used in oral contraceptives and in the control of menstruation and the treatment of abnormal uterine bleeding
580.corticosterone: secreted by the adrenal cortex; involved in regulating water and electrolyte balance in the body
580.glucocorticoid: a steroid hormone that is produced by the adrenal cortex of animals; affects functioning of gonads and has anti-inflammatory activity
580.prednisone: a dehydrogenated analogue of cortisol (trade names Orasone or Deltasone or Liquid Pred or Meticorten); used as an anti-inflammatory drug in the treatment of arthritis and as an immunosuppressant
580.nandrolone: an androgen (trade names Durabolin or Kabolin) that is used to treat testosterone deficiency or breast cancer or osteoporosis
580.dexamethasone: a corticosteroid drug (trade names Decadron or Dexamethasone Intensol or Dexone or Hexadrol or Oradexon) used to treat allergies or inflammation
580.medroxyprogesterone: a progestin compound (trade name Provera) used to treat menstrual disorders
580.androgen: male sex hormone that is produced in the testes and responsible for typical male sexual characteristics
580.mineralocorticoid: hormone that is one of the steroids of the adrenal cortex that influences the metabolism of sodium and potassium
580.megestrol: a synthetic progestational compound used to treat endometrial carcinoma
580.estriol: a naturally occurring estrogenic hormone; a synthetic form is used to treat estrogen deficiency
580.hexestrol: estrogen compound used to treat menstrual irregularities and menopausal symptoms and to prevent pregnancy
580.androsterone: an androgenic hormone that is less active than testosterone
580.testosterone: a potent androgenic hormone produced chiefly by the testes; responsible for the development of male secondary sex characteristics
580.cortisone: a corticosteroid hormone (trade name Cortone Acetate) normally produced by the adrenal cortex; is converted to hydrocortisone
580.estradiol: the most powerful female hormone that occurs naturally; synthesized and used to treat estrogen deficiency and breast cancer
580.norethindrone: a synthetic progestational hormone (trade name Norlutin) used in oral contraceptives and to treat endometriosis
580.mestranol: a synthetic form of estrogen used in combination with a progestin in oral contraceptives
580.prednisolone: a glucocorticoid (trade names Pediapred or Prelone) used to treat inflammatory conditions
580.triamcinolone: a synthetic corticosteroid (trade names Aristocort or Aristopak or Kenalog) used as an anti-inflammatory agent
580.methyltestosterone: an androgenic compound contained in drugs that are used to treat testosterone deficiency and female breast cancer and to stimulate growth and weight gain
580.hydrocortisone: an adrenal-cortex hormone (trade names Hydrocortone or Cortef) that is active in carbohydrate and protein metabolism
580.aldosterone: a corticosteroid hormone that is secreted by the cortex of the adrenal gland; regulates salt (sodium and potassium) and water balance
580.diethylstilbestrol: a potent estrogen used in medicine and in feed for livestock and poultry
580.estrone: a naturally occurring weak estrogenic hormone secreted by the mammalian ovary; synthesized (trade name Estronol) and used to treat estrogen deficiency
580.norgestrel: synthetic progestin used in oral contraceptives
580.progesterone: a steroid hormone (trade name Lipo-Lutin) produced in the ovary; prepares and maintains the uterus for pregnancy
580.corticosteroid: a steroid hormone produced by the adrenal cortex or synthesized; administered as drugs they reduce swelling and decrease the body's immune response

526.cellulose acetate: an ester of acetic acid; used in fibers and fabrics; photographic films and varnishes
526.cellulose nitrate: a nitric acid ester; used in lacquers and explosives
526.uracil: a base containing nitrogen that is found in RNA (but not in DNA) and derived from pyrimidine; pairs with adenine
526.triglyceride: glyceride occurring naturally in animal and vegetable tissues; it consists of three individual fatty acids bound together in a single large molecule; an important energy source forming much of the fat stored by the body
526.deoxyguanosine monophosphate: one of the four nucleotides used in building DNA; all four nucleotides have a common phosphate group and a sugar (ribose)
526.cellulose ester: any ester of cellulose with an acid
526.cellulose triacetate: cellulose acetate that is relatively slow to burn; used instead of celluloid for motion-picture film
526.adenosine monophosphate: a nucleotide found in muscle cells and important in metabolism; reversibly convertible to ADP and ATP
526.polyester: a complex ester used for making fibers or resins or plastics or as a plasticizer
526.deoxythymidine monophosphate: one of the four nucleotides used in building DNA; all four nucleotides have a common phosphate group and a sugar (ribose)
526.muton: the smallest unit of DNA where a mutation can occur
526.adenosine diphosphate: an ester of adenosine that is converted to ATP for energy storage
526.triolein: a naturally occurring glyceride of oleic acid that is found in fats and oils
526.glycerite: a medicine made by mixing a substance in glycerin
526.pyrocellulose: nitrocellulose containing less nitrogen than guncotton; used in making smokeless powder
526.banana oil: a liquid ester derived from amyl alcohol; has the odor of bananas
526.glycerogelatin: a medicated skin preparation made from glycerin and glycerinated gelatin
526.citrate: a salt or ester of citric acid
526.cyclohexanol phthalate: the cyclohexanol ester of phthalic acid
526.nucleotide: a phosphoric ester of a nucleoside; the basic structural unit of nucleic acids (DNA or RNA)
526.margarin: a glyceryl ester of margaric acid
526.base pair: one of the pairs of chemical bases joined by hydrogen bonds that connect the complementary strands of a DNA molecule or of an RNA molecule that has two strands; the base pairs are adenine with thymine and guanine with cytosine in DNA and adenine with uracil and guanine with cytosine in RNA
526.palmitin: an ester of glycerol and palmitic acid
526.ester: formed by reaction between an acid and an alcohol with elimination of water
526.stearin: an ester of glycerol and stearic acid
526.glyceride: an ester of glycerol and fatty acids that occurs naturally as fats and fatty oils
526.deoxycytidine monophosphate: one of the four nucleotides used in building DNA; all four nucleotides have a common phosphate group and a sugar (ribose)
526.butyrin: any of three glycerides of butyric acid
526.tributyrin: a bitter oily triglyceride of butyric acid; a form of butyrin
526.glycerin jelly: a mixture of glycerin and gelatin that is used in histology for mounting specimens
526.ethyl acetate: a fragrant colorless flammable volatile liquid ester made from ethanol and acetic acid; used in flavorings and perfumes and as a solvent for plastics
526.cellulose xanthate: a cellulose ester obtained by treating cellulose with caustic soda
526.pyroxylin: highly flammable nitrocellulose used in making collodion and plastics and lacquers
526.lactate: a salt or ester of lactic acid
526.maleate: a salt or ester of maleic acid; used as a nontricyclic antidepressant drug for psychomotor activation
526.adenosine triphosphate: a nucleotide derived from adenosine that occurs in muscle tissue; the major source of energy for cellular reactions
526.deoxyadenosine monophosphate: one of the four nucleotides used in building DNA; all four nucleotides have a common phosphate group and a sugar (ribose)

650.social insurance: government provision for unemployed, injured, or aged people; financed by contributions from employers and employees as well as by government revenue
650.health care: social insurance for the ill and injured
650.national insurance: social insurance program in Britain; based on contributions from employers and employees; provides payments to unemployed and sick and retired people as well as medical services
650.Social Security: social welfare program in the U.S.; includes old-age and survivors insurance and some unemployment insurance and old-age assistance
650.primary health care: health care that is provided by a health care professional in the first contact of a patient with the health care system
650.Medicaid: health care for the needy; a federally and state-funded program
650.unemployment compensation: payment by a United States agency to unemployed people
650.social welfare: governmental provision of economic assistance to persons in need
650.supplementary benefit: benefits paid to bring incomes up to minimum levels established by law
650.Medicare: health care for the aged; a federally administered system of health insurance available to persons aged 65 and over
650.relief: aid for the aged or indigent or handicapped

133.bundling: the act of binding something into a bundle
133.enclosure: the act of enclosing something inside something else
133.injection: the forceful insertion of a substance under pressure
133.infusion: (medicine) the passive introduction of a substance (a fluid or drug or electrolyte) into a vein or between tissues (as by gravitational force)
133.insertion: the act of putting one thing into another
133.exchange transfusion: slow removal of a person's blood and its replacement with equal amounts of a donor's blood
133.instillation: the introduction of a liquid (by pouring or injection) drop by drop
133.encasement: the act of enclosing something in a case
133.epidural injection: injection of an anesthetic substance into the epidural space of the spinal cord in order to produce epidural anesthesia
133.perfusion: pumping a liquid into an organ or tissue (especially by way of blood vessels)
133.transfusion: the introduction of blood or blood plasma into a vein or artery
133.packing: the enclosure of something in a package or box
133.cannulation: the insertion of a cannula or tube into a hollow body organ

720.posttraumatic epilepsy: a convulsive epileptic state caused by a head injury
720.status epilepticus: a condition in which there are continuing attacks of epilepsy without intervals of consciousness; can lead to brain damage and death
720.global aphasia: loss of all ability to communicate
720.tonic epilepsy: epilepsy in which the body is rigid during the seizure
720.petit mal epilepsy: epilepsy characterized by paroxysmal attacks of brief clouding of consciousness (and possibly other abnormalities)
720.Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease: rare (usually fatal) brain disease (usually in middle age) caused by an unidentified slow virus; characterized by progressive dementia and gradual loss of muscle control
720.sensory epilepsy: focal epilepsy initiated by somatosensory phenomena
720.transcortical aphasia: a general term for aphasia that results from lesions outside of Broca's area or Wernicke's area of the cerebral cortex
720.visual agnosia: inability to recognize or interpret objects in the visual field
720.grand mal epilepsy: epilepsy in which the attacks involve loss of consciousness and tonic spasms of the musculature followed by generalized jerking
720.agraphia: a loss of the ability to write or to express thoughts in writing because of a brain lesion
720.conduction aphasia: aphasia in which the lesion is assumed to be in the association tracts connecting the various language centers in the brain; patient's have difficulty repeating a sentence just heard
720.motor aphasia: aphasia in which expression by speech or writing is severely impaired
720.procursive epilepsy: epilepsy in which a seizure is induced by whirling or running
720.astereognosis: a loss of the ability to recognize objects by handling them
720.Wernicke's aphasia: aphasia characterized by fluent but meaningless speech and severe impairment of the ability understand spoken or written words
720.acataphasia: a disorder in which a lesion to the central nervous system leaves you unable to formulate a statement or to express yourself in an organized manner
720.Jacksonian epilepsy: focal epilepsy in which the attack usually moves from distal to proximal limb muscles on the same side of the body
720.auditory agnosia: inability to recognize or understand the meaning of spoken words
720.myoclonus epilepsy: epilepsy characterized by clonus of muscle groups and progressive mental deterioration and genetic origin
720.paralysis agitans: a degenerative disorder of the central nervous system characterized by tremor and impaired muscular coordination
720.brain disorder: any disorder or disease of the brain
720.psychomotor epilepsy: epilepsy characterized clinically by impairment of consciousness and amnesia for the episode; often involves purposeful movements of the arms and legs and sometimes hallucinations
720.Reye's syndrome: acquired encephalopathy following acute viral infections (especially influenza or chicken pox) in young children; characterized by fever, vomiting, disorientation, coma, and fatty infiltration of the liver
720.agnosia: inability to recognize objects by use of the senses
720.auditory aphasia: an impairment in understanding spoken language that is not attributable to hearing loss
720.aphasia: inability to use or understand language (spoken or written) because of a brain lesion
720.Wernicke's encephalopathy: inflammatory degenerative disease of the brain caused by thiamine deficiency that is usually associated with alcoholism
720.cerebral palsy: a loss or deficiency of motor control with involuntary spasms caused by permanent brain damage present at birth
720.epilepsy: a disorder of the central nervous system characterized by loss of consciousness and convulsions
720.cortical epilepsy: epilepsy in which the attacks begins with an isolated disturbance of cerebral function (as a twitching of a limb or an illusory sensation or a mental disturbance)
720.photogenic epilepsy: reflex epilepsy induced by a flickering light
720.nominal aphasia: inability to name objects or to recognize written or spoken names of objects
720.reflex epilepsy: a form of epilepsy in which attacks are induced by peripheral stimulation

554.pharyngeal reflex: normal reflex consisting of retching; may be produced by touching the soft palate in the back of the mouth
554.micturition reflex: relaxation of the urethral sphincter in response to increased pressure in the bladder
554.startle response: a complicated involuntary reaction to a sudden unexpected stimulus (especially a loud noise); involves flexion of most skeletal muscles and a variety of visceral reactions
554.mydriasis: reflex pupillary dilation as a muscle pulls the iris outward; occurs in response to a decrease in light or certain drugs
554.startle reflex: a normal reflex of young infants; a sudden loud noise causes the child to stretch out the arms and flex the legs
554.vomit: the reflex act of ejecting the contents of the stomach through the mouth
554.sneeze: a symptom consisting of the involuntary expulsion of air from the nose
554.suckling reflex: reflex behavior in newborn mammals; includes finding and grasping the nipple in the mouth and sucking on it and swallowing the milk
554.rumination: regurgitation of small amounts of food; seen in some infants after feeding
554.plantar reflex: flexion of the toes when the sole of the foot is stroked firmly on the outer side from the heel to the front in persons over the age of 2 years; under 2 years the results should be extension of the toes (Babinski reflex)
554.fart: a reflex that expels intestinal gas through the anus
554.hiccup: (usually plural) the state of having reflex spasms of the diaphragm accompanied by a rapid closure of the glottis producing an audible sound; sometimes a symptom of indigestion
554.defecation reflex: normal response to the presence of feces in the rectum
554.palpebration: repeated blinking or winking (especially if uncontrolled and persistent)
554.reflex: an automatic instinctive unlearned reaction to a stimulus
554.electric shock: a reflex response to the passage of electric current through the body
554.accommodation reflex: reflex changes in the eyes that enable an object to be focused on the retina
554.light reflex: reflex contraction of the sphincter muscle of the iris in response to a bright light (or certain drugs) causing the pupil to become smaller
554.hyperemesis gravidarum: hyperemesis during pregnancy; if severe it can result in damage to the brain and liver and kidney
554.Babinski: extension upward of the toes when the sole of the foot is stroked firmly on the outer side from the heel to the front; normal in infants under the age of two years but a sign of brain or spinal cord injury in older persons
554.rooting reflex: reflex consisting of head-turning and sucking movements elicited in a normal infant by gently stroking the side of the mouth or cheek
554.belch: a reflex that expels gas noisily from the stomach through the mouth
554.blush: sudden reddening of the face (as from embarrassment or guilt or shame or modesty)
554.gulp: a spasmodic reflex of the throat made as if in swallowing
554.blink: a reflex that closes and opens the eyes rapidly
554.pilomotor reflex: reflex erection of hairs of the skin in response to cold or emotional stress or skin irritation
554.tremble: a reflex motion caused by cold or fear or excitement
554.yawn: an involuntary intake of breath through a wide open mouth; usually triggered by fatigue or boredom
554.pandiculation: yawning and stretching (as when first waking up)
554.knee jerk: a reflex extension of the leg resulting from a sharp tap on the patellar tendon
554.wince: a reflex response to sudden pain
554.stretch reflex: reflex contraction of a muscle when an attached tendon is pulled; important in maintaining erect posture

458.conserve: fruit preserved by cooking with sugar
458.jelly: a preserve made of the jelled juice of fruit
458.chowchow: a Chinese preserve of mixed fruits and ginger
458.lemon curd: a conserve with a thick consistency; made with lemons and butter and eggs and sugar
458.marmalade: a preserve made of the pulp and rind of citrus fruits
458.crabapple jelly: a tart apple jelly made from crab apples
458.apple butter: thick dark spicy puree of apples

237.feature: a special or prominent article in a newspaper or magazine
237.sidebar: a short news story presenting sidelights on a major story
237.magazine article: an article published in a magazine
237.offprint: a separately printed article that originally appeared in a larger publication
237.nonfiction: prose writing that is not fictional
237.paper: a scholarly article describing the results of observations or stating hypotheses
237.personal: a short newspaper article about a particular person or group
237.think piece: an article in a newspaper or magazine or journal that represents opinions and ideas and discussion rather than bare facts
237.agony column: a newspaper column devoted to personal problems
237.article: nonfictional prose forming an independent part of a publication
237.lead: a news story of major importance
237.column: an article giving opinions or perspectives

546.reforestation: the restoration (replanting) of a forest that had been reduced by fire or cutting
546.car care: keeping a car in good working order
546.reclamation: the conversion of wasteland into land suitable for use of habitation or cultivation
546.reconstruction: the activity of constructing something again
546.care: activity involved in maintaining something in good working order
546.physical rehabilitation: providing help for disabled persons; the removal or reduction of disabilities
546.repair: the act of putting something in working order again
546.patching: the act of mending a hole in a garment by sewing a patch over it
546.scheduled maintenance: maintenance at a regularly scheduled time
546.overhaul: periodic maintenance on a car or machine
546.vocational rehabilitation: providing training in a specific trade with the aim of gaining employment
546.refreshment: activity that refreshes and recreates; activity that renews your health and spirits by enjoyment and relaxation
546.re-formation: forming again (especially with improvements or removal of defects); renewing and reconstituting
546.pump priming: introducing water into a pump to improve the seal and start the water flowing
546.makeover: a complete reconstruction and renovation of something
546.rehabilitation: the restoration of someone to a useful place in society
546.restitution: the act of restoring something to its original state
546.rejuvenation: the act of restoring to a more youthful condition
546.darning: the act of mending a hole in a garment with crossing threads
546.anastylosis: the archeological reassembly of ruined monuments from fallen or decayed fragments (incorporating new materials when necessary)
546.gentrification: the restoration of run-down urban areas by the middle class (resulting in the displacement of low-income residents)
546.reinstatement: the act of restoring someone to a previous position
546.urban renewal: the clearing and rebuilding and redevelopment of urban slums
546.interim overhaul: an overhaul between the regular times for overhauling
546.steam fitting: care (installation and maintenance) of equipment for ventilating or heating or refrigerating
546.correctional rehabilitation: providing penal custody or probation or parole for convicted offenders
546.restoration: the act of restoring something or someone to a satisfactory state
546.camera care: keeping a camera in good working order

544.calcium hydride: a saltlike binary compound (CaH2) used as a reducing agent and source of hydrogen
544.water: binary compound that occurs at room temperature as a clear colorless odorless tasteless liquid; freezes into ice below 0 degrees centigrade and boils above 100 degrees centigrade; widely used as a solvent
544.soft water: water that is not hard (does not contain mineral salts that interfere with the formation of lather with soap)
544.binary compound: chemical compound composed of only two elements
544.red tide: seawater that is discolored by large numbers of certain dinoflagellates that produce saxitoxin
544.water of crystallization: the water present in hydrated compounds
544.ammonia: a pungent gas compounded of nitrogen and hydrogen (NH3)
544.hydride: any binary compound formed by the union of hydrogen and other elements
544.bilge: water accumulated in the bilge of a ship
544.hard water: water that contains mineral salts (as calcium and magnesium ions) that limit the formation of lather with soap
544.sodium chloride: a white crystalline solid consisting mainly of sodium chloride (NaCl)
544.calcium carbide: a grey salt of calcium (CaC) used in making acetylene
544.distilled water: water that has been purified by distillation
544.ammonium: the ion NH4 derived from ammonia; behaves in many respects like an alkali metal ion
544.limewater: solution of calcium hydroxide in water used as an antacid
544.ground water: underground water that is held in the soil and in pervious rocks
544.dishwater: water in which dishes and cooking utensils are washed
544.holy water: water that has been blessed by a priest for use in symbolic purification
544.sodium hydride: a flammable grey crystalline binary compound (NaH)
544.hydrazoic acid: a colorless explosive liquid that is volatile and poisonous and foul-smelling
544.rain: drops of fresh water that fall as precipitation from clouds

675.Bureau of Alcohol Tobacco and Firearms: the law enforcement and tax collection agency of the Treasury Department that enforces federal laws concerning alcohol and tobacco products and firearms and explosives and arson
675.Schutzstaffel: special police force in Nazi Germany founded as a personal bodyguard for Adolf Hitler in 1925; the SS administered the concentration camps
675.Mutawa'een: religious police in Saudi Arabia whose duty is to ensure strict adherence to established codes of conduct; offenders may be detained indefinitely; foreigners are not excluded
675.Gestapo: the secret state police in Nazi Germany; known for its terrorist methods
675.National Institute of Justice: the law enforcement agency that is the research and development branch of the Department of Justice
675.Federal Bureau of Investigation: a federal law enforcement agency that is the principal investigative arm of the Department of Justice
675.Scotland Yard: the detective department of the metropolitan police force of London
675.Europol: police organization for the European Union; aims to improve effectiveness and cooperation among European police forces
675.police: the force of policemen and officers
675.law enforcement agency: an agency responsible for insuring obedience to the laws
675.Federal Judiciary: the judiciary of the United States which is responsible for interpreting and enforcing federal laws
675.Federal Law Enforcement Training Center: a center in the Department of that trains law enforcement professionals for more than seventy federal agencies
675.Financial Crimes Enforcement Network: a law enforcement agency of the Treasury Department responsible for establishing and implementing policies to detect money laundering
675.Criminal Investigation Command: the United States Army's principal law enforcement agency responsible for the conduct of criminal investigations for all levels of the Army anywhere in the world
675.Drug Enforcement Administration: federal agency responsible for enforcing laws and regulations governing narcotics and controlled substances; goal is to immobilize drug trafficking organizations
675.Royal Canadian Mounted Police: the federal police force of Canada
675.gendarmerie: French police force; a group of gendarmes or gendarmes collectively
675.United States Marshals Service: the United States' oldest federal law enforcement agency is responsible today for protecting the Federal Judiciary and transporting federal prisoners and protecting federal witnesses and managing assets seized from criminals and generally ensuring the effective operation of the federal judicial system
675.Federal Bureau of Prisons: the law enforcement agency of the Justice Department that operates a nationwide system of prisons and detention facilities to incarcerate inmates sentenced to imprisonment for federal crimes
675.secret police: a police force that operates in secrecy (usually against persons suspected of treason or sedition)

326.demonstration: a visual presentation showing how something works
326.big stick: a display of force or power
326.gaudery: cheap or pretentious or vain display
326.lamentation: the passionate and demonstrative activity of expressing grief
326.display: something intended to communicate a particular impression
326.acting out: a (usually irritating) impulsive and uncontrollable outburst by a problem child or a neurotic adult

43.fatigues: military uniform worn by military personnel when doing menial labor
43.olive drab: military uniform of the United States Army; made from cloth of a dull olive color
43.battle dress: a military uniform designed for field service
43.khakis: a military uniform made of khaki fabric
43.regimentals: the military uniform and insignia of a regiment
43.full-dress uniform: the naval or military uniform that is specified by regulations to be worn on ceremonial occasions
43.dress blues: a dress uniform for formal occasions
43.livery: uniform worn by some menservants and chauffeurs
43.uniform: clothing of distinctive design worn by members of a particular group as a means of identification
43.dress uniform: a military uniform worn on formal occasions

17.course: education imparted in a series of lessons or meetings
17.life class: an art class using a live human model
17.higher education: education provided by a college or university
17.elementary education: education in elementary subjects (reading and writing and arithmetic) provided to young students at a grade school
17.orientation course: a course introducing a new situation or environment
17.directed study: a course of study that is supervised and controlled by a specialist in the subject
17.extension course: a course offered as part of an extension service
17.extracurricular activity: educational activities not falling within the scope of the regular curriculum
17.work-study program: an educational plan in which students alternate between paid employment and formal study
17.continuing education: a program of instruction designed primarily for adult students who participate part-time
17.coeducation: education of men and women in the same institutions
17.dramatics: participation in theatrical productions as an extracurricular activity
17.course of lectures: a series of lectures dealing with a subject
17.team teaching: a method of coordinated classroom teaching involving a team of teachers working together with a single group of students
17.refresher course: a course that reviews and updates a topic for those who have not kept abreast of developments
17.home study: a course of study carried out at home rather than in a classroom
17.education: the activities of educating or instructing; activities that impart knowledge or skill
17.extension: an educational opportunity provided by colleges and universities to people who are not enrolled as regular students
17.industrial arts: a course in the methods of using tools and machinery as taught in secondary schools and technical schools
17.athletics: participation in sports events as an extracurricular activity
17.workshop: a brief intensive course for a small group; emphasizes problem solving
17.propaedeutic: a course that provides an introduction to an art or science (or to more advanced study generally)
17.required course: a course that all students are required to take
17.secondary education: education beyond the elementary grades; provided by a high school or college preparatory school
17.correspondence course: a course offered (by mail) by a correspondence school
17.art class: a class in which you learn to draw or paint
17.elective course: a course that the student can select from among alternatives
17.childbirth-preparation class: a course that teaches pregnant women to use breathing and concentration and exercise techniques to use during labor
17.adult education: a course (via lectures or correspondence) for adults who are not otherwise engaged in formal study
17.seminar: a course offered for a small group of advanced students
17.shop class: a course of instruction in a trade (as carpentry or electricity)

397.growler: a small iceberg or ice floe just large enough to be hazardous for shipping
397.glacier: a slowly moving mass of ice
397.icecap: a mass of ice and snow that permanently covers a large area of land (e.g., the polar regions or a mountain peak)
397.Piedmont glacier: a type of glaciation characteristic of Alaska; large valley glaciers meet to form an almost stagnant sheet of ice
397.ice field: a large flat mass of ice (larger than an ice floe) floating at sea
397.iceberg: a large mass of ice floating at sea; usually broken off of a polar glacier
397.continental glacier: a glacier that spreads out from a central mass of ice
397.Alpine glacier: a glacier that moves down from a high valley
397.polar glacier: a glacier near the Arctic or Antarctic poles
397.Mendenhall Glacier: a glacier of the Piedmont type near Juneau in Alaska
397.ice floe: a flat mass of ice (smaller than an ice field) floating at sea

103.occultism: a belief in supernatural powers and the possibility of bringing them under human control
103.conjuring: calling up a spirit or devil
103.juju: the power associated with a juju
103.obiism: belief in a kind of sorcery that originated in Africa and is practiced in the West Indies
103.mojo: a magic power or magic spell
103.theurgy: white magic performed with the help of beneficent spirits (as formerly practiced by Neoplatonists)
103.supernaturalism: a belief in forces beyond ordinary human understanding
103.evocation: calling up supposed supernatural forces by spells and incantations
103.magic: any art that invokes supernatural powers
103.sorcery: the belief in magical spells that harness occult forces or evil spirits to produce unnatural effects in the world
103.diabolism: a belief in and reverence for devils (especially Satan)
103.white magic: magic used only for good purposes

537.disjunctive conjunction: the conjunctive relation of units that expresses the disjunction of their meanings
537.restrictiveness: a grammatical qualification that makes the meaning more specific (`red hat' has a more specific meaning than `hat')
537.inflection: a change in the form of a word (usually by adding a suffix) to indicate a change in its grammatical function
537.grammatical relation: a linguistic relation established by grammar
537.imperative mood: a mood that expresses an intention to influence the listener's behavior
537.coordinating conjunction: the coordination by conjunction of linguistic units of the same status
537.person agreement: agreement in person between pronouns and verbs
537.apposition: a grammatical relation between a word and a noun phrase that follows
537.number agreement: agreement in number between words in the same grammatical construction (e.g., between adjectives and the nouns they modify)
537.agreement: the determination of grammatical inflection on the basis of word relations
537.inchoative: aspect with regard to the beginning of the action of the verb
537.active voice: the voice used to indicate that the grammatical subject of the verb is performing the action or causing the happening denoted by the verb
537.interrogative mood: some linguists consider interrogative sentences to constitute a mood
537.progressive aspect: the aspect of a verb that expresses its on-going action
537.iterative: the aspect of the verb that expresses the repetition of an action
537.perfective: the aspect of a verb that expresses a completed action
537.imperfective: aspect without regard to the beginning or completion of the action of the verb
537.copulative conjunction: the conjunctive relation of units that expresses the addition of their meanings
537.adversative conjunction: the conjunctive relation of units that expresses the opposition of their meanings
537.mood: verb inflections that express how the action or state is conceived by the speaker
537.gender agreement: agreement in grammatical gender between words in the same construction
537.case agreement: agreement in grammatical case between words in the same construction
537.aspect: the beginning or duration or completion or repetition of the action of a verb
537.coordination: the grammatical relation of two constituents having the same grammatical form
537.pluralization: the act of pluralizing or attributing plurality to
537.declension: the inflection of nouns and pronouns and adjectives in Indo-European languages
537.complementation: the grammatical relation of a word or phrase to a predicate
537.optative mood: a mood (as in Greek or Sanskrit) that expresses a wish or hope; expressed in English by modal verbs
537.modification: the grammatical relation that exists when a word qualifies the meaning of the phrase
537.conjunction: the grammatical relation between linguistic units (words or phrases or clauses) that are connected by a conjunction
537.anaphoric relation: the relation between an anaphor and its antecedent
537.indicative mood: a mood (grammatically unmarked) that represents the act or state as an objective fact
537.coreference: the grammatical relation between two words that have a common referent
537.intransitivity: the grammatical relation created by an intransitive verb
537.reflexivity: the coreferential relation between a reflexive pronoun and its antecedent
537.voice: (linguistics) the grammatical relation (active or passive) of the grammatical subject of a verb to the action that the verb denotes
537.durative: the aspect of a verb that expresses its duration
537.subordinating conjunction: the subordination that occurs when a conjunction makes one linguistic unit a constituent of another
537.transitivity: the grammatical relation created by a transitive verb
537.subjunctive mood: a mood that represents an act or state (not as a fact but) as contingent or possible
537.paradigm: systematic arrangement of all the inflected forms of a word
537.subordination: the grammatical relation of a modifying word or phrase to its head
537.passive voice: the voice used to indicate that the grammatical subject of the verb is the recipient (not the source) of the action denoted by the verb

716.unknown quantity: a factor in a given situation whose bearing and importance is not apparent
716.intrinsic factor: a substance produced by the mucosa of the stomach and intestines that is essential for the absorption of vitamin B12
716.releasing factor: a substance produced by the hypothalamus that is capable of accelerating the secretion of a given hormone by the anterior pituitary gland
716.antecedent: a preceding occurrence or cause or event
716.cause: events that provide the generative force that is the origin of something
716.fundamental: any factor that could be considered important to the understanding of a particular business
716.mutagenesis: an event capable of causing a mutation
716.growth hormone-releasing factor: a releasing factor that accelerates the secretion of growth hormone by the anterior pituitary body
716.factor: anything that contributes causally to a result
716.insertional mutagenesis: (genetics) a mutation caused by the insertion of exogenous DNA into a genome
716.parameter: any factor that defines a system and determines (or limits) its performance

499.intent: the intended meaning of a communication
499.denotatum: an actual object referred to by a linguistic expression
499.antecedent: the referent of an anaphor; a phrase or clause that is referred to by an anaphoric pronoun
499.overtone: (usually plural) an ulterior implicit meaning or quality
499.referent: something referred to; the object of a reference
499.designatum: something (whether existing or not) that is referred to by a linguistic expression
499.point: a brief version of the essential meaning of something
499.intension: what you must know in order to determine the reference of an expression
499.nuance: a subtle difference in meaning or opinion or attitude
499.sense: the meaning of a word or expression; the way in which a word or expression or situation can be interpreted
499.grammatical meaning: the meaning of a word that depends on its role in a sentence; varies with inflectional form
499.symbolization: the use of symbols to convey meaning
499.alpha and omega: the basic meaning of something; the crucial part
499.moral: the significance of a story or event
499.lexical meaning: the meaning of a content word that depends on the nonlinguistic concepts it is used to express
499.rallying point: a point or principle on which scattered or opposing groups can come together
499.meaning: the message that is intended or expressed or signified
499.talking point: an especially persuasive point helping to support an argument or discussion
499.word meaning: the accepted meaning of a word
499.effect: the central meaning or theme of a speech or literary work

272.zymology: the branch of chemistry concerned with fermentation (as in making wine or brewing or distilling)
272.phytochemistry: the branch of organic chemistry dealing with the chemistry of plants
272.physical chemistry: the branch of chemistry dealing with the physical properties of chemical substances
272.enzymology: the branch of biochemistry dealing with the chemical nature and biological activity of enzymes
272.electrochemistry: branch of chemistry that deals with the chemical action of electricity and the production of electricity by chemical reactions
272.geochemistry: the chemistry of the earth's crust
272.biochemistry: the organic chemistry of compounds and processes occurring in organisms; the effort to understand biology within the context of chemistry
272.immunochemistry: the field of chemistry concerned with chemical processes in immunology (such as chemical studies of antigens and antibodies)
272.femtochemistry: the branch of chemistry that studies elementary (often very fast) chemical reactions as they occur; the experimental methods are often based on the use of femtosecond laser pulses
272.surface chemistry: the branch of chemistry that studies processes occurring at interfaces between phases (especially those between liquid and gas)
272.inorganic chemistry: the chemistry of compounds that do not contain hydrocarbon radicals
272.organic chemistry: the chemistry of compounds containing carbon (originally defined as the chemistry of substances produced by living organisms but now extended to substances synthesized artificially)
272.photochemistry: branch of chemistry that deals with the chemical action of light
272.chemistry: the science of matter; the branch of the natural sciences dealing with the composition of substances and their properties and reactions
272.thermochemistry: the branch of chemistry that studies the relation between chemical action and the amount of heat absorbed or generated

76.state of matter: (chemistry) the three traditional states of matter are solids (fixed shape and volume) and liquids (fixed volume and shaped by the container) and gases (filling the container)
76.solid: the state in which a substance has no tendency to flow under moderate stress; resists forces (such as compression) that tend to deform it; and retains a definite size and shape
76.exchange: chemical process in which one atom or ion or group changes places with another
76.photochemical exchange: an exchange produced by the chemical action of radiant energy (especially light)
76.interplanetary gas: a rarefied flow of gas and charged particles (plasma) that stream from the sun and form the solar wind
76.polymorphism: (chemistry) the existence of different kinds of crystal of the same chemical compound
76.dimorphism: (chemistry) the property of certain substances that enables them to exist in two distinct crystalline forms
76.phase: (physical chemistry) a distinct state of matter in a system; matter that is identical in chemical composition and physical state and separated from other material by the phase boundary
76.chemical phenomenon: any natural phenomenon involving chemistry (as changes to atoms or molecules)
76.gas: the state of matter distinguished from the solid and liquid states by: relatively low density and viscosity; relatively great expansion and contraction with changes in pressure and temperature; the ability to diffuse readily; and the spontaneous tendency to become distributed uniformly throughout any container
76.plasma: (physical chemistry) a fourth state of matter distinct from solid or liquid or gas and present in stars and fusion reactors; a gas becomes a plasma when it is heated until the atoms lose all their electrons, leaving a highly electrified collection of nuclei and free electrons
76.efflorescence: a powdery deposit on a surface
76.allotropy: the phenomenon of an element existing in two or more physical forms
76.liquid: the state in which a substance exhibits a characteristic readiness to flow with little or no tendency to disperse and relatively high incompressibility
76.dispersing phase: (of colloids) a substance in which another is colloidally dispersed
76.valency: the phenomenon of forming chemical bonds
76.dispersed phase: (of colloids) a substance in the colloidal state

743.fluoroscopy: examination of body structures using a fluoroscope
743.B-scan ultrasonography: the use of ultrasonography to view structure in the back of the eye
743.imaging: (medicine) obtaining pictures of the interior of the body
743.blood-oxygenation level dependent functi: functional magnetic resonance imaging that relies on intrinsic changes in hemoglobin oxygenation
743.X-raying: obtaining images by the use of X rays
743.functional magnetic resonance imaging: a form of magnetic resonance imaging of the brain that registers blood flow to functioning areas of the brain
743.A-scan ultrasonography: the use of ultrasonography to measure the length of the eyeball
743.sonography: using the reflections of high-frequency sound waves to construct an image of a body organ (a sonogram); commonly used to observe fetal growth or study bodily organs
743.magnetic resonance imaging: the use of nuclear magnetic resonance of protons to produce proton density images
743.computerized tomography: a method of examining body organs by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis
743.positron emission tomography: using a computerized radiographic technique to examine the metabolic activity in various tissues (especially in the brain)
743.radioscopy: (radiology) examination of the inner structure of opaque objects using X rays or other penetrating radiation

131.Eurasia: the land mass formed by the continents of Europe and Asia
131.South America: a continent in the western hemisphere connected to North America by the Isthmus of Panama
131.Europe: the 2nd smallest continent (actually a vast peninsula of Eurasia); the British use `Europe' to refer to all of the continent except the British Isles
131.Australia: the smallest continent; between the South Pacific and the Indian Ocean
131.landmass: a large continuous extent of land
131.continent: one of the large landmasses of the earth
131.Africa: the second largest continent; located to the south of Europe and bordered to the west by the South Atlantic and to the east by the Indian Ocean
131.Pangaea: (plate tectonics) a hypothetical continent including all the landmass of the earth prior to the Triassic period when it split into Laurasia and Gondwanaland
131.Gondwanaland: a hypothetical continent that (according to plate tectonic theory) broke up later into India and Australia and Africa and South America and Antarctica
131.Antarctica: an extremely cold continent at the south pole almost entirely below the Antarctic Circle; covered by an ice cap up to 13,000 feet deep
131.subcontinent: a large and distinctive landmass (as India or Greenland) that is a distinct part of some continent
131.Asia: the largest continent with 60% of the earth's population; it is joined to Europe on the west to form Eurasia; it is the site of some of the world's earliest civilizations
131.North America: a continent (the third largest) in the western hemisphere connected to South America by the Isthmus of Panama
131.Laurasia: a hypothetical continent that (according to plate tectonic theory) broke up later into North America and Europe and Asia
131.Gulf of Carpentaria: a wide shallow inlet of the Arafura Sea in northern Australia

461.repletion: the state of being satisfactorily full and unable to take on more
461.Guinea worm disease: a painful and debilitating infestation contracted by drinking stagnant water contaminated with Guinea worm larvae that can mature inside a human's abdomen until the worm emerges through a painful blister in the person's skin
461.pediculosis: infestation with lice (Pediculus humanus) resulting in severe itching
461.trichuriasis: infestation by a roundworm; common in tropical areas with poor sanitation
461.enterobiasis: an infestation with or a resulting infection caused by the pinworm Enterobius vermicularis; occurs especially in children
461.trichinosis: infestation by trichina larvae that are transmitted by eating inadequately cooked meat (especially pork); larvae migrate from the intestinal tract to the muscles where they become encysted
461.onchocerciasis: infestation with slender threadlike roundworms (filaria) deposited under the skin by the bite of black fleas; when the eyes are involved it can result in blindness; common in Africa and tropical America
461.solidity: state of having the interior filled with matter
461.hookworm: infestation of the intestines by hookworms which enter the body (usually) through the skin
461.fasciolopsiasis: infestation with the large intestinal fluke Fasciolopsis buski; common in eastern Asia
461.pediculosis capitis: infestation of the scalp with lice
461.fascioliasis: infestation with the liver fluke Fasciola hepatica; liver damage sometimes occurs; related to liver rot
461.myiasis: infestation of the body by the larvae of flies (usually through a wound or other opening) or any disease resulting from such infestation
461.ascariasis: infestation of the human intestine with Ascaris roundworms
461.schistosomiasis: an infestation with or a resulting infection caused by a parasite of the genus Schistosoma; common in the tropics and Far East; symptoms depend on the part of the body infected
461.surfeit: the state of being more than full
461.opisthorchiasis: infestation with flukes obtained from eating raw fish; common in eastern Asia
461.helminthiasis: infestation of the body with parasitic worms
461.pediculosis corporis: infestation of body skin with lice
461.fullness: the condition of being filled to capacity
461.pediculosis pubis: infestation of the pubic hair by crab lice
461.infestation: the state of being invaded or overrun by parasites

410.haircut: the act of cutting the hair
410.shearing: removing by cutting off or clipping
410.trim: cutting down to the desired size or shape
410.Braxton-Hicks contraction: painless contractions of the muscles of the uterus that continue throughout pregnancy with increasing frequency
410.cut: the act of shortening something by chopping off the ends
410.nip: a small sharp bite or snip
410.vaginismus: muscular contraction that causes the vagina to close; usually an anxiety reaction before coitus or pelvic examination
410.abbreviation: shortening something by omitting parts of it
410.contraction: (physiology) a shortening or tensing of a part or organ (especially of a muscle or muscle fiber)
410.tetanus: a sustained muscular contraction resulting from a rapid series of nerve impulses
410.contracture: an abnormal and usually permanent contraction of a muscle
410.clip: the act of clipping or snipping
410.pruning: the act of trimming a plant
410.uterine contraction: a rhythmic tightening in labor of the upper uterine musculature that contracts the size of the uterus and pushes the fetus toward the birth canal

343.drug bust: seizure of illegal drugs by the police
343.crossover: the appropriation of a new style (especially in popular music) by combining elements of different genres in order to appeal to a wider audience
343.naturalization: changing the pronunciation of a borrowed word to agree with the borrowers' phonology

343.impoundment: placing private property in the custody of an officer of the law
343.recapture: a legal seizure by the government of profits beyond a fixed amount

343.borrowing: the appropriation (of ideas or words etc) from another source

109.Irish soda bread: round loaf made with soda and buttermilk; often containing caraway seeds and raisins
109.shortcake: very short biscuit dough baked as individual biscuits or a round loaf; served with sweetened fruit and usually whipped cream
109.Yorkshire pudding: light puffy bread made of a puff batter and traditionally baked in the pan with roast beef

109.rolled biscuit: biscuit made from dough rolled and cut

109.popover: light hollow muffin made of a puff batter (individual Yorkshire pudding) baked in a deep muffin cup
109.drop biscuit: biscuit made from dough with enough milk that it can be dropped from a spoon

109.johnnycake: cornbread usually cooked pancake-style on a griddle (chiefly New England)
109.biscuit: small round bread leavened with baking-powder or soda

109.muffin: a sweet quick bread baked in a cup-shaped pan
109.quick bread: breads made with a leavening agent that permits immediate baking
109.date-nut bread: bread containing chopped dates and nuts
109.oatcake: thin flat unleavened cake of baked oatmeal
109.skillet corn bread: cornbread usually containing ham or bacon bits and cooked in a skillet
109.corn cake: baked in a pan or on a griddle (southern and midland)
109.spoon bread: soft bread made of cornmeal and sometimes rice or hominy; must be served with a spoon (chiefly southern)
109.skillet bread: usually cooked in a skillet over an open fire: especially cornbread with ham bits and sometimes Irish soda bread

163.lobster tart: a pastry shell filled with cooked lobster

508.treasury stock: stock that has been bought back by the issuing corporation and is available for retirement or resale; it is issued but not outstanding; it cannot vote and pays no dividends

508.growth stock: stock of a corporation that has had faster than average gains in earnings and is expected to continue to

372.carbohydrate loading: a diet of foods high in starch that increases carbohydrate reserves in muscles

234.litmus: a coloring material (obtained from lichens) that turns red in acid solutions and blue in alkaline solutions; used as a very rough acid-base indicator

451.toy: a nonfunctional replica of something else (frequently used as a modifier)

622.resuscitation: the act of reviving a person and returning them to consciousness
622.regeneration: the activity of spiritual or physical renewal

622.readjustment: the act of adjusting again (to changed circumstances)
622.habituation: a general accommodation to unchanging environmental conditions
622.resurrection: a revival from inactivity and disuse
622.adjustment: making or becoming suitable; adjusting to circumstances
622.conservation: an occurrence of improvement by virtue of preventing loss or injury or other change
622.improvement: a change for the better; progress in development
622.rebirth: the revival of learning and culture
622.revival: bringing again into activity and prominence

750.beastliness: unpleasant nastiness; used especially of nasty weather
750.harshness: the quality of being unpleasant (harsh or rough or grating) to the senses
750.loathsomeness: the quality of being disgusting to the senses or emotions
750.blatancy: the property of being both obvious and offensive

360.proline: an amino acid that is found in many proteins (especially collagen)
360.tyramine: amino acid derived from tyrosine; has a sympathomimetic action; found in chocolate and cola drinks and ripe cheese and beer
360.hydroxyproline: a crystalline amino acid obtained from gelatin or collagen
360.ornithine: an amino acid that does not occur in proteins but is important in the formation of urea
360.histidine: an essential amino acid found in proteins that is important for the growth and repair of tissue
360.glutamic acid: an amino acid occurring in proteins; important in the nitrogen metabolism of plants; used in monosodium glutamate to enhance the flavor of meats
360.di-iodotyrosine: tyrosine with two iodine atoms added
360.alanine: a crystalline amino acid that occurs in many proteins
360.aspartic acid: a crystalline amino acid found in proteins and occurring naturally in sugar beets and sugar cane
360.tryptophan: an amino acid that occurs in proteins; is essential for growth and normal metabolism; a precursor of niacin
360.essential amino acid: an amino acid that is required by animals but that they cannot synthesize; must be supplied in the diet
360.isoleucine: an essential amino acid found in proteins; isomeric with leucine
360.cysteine: an amino acid containing sulfur that is found in most proteins; oxidizes on exposure to air to form cystine
360.L-dopa: the levorotatory form of dopa (trade names Bendopa and Brocadopa and Larodopa); as a drug it is used to treat Parkinson's disease
360.creatine: an amino acid that does not occur in proteins but is found in the muscle tissue of vertebrates both in the free form and as phosphocreatine; supplies energy for muscle contraction
360.glycine: the simplest amino acid found in proteins and the principal amino acid in sugar cane
360.arginine: a bitter tasting amino acid found in proteins and necessary for nutrition; its absence from the diet leads to a reduced production of spermatozoa
360.serine: a sweetish crystalline amino acid involved in the synthesis by the body of cysteine
360.dopa: amino acid that is formed in the liver and converted into dopamine in the brain
360.iodoamino acid: an amino acid with iodine added
360.thyronine: a phenolic amino acid of which thyroxine is a derivative
360.glutamine: a crystalline amino acid occurring in proteins; important in protein metabolism
360.tri-iodothyronine: thyronine with three iodine atoms added
360.cystine: a crystalline amino acid found in proteins (especially keratin); discovered in bladder stones
360.valine: an essential amino acid found in proteins; important for growth in children and nitrogen balance in adults
360.threonine: a colorless crystalline amino acid found in protein; occurs in the hydrolysates of certain proteins; an essential component of human nutrition
360.phenylalanine: an essential amino acid found in proteins and needed for growth of children and for protein metabolism in children and adults; abundant in milk and eggs; it is normally converted to tyrosine in the human body
360.tyrosine: an amino acid found in most proteins; a precursor of several hormones
360.canavanine: an amino acid found in the jack bean
360.citrulline: an amino acid that does not occur in proteins but is an intermediate in the conversion of ornithine to arginine
360.methionine: a crystalline amino acid containing sulfur; found in most proteins and essential for nutrition
360.asparagine: a crystalline amino acid found in proteins and in many plants (e.g., asparagus)
360.leucine: a white crystalline amino acid occurring in proteins that is essential for nutrition; obtained by the hydrolysis of most dietary proteins
360.amino acid: organic compounds containing an amino group and a carboxylic acid group
360.mono-iodotyrosine: tyrosine with one iodine atom added
360.gamma aminobutyric acid: an amino acid that is found in the central nervous system; acts as an inhibitory neurotransmitter
360.lysine: an essential amino acid found in proteins; occurs especially in gelatin and casein

533.hematochezia: passage of stools containing blood (as from diverticulosis or colon cancer or peptic ulcer)
533.overflow incontinence: urinary incontinence that occurs when the bladder is so full that it continually leaks urine; often attributable to a blocked urethra (e.g., due to prostate enlargement) or weak bladder muscles or nerve damage
533.lithuresis: passing small stones with the urine
533.oliguria: production of an abnormally small amount of urine
533.defecation: the elimination of fecal waste through the anus
533.stress incontinence: urinary incontinence that occurs when involuntary pressure is put on the bladder by coughing or laughing or sneezing or lifting or straining
533.urochesia: passage of urine from the anus
533.bed-wetting: enuresis during sleep; especially common in children (who usually outgrow it)
533.elimination: the bodily process of discharging waste matter
533.enuresis: inability to control the flow of urine and involuntary urination
533.urge incontinence: urinary incontinence that is generally attributable to involuntary contracts of the bladder muscle resulting in an urgent need to urinate accompanied by a sudden loss of urine; most common in people over 60 years of age
533.nocturia: excessive urination at night; especially common in older men

401.silique: narrow elongated seed capsule peculiar to the family Cruciferae

401.mesocarp: the middle layer of a pericarp

89.delayed allergy: an allergic reaction that becomes apparent only hours after contact
89.anaphylaxis: hypersensitivity reaction to the ingestion or injection of a substance (a protein or drug) resulting from prior contact with a substance
89.anaphylactic shock: a severe and rapid and sometimes fatal hypersensitivity reaction to a substance (especially a vaccine or penicillin or shellfish or insect venom) to which the organism has become sensitized by previous exposure
89.immediate allergy: an allergic reaction that becomes apparent in a sensitized person only minutes after contact
89.allergic rhinitis: rhinitis caused by an allergic reaction
89.hay fever: a seasonal rhinitis resulting from an allergic reaction to pollen
89.food allergy: allergic reaction to a substance ingested in food
89.allergy: hypersensitivity reaction to a particular allergen; symptoms can vary greatly in intensity
89.urtication: an itchy skin eruption characterized by weals with pale interiors and well-defined red margins; usually the result of an allergic response to insect bites or food or drugs
89.serum sickness: a delayed allergic reaction to the injection of an antiserum caused by an antibody reaction to an antigen in the donor serum
89.hypersensitivity reaction: an inappropriate and excessive reaction to an allergen (as pollen or dust or animal hair or certain foods); severity ranges from mild allergy to severe systemic reactions leading to anaphylactic shock

566.shark repellent: a measure undertaken by a corporation to discourage unwanted takeover attempts
566.poison pill: the target company defends itself by making its stock less attractive to an acquirer
566.golden parachute: giving top executives lucrative benefits that must be paid by the acquirer if they are discharged after a takeover
566.greenmail: (corporation) the practice of purchasing enough shares in a firm to threaten a takeover and thereby forcing the owners to buy those shares back at a premium in order to stay in business
566.countermine: (military) a tunnel dug to defeat similar activities by the enemy
566.countermeasure: an action taken to offset another action
566.safe harbor: the target company defends itself by acquiring a company so onerously regulated that it makes the target less attractive
566.scorched-earth policy: the target company defends itself by selling off its crown jewels
566.suicide pill: a poison pill with potentially catastrophic implications for the company it is intended to protect
566.measure: any maneuver made as part of progress toward a goal
566.security: measures taken as a precaution against theft or espionage or sabotage etc.
566.precaution: a precautionary measure warding off impending danger or damage or injury etc.
566.backstop: a precaution in case of an emergency
566.pac-man strategy: the target company defends itself by threatening to take over its acquirer

2.chip: a piece of dried bovine dung

541.drizzle: very light rain; stronger than mist but less than a shower

517.main: a principal pipe in a system that distributes water or gas or electricity or that collects sewage

517.sparge pipe: a horizontal pipe having fine holes drilled throughout its length so as to deliver a spray of water

85.scrap iron: iron to be melted again and reworked

85.delta iron: an allotrope of iron that is stable between 1403 degrees centigrade and the melting point (= 1532 degrees)

85.cinder pig: pig iron containing a substantial proportion of slag
85.wrought iron: iron having a low carbon content that is tough and malleable and so can be forged and welded

85.basic iron: pig iron containing a high percentage of phosphorus; used in making steel by a process that removes the phosphorus

85.alpha iron: a magnetic allotrope of iron; stable below 906 degrees centigrade

85.iron: a heavy ductile magnetic metallic element; is silver-white in pure form but readily rusts; used in construction and tools and armament; plays a role in the transport of oxygen by the blood

83.Takelma: a member of a North American Indian people of southwestern Oregon

610.trip wire: a wire stretched close to the ground that activates something (a trap or camera or weapon) when tripped over

610.chain: a series of (usually metal) rings or links fitted into one another to make a flexible ligament
610.wire: ligament made of metal and used to fasten things or make cages or fences etc
610.haywire: wire for tying up bales of hay
610.binder: something used to tie or bind
610.piano wire: thin steel wire of high tensile strength

576.tinea cruris: fungal infection of the groin (most common in men)
576.blastomycosis: any of several infections of the skin or mucous membrane caused by Blastomyces
576.dermatomycosis: fungal infection of the skin (especially of moist parts covered by clothing)
576.dhobi itch: fungal infection attacking moist parts of the body
576.rhinosporidiosis: fungal infection of the nose; often acquired while swimming
576.coccidioidomycosis: an infection of the lungs and skin characterized by excessive sputum and nodules
576.cryptococcosis: a fungal infection characterized by nodular lesions--first in the lungs and spreading to the nervous system
576.tinea: infections of the skin or nails caused by fungi and appearing as itching circular patches
576.chromoblastomycosis: a fungal infection characterized by itchy warty nodules on the skin
