576.zymosis: (medicine) the development and spread of an infectious disease (especially one caused by a fungus)
576.phycomycosis: any fungal infection caused by fungi of the Phycomycetes group
576.tinea barbae: fungal infection of the face and neck
576.sporotrichosis: a chronic fungal infection of the skin and lymph nodes
576.fungal infection: an inflammatory condition caused by a fungus
576.candidiasis: an infection caused by fungi of the genus Monilia or Candida (especially Candida albicans)
576.tinea unguium: fungal infection of the nails (especially toenails)
576.tinea corporis: fungal infection of nonhairy parts of the skin
576.tinea capitis: fungal infection of the scalp characterized by bald patches
576.thrush: candidiasis of the oral cavity; seen mostly in infants or debilitated adults
576.favus: a contagious fungal infection of the scalp; occurs mainly in Africa and the Middle East

125.sard: a deep orange-red variety of chalcedony
125.quartz crystal: a thin plate or small rod of quartz cut along certain lines and ground so that it can produce an electric signal at a constant frequency; used in crystal oscillators
125.onyx: a chalcedony with alternating black and white bands; used in making cameos
125.sardonyx: an onyx characterized by parallel layers of sard and a different colored mineral

125.chrysoprase: a green variety of chalcedony valued as a gemstone
125.rock crystal: a clear quartz used in making electronic and optical equipment
125.plasma: a green slightly translucent variety of chalcedony used as a gemstone

150.in-joke: a joke that is appreciated only by members of some particular group of people
150.ethnic joke: a joke at the expense of some ethnic group
150.joke: a humorous anecdote or remark intended to provoke laughter
150.cartoon: a humorous or satirical drawing published in a newspaper or magazine
150.pungency: wit having a sharp and caustic quality
150.topper: an exceedingly good witticism that surpasses all that have gone before
150.sight gag: a joke whose effect is achieved by visual means rather than by speech (as in a movie)
150.caricature: a representation of a person that is exaggerated for comic effect
150.belly laugh: a joke that seems extremely funny
150.mock-heroic: a satirical imitation of heroic verse
150.comic strip: a sequence of drawings telling a story in a newspaper or comic book
150.fun: verbal wit or mockery (often at another's expense but not to be taken seriously)
150.parody: a composition that imitates or misrepresents somebody's style, usually in a humorous way
150.funny story: an account of an amusing incident (usually with a punch line)
150.wit: a message whose ingenuity or verbal skill or incongruity has the power to evoke laughter
150.esprit de l'escalier: a witty remark that occurs to you too late
150.drollery: a comic incident or series of incidents
150.shaggy dog story: a long rambling joke whose humor derives from its pointlessness
150.sarcasm: witty language used to convey insults or scorn; ; ; --Jonathan Swift

681.client-centered therapy: a method of psychotherapy developed by Carl Rogers in which the client determines the focus and pace of each session
681.psychoanalysis: a set of techniques for exploring underlying motives and a method of treating various mental disorders; based on the theories of Sigmund Freud
681.assertiveness training: a method of psychotherapy that reinforces you for stating negative and positive feelings directly
681.aversion therapy: any technique of behavior modification that uses unpleasant stimuli in a controlled fashion to alter behavior in a therapeutic way; primarily used for alcoholism or drug abuse (but with little success)
681.play therapy: form of psychotherapy for children that uses play situations for diagnosis or treatment
681.desensitization technique: a technique used in behavior therapy to treat phobias and other behavior problems involving anxiety; client is exposed to the threatening situation under relaxed conditions until the anxiety reaction is extinguished
681.exposure therapy: a form of behavior therapy in which a survivor confronts feelings or phobias or anxieties about a traumatic event and relives it in the therapy situation
681.family therapy: any of several therapeutic approaches in which a family is treated as a whole
681.hypnotherapy: the use of hypnosis in psychotherapy
681.implosion therapy: a technique used in behavior therapy; client is flooded with experiences of a particular kind until becoming either averse to them or numbed to them
681.reciprocal inhibition: a method of behavior therapy based on the inhibition of one response by the occurrence of another response that is mutually incompatible with it; a relaxation response might be conditioned to a stimulus that previously evoked anxiety
681.self-analysis: the application of psychotherapeutic principles to the analysis of your own personality
681.token economy: a form of behavior therapy that has been used in some mental institutions; patients are rewarded with tokens for appropriate behavior and the tokens may be cashed in for valued rewards
681.behavior therapy: psychotherapy that seeks to extinguish or inhibit abnormal or maladaptive behavior by reinforcing desired behavior and extinguishing undesired behavior
681.group therapy: psychotherapy in which a small group of individuals meet with a therapist; interactions among the members are considered to be therapeutic
681.psychotherapy: the treatment of mental or emotional problems by psychological means
681.hypnoanalysis: the use of hypnosis in conjunction with psychoanalysis
681.crisis intervention: psychotherapy that focuses on acute critical situations (depressive episodes or attempted suicides or drug overdoses) with the aim of restoring the person to the level of functioning before the crisis

188.photogravure: printing from an intaglio plate prepared by photographic methods
188.rotogravure: printing by transferring an image from a photogravure plate to a cylinder in a rotary press
188.planographic printing: the process of printing from a surface on which the printing areas are not raised but are ink-receptive (as opposed to ink repellent)
188.carbon process: a process of printing on paper coated with bichromated gelatin containing pigment
188.printing: reproduction by applying ink to paper as for publication
188.offset: a plate makes an inked impression on a rubber-blanketed cylinder, which in turn transfers it to the paper
188.hectograph: duplicator consisting of a gelatin plate from which ink can be taken to make a copy
188.photo-offset printing: a method of offset printing using photomechanical plates
188.typography: art and technique of printing with movable type
188.relief printing: printing from a plate with raised characters
188.letterset printing: image is transferred from a relief type plate to a roller
188.intaglio printing: a printing process that uses an etched or engraved plate; the plate is smeared with ink and wiped clean, then the ink left in the recesses makes the print
188.lithography: a method of planographic printing from a metal or stone surface
188.process printing: a method of printing colored reproductions from halftone plates
188.photolithography: a planographic printing process using plates made from a photographic image
188.collotype: a photomechanical printing process that uses a glass plate with a gelatin surface that carries the image to be reproduced; can be used with one or more colors

498.bullet hole: a hole made by a bullet passing through it
498.bolt-hole: a hole through which an animal may bolt when pursued into its burrow or den
498.ozone hole: an area of the ozone layer (near the poles) that is seasonally depleted of ozone
498.rathole: a hole (as in the wall of a building) made by rats
498.hydathode: a pore that exudes water on the surface or margin of a leaf of higher plants
498.micropyle: minute opening in the wall of an ovule through which the pollen tube enters
498.pupil: the contractile aperture in the center of the iris of the eye; resembles a large black dot
498.cranny: a small opening or crevice (especially in a rock face or wall)
498.germ pore: a pore in the outer wall of a spore or pollen grain through which the germ tube or pollen tube makes its exit on germination
498.stoma: a minute epidermal pore in a leaf or stem through which gases and water vapor can pass
498.hole: an opening into or through something
498.lenticel: one of many raised pores on the stems of woody plants that allow the interchange of gas between the atmosphere and the interior tissue
498.knothole: a hole in a board where a knot came out
498.leak: an accidental hole that allows something (fluid or light etc.) to enter or escape

390.largeness: large or extensive in breadth or importance or comprehensiveness
390.indispensability: the quality possessed by something that you cannot possibly do without
390.purposefulness: the quality of having a definite purpose
390.vitalness: the quality of being essential to maintain life
390.big deal: anything of great importance or consequence
390.greatness: the property possessed by something or someone of outstanding importance or eminence
390.edge: the attribute of urgency in tone of voice
390.weight: the relative importance granted to something
390.importance: the quality of being important and worthy of note
390.meaningfulness: the quality of having great value or significance

708.local anesthesia: loss of sensation in a small area of the body (as when a local anesthetic is injected for a tooth extraction)
708.spinal anesthesia: anesthesia of the lower half of the body; caused by injury to the spinal cord or by injecting an anesthetic beneath the arachnoid membrane that surrounds the spinal cord
708.saddle block anesthesia: the parts of a patient's body that would touch a saddle if the patient were sitting in one are anesthetized by injecting a local anesthetic into the spinal cord
708.anesthesia: loss of bodily sensation with or without loss of consciousness
708.acroanesthesia: loss of sensation in the extremities
708.inhalation anesthesia: general anesthesia achieved by administration of an inhalation anesthetic
708.topical anesthesia: loss of sensation confined to the skin or mucous surfaces (as when benzocaine or Lidocaine is applied to the surface)
708.pudendal block: regional anesthesia resulting from the use of a local anesthetic to deaden the pudendal nerves in the region of the vulva and labia majora; used to ease discomfort during childbirth
708.epidural anesthesia: regional anesthesia resulting from injection of an anesthetic into the epidural space of the spinal cord; sensation is lost in the abdominal and genital and pelvic areas; used in childbirth and gynecological surgery
708.paracervical block: regional anesthesia resulting from the injection of a local anesthetic on each side of the cervix; used during labor and childbirth
708.caudal anesthesia: regional anesthesia resulting from injection of an anesthetic into the caudal end of the spinal canal; now largely replaced by epidural anesthesia
708.twilight sleep: a state of general anesthesia in which the person retains a slight degree of consciousness; can be induced by injection of scopolamine or morphine
708.regional anesthesia: loss of sensation in a region of the body produced by application of an anesthetic agent to all the nerves supplying that region (as when an epidural anesthetic is administered to the pelvic region during childbirth)
708.conduction anesthesia: anesthesia of an area supplied by a nerve; produced by an anesthetic agent applied to the nerve
708.general anesthesia: a state of total unconsciousness resulting from anesthetic drugs (as for a major surgical operation)

382.multivariate analysis: a generic term for any statistical technique used to analyze data from more than one variable
382.regression analysis: the use of regression to make quantitative predictions of one variable from the values of another
382.regression: the relation between selected values of x and observed values of y (from which the most probable value of y can be predicted for any value of x)
382.multiple regression: a statistical technique that predicts values of one variable on the basis of two or more other variables
382.curvilinear regression: the relation between variables when the regression equation is nonlinear (quadratic or higher order)
382.linear regression: the relation between variables when the regression equation is linear: e.g., y = ax + b
382.multicollinearity: a case of multiple regression in which the predictor variables are themselves highly correlated
382.factor analysis: any of several methods for reducing correlational data to a smaller number of dimensions or factors; beginning with a correlation matrix a small number of components or factors are extracted that are regarded as the basic variables that account for the interrelations observed in the data
382.least squares: a method of fitting a curve to data points so as to minimize the sum of the squares of the distances of the points from the curve
382.correlational analysis: the use of statistical correlation to evaluate the strength of the relations between variables
382.analysis of variance: a statistical method for making simultaneous comparisons between two or more means; a statistical method that yields values that can be tested to determine whether a significant relation exists between variables
382.statistical method: a method of analyzing or representing statistical data; a procedure for calculating a statistic

165.frost heave: upthrust of ground or pavement caused by the freezing of moist soil
165.geological phenomenon: a natural phenomenon involving the structure or composition of the earth
165.seaquake: an earthquake at the sea bed
165.volcanism: the phenomena associated with volcanic activity
165.alluvial fan: a fan-shaped deposit where a fast flowing stream flattens out
165.flash flood: a sudden local flood of great volume and short duration
165.shock: an instance of agitation of the earth's crust
165.floodhead: a wall of water rushing ahead of the flood
165.catastrophe: a sudden violent change in the earth's surface
165.aftershock: a tremor (or one of a series of tremors) occurring after the main shock of an earthquake
165.Noah's flood: (Biblical) the great deluge that is said in the Book of Genesis to have occurred in the time of Noah; it was brought by God upon the earth because of the wickedness of human beings
165.endogeny: a geological phenomenon below the surface of the earth
165.transgression: the spreading of the sea over land as evidenced by the deposition of marine strata over terrestrial strata
165.continental drift: the gradual movement and formation of continents (as described by plate tectonics)
165.debacle: flooding caused by a tumultuous breakup of ice in a river during the spring or summer
165.deposit: the phenomenon of sediment or gravel accumulating
165.mother lode: the main vein of ore in a deposit
165.nuclear winter: a long period of darkness and extreme cold that scientists predict would follow a full-scale nuclear war; a layer of dust and smoke in the atmosphere would cover the earth and block the rays of the sun; most living organisms would perish
165.lode: a deposit of valuable ore occurring within definite boundaries separating it from surrounding rocks
165.earthquake: shaking and vibration at the surface of the earth resulting from underground movement along a fault plane of from volcanic activity
165.flood: the rising of a body of water and its overflowing onto normally dry land

24.howler monkey: monkey of tropical South American forests having a loud howling cry
24.woolly monkey: large monkeys with dark skin and woolly fur of the Amazon and Orinoco basins
24.pinche: South American tamarin with a tufted head
24.saki: small arboreal monkey of tropical South America with long hair and bushy nonprehensile tail
24.spider monkey: arboreal monkey of tropical America with long slender legs and long prehensile tail
24.douroucouli: nocturnal monkey of Central America and South America with large eyes and thick fur
24.silky tamarin: golden South American monkey with long soft hair forming a mane
24.squirrel monkey: small long-tailed monkey of Central American and South America with greenish fur and black muzzle
24.capuchin: monkey of Central America and South America having thick hair on the head that resembles a monk's cowl
24.marmoset: small soft-furred South American and Central American monkey with claws instead of nails
24.titi: small South American monkeys with long beautiful fur and long nonprehensile tail
24.pygmy marmoset: the smallest monkey; of tropical forests of the Amazon
24.New World monkey: hairy-faced arboreal monkeys having widely separated nostrils and long usually prehensile tails
24.tamarin: small South American marmoset with silky fur and long nonprehensile tail
24.uakari: medium-sized tree-dwelling monkey of the Amazon basin; only New World monkey with a short tail

540.occupational safety and health act: a law passed by the United States Congress that created the Occupational Safety and Health Administration to prevent employees from being injured or contracting diseases in the course of their employment
540.statutory law: the body of laws created by legislative statutes
540.administrative law: the body of rules and regulations and orders and decisions created by administrative agencies of government
540.common law: a system of jurisprudence based on judicial precedents rather than statutory laws
540.law of the land: a phrase used in the Magna Carta to refer to the then established law of the kingdom (as distinct from Roman or civil law); today it refers to fundamental principles of justice commensurate with due process
540.military law: the body of laws and rules of conduct administered by military courts for the discipline, trial, and punishment of military personnel
540.securities law: the body of laws governing the issuance and selling of securities
540.mercantile law: the body of rules applied to commercial transactions; derived from the practices of traders rather than from jurisprudence
540.canon law: the body of codified laws governing the affairs of a Christian church
540.hudud: Islamic laws stating the limits ordained by Allah and including the deterrent punishments for serious crimes
540.maritime law: the branch of international law that deals with territorial and international waters or with shipping or with ocean fishery etc.
540.Mosaic law: the laws (beginning with the Ten Commandments) that God gave to the Israelites through Moses; it includes many rules of religious observance given in the first five books of the Old Testament (in Judaism these books are called the Torah)
540.tax law: the body of laws governing taxation
540.international law: the body of laws governing relations between nations
540.law: the collection of rules imposed by authority
540.case law: (civil law) a law established by following earlier judicial decisions
540.martial law: the body of law imposed by the military over civilian affairs (usually in time of war or civil crisis); overrides civil law
540.civil law: the body of laws established by a state or nation for its own regulation
540.legislation: law enacted by a legislative body
540.shariah: the code of law derived from the Koran and from the teachings and example of Mohammed
540.enabling legislation: legislation that gives appropriate officials the authority to implement or enforce the law

135.supper: a light evening meal; served in early evening if dinner is at midday or served late in the evening at bedtime
135.refreshment: snacks and drinks served as a light meal
135.ploughman's lunch: a meal consisting of a sandwich of bread and cheese and a salad
135.clambake: a cookout at the seashore where clams and fish and other foods are cooked--usually on heated stones covered with seaweed
135.barbecue: a cookout in which food is cooked over an open fire; especially a whole animal carcass roasted on a spit
135.power breakfast: a meeting of influential people to conduct business while eating breakfast
135.mess: a meal eaten in a mess hall by service personnel
135.Last Supper: the traditional Passover supper of Jesus with his disciples on the eve of his crucifixion
135.banquet: a meal that is well prepared and greatly enjoyed
135.Seder: (Judaism) the ceremonial dinner on the first night (or both nights) of Passover
135.wiener roast: a cookout where roasted frankfurters are the main course
135.breakfast: the first meal of the day (usually in the morning)
135.buffet: a meal set out on a buffet at which guests help themselves
135.burgoo: a gathering at which burgoo stew is served
135.fish fry: a cookout where fried fish is the main course
135.tea: a light midafternoon meal of tea and sandwiches or cakes
135.cookout: an informal meal cooked and eaten outdoors
135.business lunch: lunch (usually at a restaurant) where business is discussed and the cost is charged as a business expense
135.high tea: substantial early evening meal including tea
135.potluck: whatever happens to be available especially when offered to an unexpected guest or when brought by guests and shared by all
135.smorgasbord: an assortment of foods starting with herring or smoked eel or salmon etc with bread and butter; then cheeses and eggs and pickled vegetables and aspics; finally hot foods; served as a buffet meal
135.picnic: any informal meal eaten outside or on an excursion
135.dinner: the main meal of the day served in the evening or at midday
135.brunch: combination breakfast and lunch; usually served in late morning
135.coffee break: a snack taken during a break in the work day
135.meal: the food served and eaten at one time
135.continental breakfast: a breakfast that usually includes a roll and coffee or tea

581.gilding metal: a brass that is rich in copper; used to make articles that were to be gilded
581.nickel bronze: a bronze containing up to 30% nickel
581.bell metal: bronze with 3 or 4 parts copper to 1 part tin; used in making bells
581.copper-base alloy: any alloy whose principal component is copper
581.cartridge brass: an alloy of copper and zinc (containing about 30% zinc) that is wrought into cartridges or tubing
581.leaded bronze: bronze to which 1-4% lead is added
581.brass: an alloy of copper and zinc
581.alpha-beta brass: a brass that has more zinc and is stronger than alpha brass; used in making castings and hot-worked products
581.phosphor bronze: a corrosion-resistant bronze containing phosphorus; used in bearings and gears
581.constantan: an alloy of copper and nickel with high electrical resistance and a low temperature coefficient; used as resistance wire
581.manganese bronze: a brass with from 1-4% manganese to harden it
581.gunmetal: a type of bronze used for parts subject to wear or corrosion (especially corrosion by sea water)
581.silicon bronze: a bronze with 2-3% silicon that is resistant to corrosion
581.latten: brass (or a yellow alloy resembling brass) that was hammered into thin sheets; formerly used for church utensils
581.cupronickel: a 60/40 alloy of copper and nickel
581.bearing brass: a brass bushing or a lining for a bearing
581.alpha brass: an alloy of brass and zinc; used mainly for cold working
581.aluminum bronze: an alloy of copper and aluminum with high tensile strength and resistance to corrosion
581.naval brass: alpha-beta brass containing tin; resistant to sea water; Admiralty Metal is a trademark
581.ormolu: brass that looks like gold; used to decorate furniture
581.bronze: an alloy of copper and tin and sometimes other elements; also any copper-base alloy containing other elements in place of tin
581.alpha bronze: an alloy of copper and tin that can be worked
581.red brass: brass with enough copper to give it a reddish tint; used for plumbing pipe and other brass hardware and in cheap jewelry

104.demonstrability: capability of being demonstrated or logically proved
104.slam dunk: something that is a sure to occur; a foregone conclusion
104.givenness: the quality of being granted as a supposition; of being acknowledged or assumed
104.determinateness: the quality of being predictable with great confidence
104.indisputability: the quality of being beyond question or dispute or doubt
104.ineluctability: the quality of being impossible to avoid or evade
104.finality: the quality of being final or definitely settled
104.moral certainty: certainty based on an inner conviction
104.incontrovertibility: the quality of being undeniable and not worth arguing about

603.employment: the occupation for which you are paid

603.coaching: the job of a professional coach
603.minister: the job of a head of a government department
603.piecework: work paid for according to the quantity produced
603.workload: work that a person is expected to do in a specified time
603.case load: the number of cases handled in a given period of time (as by a court or agency)
603.paper route: the job of delivering newspapers regularly
603.service: employment in or work for another
603.ministry: the work of a minister of religion
603.services: performance of duties or provision of space and equipment helpful to others
603.public service: employment within a government system (especially in the civil service)

249.stratified language: a language that cannot be used as its own metalanguage
249.C: a general-purpose programing language closely associated with the UNIX operating system
249.flow chart: a diagram of the sequence of operations in a computer program or an accounting system
249.assembly language: a low-level programing language; close approximation to machine language
249.unstratified language: a programming language that (like natural language) can be used as its own metalanguage
249.logic diagram: a graphical representation of a program using formal logic
249.Pascal: a programing language designed to teach programming through a top-down modular approach
249.object-oriented programming language: (computer science) a programming language that enables the programmer to associate a set of procedures with each type of data structure
249.Prolog: a computer language designed in Europe to support natural language processing
249.computer language: a programming language designed for use on a specific class of computers
249.object language: a computer language into which something written in another computer language is to be translated
249.one-dimensional language: a programming language whose expressions are represented by strings of characters
249.LISP: a flexible procedure-oriented programing language that manipulates symbols in the form of lists
249.algebraic language: an algorithmic language having statements that resemble algebraic expressions
249.BASIC: a popular programming language that is relatively easy to learn; an acronym for beginner's all-purpose symbolic instruction code; no longer in general use
249.FORTRAN: a high-level programing language for mathematical and scientific purposes; stands for formula translation
249.algorithmic language: an artificial language designed to express algorithms
249.programming language: (computer science) a language designed for programming computers
249.multidimensional language: a programming language whose expressions are assembled in more than one dimension
249.decision table: a table of all contingencies and the actions to be taken for each
249.ALGOL: (from a combination of ALGOrithmic and Language); a programming language used to express computer programs as algorithms

396.seat belt: a safety belt used in a car or plane to hold you in your seat in case of an accident
396.accessory: clothing that is worn or carried, but not part of your main clothing
396.money belt: belt with a concealed section for holding money
396.Sam Browne belt: leather belt supported by a strap over the right shoulder
396.holster: a belt with loops or slots for carrying small hand tools
396.baldric: a wide (ornamented) belt worn over the right shoulder to support a sword or bugle by the left hip
396.safety belt: belt attaching you to some object as a restraint in order to prevent you from getting hurt
396.cartridge belt: a broad belt with loops or pockets for holding ammunition
396.belt: a band to tie or buckle around the body (usually at the waist)
396.bandoleer: a broad cartridge belt worn over the shoulder by soldiers

143.clutch: a coupling that connects or disconnects driving and driven parts of a driving mechanism
143.clevis: a coupler shaped like the letter U with holes through each end so a bolt or pin can pass through the holes to complete the coupling; used to attach a drawbar to a plow or wagon or trailer etc.
143.friction clutch: a clutch in which one part turns the other by the friction between them
143.coupling: a mechanical device that serves to connect the ends of adjacent objects
143.universal joint: coupling that connects two rotating shafts allowing freedom of movement in all directions
143.swivel: a coupling (as in a chain) that has one end that turns on a headed pin
143.disk clutch: a friction clutch in which the frictional surfaces are disks
143.cone clutch: a friction clutch in which the frictional surfaces are cone-shaped
143.slip clutch: a friction clutch that will slip when the torque is too great
143.freewheel: a clutch (as on the rear wheel of a bicycle) that allows wheels to turn freely (as in coasting)
143.turnbuckle: an oblong metal coupling with a swivel at one end and an internal thread at the other into which a threaded rod can be screwed in order to form a unit that can be adjusted for length or tension

483.Fury: (classical mythology) the hideous snake-haired monsters (usually three in number) who pursued unpunished criminals
483.Loch Ness monster: a large aquatic animal supposed to resemble a serpent or plesiosaur of Loch Ness in Scotland
483.gryphon: winged monster with the head of an eagle and the body of a lion
483.salamander: reptilian creature supposed to live in fire
483.Gorgon: (Greek mythology) any of three winged sister monsters and the mortal Medusa who had live snakes for hair; a glance at Medusa turned the beholder to stone
483.Nemean lion: (Greek mythology) an enormous lion strangled by Hercules as the first of his 12 labors
483.legendary creature: a monster that is unverifiable but popularly accepted as possibly factual
483.Fafnir: (Norse mythology) the Norse dragon that guarded a treasure and was slain by Sigurd
483.Python: (Greek mythology) dragon killed by Apollo at Delphi
483.leviathan: monstrous sea creature symbolizing evil in the Old Testament
483.dragon: a creature of Teutonic mythology; usually represented as breathing fire and having a reptilian body and sometimes wings
483.Cerberus: (Greek mythology) the three-headed dog guarding the entrance to Hades; son of Typhon
483.Geryon: (Greek mythology) a mythical monster with three heads that was slain by Hercules
483.bogeyman: an imaginary monster used to frighten children
483.Minotaur: (Greek mythology) a mythical monster with the head of a bull and the body of a man; slain by Theseus
483.doppelganger: a ghostly double of a living person that haunts its living counterpart
483.cockatrice: monster hatched by a reptile from a cock's egg; able to kill with a glance
483.basilisk: (classical mythology) a serpent (or lizard or dragon) able to kill with its breath or glance
483.Bigfoot: large hairy humanoid creature said to live in wilderness areas of the United States and Canada
483.monster: an imaginary creature usually having various human and animal parts
483.Medusa: (Greek mythology) a woman transformed into a Gorgon by Athena; she was slain by Perseus
483.Chiron: (Greek mythology) the learned centaur who tutored Achilles, Asclepius, Hercules, Jason, and other heroes
483.Euryale: (Greek mythology) one of the three Gorgons
483.abominable snowman: a large hairy humanoid creature said to live in the Himalayas
483.manticore: a mythical monster having the head of man (with horns) and the body of a lion and the tail of a scorpion
483.Sphinx: (Greek mythology) a riddling winged monster with a woman's head and breast on a lion's body; daughter of Typhon
483.sea serpent: huge creature of the sea resembling a snake or dragon
483.amphisbaena: (classical mythology) a serpent with a head at each end of its body
483.Stheno: (Greek mythology) one of the three Gorgons
483.wyvern: a fire-breathing dragon used in medieval heraldry; had the head of a dragon and the tail of a snake and a body with wings and two legs
483.Chimera: (Greek mythology) fire-breathing female monster with a lion's head and a goat's body and a serpent's tail; daughter of Typhon
483.Typhoeus: (Greek mythology) son of Gaea and Tartarus who created the whirlwinds; had a terrifying voice and 100 dragon heads that spurted fire
483.Hydra: (Greek mythology) monster with nine heads; when struck off each head was replaced by two new ones
483.Typhon: (Greek mythology) a monster with a hundred heads who breathed out flames; son of Typhoeus and father of Cerberus and the Chimera and the Sphinx
483.mythical monster: a monster renowned in folklore and myth
483.centaur: (classical mythology) a mythical being that is half man and half horse
483.Harpy: (Greek mythology) vicious winged monster; often depicted as a bird with the head of a woman
483.werewolf: a monster able to change appearance from human to wolf and back again
483.troll: (Scandanavian folklore) a supernatural creature (either a dwarf or a giant) that is supposed to live in caves or in the mountains
483.roc: mythical bird of prey having enormous size and strength

647.backfire: a loud noise made by the explosion of fuel in the manifold or exhaust of an internal combustion engine
647.big bang: (cosmology) the cosmic explosion that is hypothesized to have marked the origin of the universe
647.nuclear explosion: the explosion of an atomic bomb
647.explosion: a violent release of energy caused by a chemical or nuclear reaction
647.inflation: (cosmology) a brief exponential expansion of the universe (faster than the speed of light) postulated to have occurred shortly after the big bang
647.blowback: the backward escape of gases and unburned gunpowder after a gun is fired
647.fragmentation: the scattering of bomb fragments after the bomb explodes

398.field: (mathematics) a set of elements such that addition and multiplication are commutative and associative and multiplication is distributive over addition and there are two elements 0 and 1
398.image: (mathematics) the set of values of the dependent variable for which a function is defined
398.Mandelbrot set: a set of complex numbers that has a highly convoluted fractal boundary when plotted; the set of all points in the complex plane that are bounded under a certain mathematical iteration
398.metric space: a set of points such that for every pair of points there is a nonnegative real number called their distance that is symmetric and satisfies the triangle inequality
398.Euclidean space: a space in which Euclid's axioms and definitions apply; a metric space that is linear and finite-dimensional
398.domain: (mathematics) the set of values of the independent variable for which a function is defined
398.universal set: (mathematics) the set that contains all the elements or objects involved in the problem under consideration
398.subset: a set whose members are members of another set; a set contained within another set
398.sub-interval: an interval that is included in another interval
398.set: (mathematics) an abstract collection of numbers or symbols
398.manifold: a set of points such as those of a closed surface or an analogue in three or more dimensions
398.subspace: a space that is contained within another space
398.diagonal: (mathematics) a set of entries in a square matrix running diagonally either from the upper left to lower right entry or running from the upper right to lower left entry
398.solution: the set of values that give a true statement when substituted into an equation
398.group: a set that is closed, associative, has an identity element and every element has an inverse
398.Abelian group: a group that satisfies the commutative law
398.Hilbert space: a metric space that is linear and complete and (usually) infinite-dimensional
398.null set: a set that is empty; a set with no members
398.locus: the set of all points or lines that satisfy or are determined by specific conditions
398.mathematical space: (mathematics) any set of points that satisfy a set of postulates of some kind
398.intersection: a point or set of points common to two or more geometric configurations
398.open interval: an interval that does not include its endpoints
398.origin: the point of intersection of coordinate axes; where the values of the coordinates are all zero
398.null space: a space that contains no points; and empty space
398.interval: a set containing all points (or all real numbers) between two given endpoints
398.subgroup: (mathematics) a subset (that is not empty) of a mathematical group
398.closed interval: an interval that includes its endpoints

246.defenestration: the act of throwing someone or something out of a window
246.relegation: mild banishment; consignment to an inferior position
246.deportation: the expulsion from a country of an undesirable alien
246.ouster: the act of ejecting someone or forcing them out
246.disbarment: the act of expelling a lawyer from the practice of law
246.barring: the act of excluding someone by a negative vote or veto

246.ostracism: the act of excluding someone from society by general consent
246.banishment: rejection by means of an act of banishing or proscribing someone
246.ejection: the act of forcing out someone or something

246.excommunication: the act of banishing a member of a church from the communion of believers and the privileges of the church; cutting a person off from a religious society
246.deposition: the act of deposing someone; removing a powerful person from a position or office
246.anathematization: the formal act of pronouncing (someone or something) accursed

673.nitrazepam: a hypnotic and sedative drug of the benzodiazepine type
673.flurazepam: tranquilizer (trade name Dalmane) used to treat insomnia
673.thiothixene: a tranquilizer (trade name Navane) used to treat schizophrenia
673.minor tranquilizer: a tranquilizer used to relieve anxiety and reduce tension and irritability
673.major tranquilizer: tranquilizer used to treat psychotic conditions when a calming effect is desired
673.estazolam: a frequently prescribed sleeping pill (trade name ProSom)
673.thioridazine: a tranquilizer (trade name Mellaril) used to treat schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders
673.oxazepam: a tranquilizing drug (trade name Serax) used to treat anxiety and insomnia and alcohol withdrawal
673.meprobamate: a sedative and tranquilizer (trade name Miltown and Equanil and Meprin) used to treat muscle tension and anxiety
673.diazepam: a tranquilizer (trade name Valium) used to relieve anxiety and relax muscles; acts by enhancing the inhibitory actions of the neurotransmitter GABA; can also be used as an anticonvulsant drug in cases of nerve agent poisoning
673.hydroxyzine hydrochloride: a drug (trade names Atarax and Vistaril) used as a tranquilizer to treat anxiety and motion sickness
673.molindone: antipsychotic drug (trade name Moban) used in the treatment of schizophrenia
673.haloperidol: tranquilizer (trade name Haldol) used to treat some psychotic disorders and Tourette's syndrome
673.lorazepam: tranquilizer (trade name Ativan) used to treat anxiety and tension and insomnia
673.temazepam: a frequently prescribed benzodiazepine (trade name Restoril); takes effect slowly and lasts long enough to help those people who wake up frequently during the night
673.clozapine: an antipsychotic drug (trade name Clozaril) used as a sedative and for treatment-resistant schizophrenia; know to have few side effects
673.chlorpromazine: a drug (trade name Thorazine) derived from phenothiazine that has antipsychotic effects and is used as a sedative and tranquilizer
673.loxapine: a tranquilizer (trade name Loxitane) used to treat schizophrenia
673.fluphenazine: tranquilizer used to treat psychotic disorders
673.pimozide: the most commonly used diphenylbutyl piperidine
673.triazolam: a form of benzodiazepine (trade name Halcion) frequently prescribed as a sleeping pill; usually given to people who have trouble falling asleep
673.midazolam: an injectable form of benzodiazepine (trade name Versed) useful for sedation and for reducing pain during uncomfortable medical procedures
673.tranquilizer: a drug used to reduce stress or tension without reducing mental clarity
673.perphenazine: tranquilizer and antidepressant (trade name Triavil) sometimes used as an antiemetic for adults

673.benzodiazepine: any of several similar lipophilic amines used as tranquilizers or sedatives or hypnotics or muscle relaxants; chronic use can lead to dependency
673.chlordiazepoxide: a tranquilizer (trade names Librium and Libritabs) used in the treatment of alcoholism
673.buspirone: a drug (trade name BuSpar) designed specifically for anxiety
673.prochlorperazine: antipsychotic and antiemetic drug used to treat schizophrenia and to combat nausea and vomiting

367.parallax: the apparent displacement of an object as seen from two different points that are not on a line with the object
367.spherical aberration: an optical aberration resulting in a distorted image
367.optical phenomenon: a physical phenomenon related to or involving light
367.chromatic aberration: an optical aberration in which the image has colored fringes
367.Tyndall effect: the phenomenon in which light is scattered by very small particles in its path; it makes a beam of light visible; the scattered light is mainly blue
367.fringe: one of the light or dark bands produced by the interference and diffraction of light
367.incidence: the striking of a light beam on a surface
367.geocentric parallax: the parallax of a celestial body using two points on the surface of the earth as the earth rotates
367.pleochroism: the phenomenon of different colors appearing when certain crystals are viewed from different directions
367.trichroism: pleochroism of a crystal so that it exhibits three different colors when viewed from three different directions
367.absorption band: a dark band in the spectrum of white light that has been transmitted through a substance that exhibits absorption at selective wavelengths
367.diffraction: when light passes sharp edges or goes through narrow slits the rays are deflected and produce fringes of light and dark bands
367.dichroism: pleochroism of a crystal so that it exhibits two different colors when viewed from two different directions
367.heliocentric parallax: the parallax of a celestial body using two points in the earth's orbit around the sun as the baseline
367.fata morgana: a mirage in the Strait of Messina (attributed to the Arthurian sorcerer Morgan le Fay)
367.aberration: an optical phenomenon resulting from the failure of a lens or mirror to produce a good image
367.stellar parallax: the heliocentric parallax of a star
367.X-ray diffraction: the scattering of X rays by the atoms of a crystal; the diffraction pattern shows structure of the crystal
367.optical illusion: an optical phenomenon that results in a false or deceptive visual impression
367.mirage: an optical illusion in which atmospheric refraction by a layer of hot air distorts or inverts reflections of distant objects
367.polarization: the phenomenon in which waves of light or other radiation are restricted in direction of vibration
367.apparent motion: an optical illusion of motion produced by viewing a rapid succession of still pictures of a moving object
367.solar parallax: the angle subtended by the mean equatorial radius of the Earth at a distance of one astronomical unit
367.horizontal parallax: the maximum parallax observed when the celestial body is at the horizon

44.Scholasticism: the system of philosophy dominant in medieval Europe; based on Aristotle and the Church Fathers
44.existentialism: (philosophy) a 20th-century philosophical movement chiefly in Europe; assumes that people are entirely free and thus responsible for what they make of themselves
44.fatalism: a philosophical doctrine holding that all events are predetermined in advance for all time and human beings are powerless to change them
44.subjectivism: (philosophy) the doctrine that knowledge and value are dependent on and limited by your subjective experience
44.solipsism: (philosophy) the philosophical theory that the self is all that you know to exist
44.logicism: (philosophy) the philosophical theory that all of mathematics can be derived from formal logic
44.naturalism: (philosophy) the doctrine that the world can be understood in scientific terms without recourse to spiritual or supernatural explanations
44.aesthetic: (philosophy) a philosophical theory as to what is beautiful
44.Aristotelianism: (philosophy) the philosophy of Aristotle that deals with logic and metaphysics and ethics and poetics and politics and natural science
44.intuitionism: (philosophy) the doctrine that knowledge is acquired primarily by intuition
44.pragmatism: (philosophy) the doctrine that practical consequences are the criteria of knowledge and meaning and value
44.determinism: (philosophy) a philosophical theory holding that all events are inevitable consequences of antecedent sufficient causes; often understood as denying the possibility of free will
44.nominalism: (philosophy) the doctrine that the various objects labeled by the same term have nothing in common but their name
44.philosophical doctrine: a doctrine accepted by adherents to a philosophy
44.formalism: (philosophy) the philosophical theory that formal (logical or mathematical) statements have no meaning but that its symbols (regarded as physical entities) exhibit a form that has useful applications
44.British empiricism: the predominant philosophical tradition in Great Britain since the 17th century
44.Comtism: Auguste Comte's positivistic philosophy that metaphysics and theology should be replaced by a hierarchy of sciences from mathematics at the base to sociology at the top
44.rationalism: (philosophy) the doctrine that knowledge is acquired by reason without resort to experience
44.sensualism: (philosophy) the ethical doctrine that feeling is the only criterion for what is good
44.conceptualism: the doctrine that the application of a general term to various objects indicates the existence of a mental entity that mediates the application
44.Stoicism: (philosophy) the philosophical system of the Stoics following the teachings of the ancient Greek philosopher Zeno
44.nativism: (philosophy) the philosophical theory that some ideas are innate
44.teleology: (philosophy) a doctrine explaining phenomena by their ends or purposes
44.probabilism: (philosophy) the doctrine that (since certainty is unattainable) probability is a sufficient basis for belief and action
44.empiricism: (philosophy) the doctrine that knowledge derives from experience
44.relativism: (philosophy) the philosophical doctrine that all criteria of judgment are relative to the individuals and situations involved
44.instrumentalism: a system of pragmatic philosophy that considers idea to be instruments that should guide our actions and their value is measured by their success
44.Neoplatonism: a system of philosophical and theological doctrines composed of elements of Platonism and Aristotelianism and oriental mysticism; its most distinctive doctrine holds that the first principle and source of reality transcends being and thought and is naturally unknowable
44.deconstruction: a philosophical theory of criticism (usually of literature or film) that seeks to expose deep-seated contradictions in a work by delving below its surface meaning
44.semiotics: (philosophy) a philosophical theory of the functions of signs and symbols
44.mechanism: (philosophy) the philosophical theory that all phenomena can be explained in terms of physical or biological causes
44.environmentalism: the philosophical doctrine that environment is more important than heredity in determining intellectual growth
44.materialism: (philosophy) the philosophical theory that matter is the only reality
44.dialectical materialism: the materialistic philosophy of Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels
44.Confucianism: the teachings of Confucius emphasizing love for humanity; high value given to learning and to devotion to family (including ancestors); peace; justice; influenced the traditional culture of China
44.vitalism: (philosophy) a doctrine that life is a vital principle distinct from physics and chemistry
44.realism: (philosophy) the philosophical doctrine that physical objects continue to exist when not perceived
44.traditionalism: the doctrine that all knowledge was originally derived by divine revelation and that it is transmitted by traditions
44.operationalism: (philosophy) the doctrine that the meaning of a proposition consists of the operations involved in proving or applying it
44.hereditarianism: the philosophical doctrine that heredity is more important than environment in determining intellectual growth
44.experimentalism: an empirical doctrine that advocates experimental principles
44.mentalism: (philosophy) a doctrine that mind is the true reality and that objects exist only as aspects of the mind's awareness
44.Platonism: (philosophy) the philosophical doctrine that abstract concepts exist independent of their names
44.Taoism: philosophical system developed by Lao-tzu and Chuang-tzu advocating a simple honest life and noninterference with the course of natural events
44.idealism: (philosophy) the philosophical theory that ideas are the only reality
44.positivism: the form of empiricism that bases all knowledge on perceptual experience (not on intuition or revelation)

252.reflexology: the study of reflex action as it relates to the behavior of organisms
252.physiological psychology: the branch of psychology that is concerned with the physiological bases of psychological processes
252.experimental psychology: the branch of psychology that uses experimental methods to study psychological issues
252.psycholinguistics: the branch of cognitive psychology that studies the psychological basis of linguistic competence and performance
252.differential psychology: the branch of psychology that studies measurable differences between individuals
252.behaviorism: an approach to psychology that emphasizes observable measurable behavior
252.cognitive psychology: an approach to psychology that emphasizes internal mental processes
252.applied psychology: any of several branches of psychology that seek to apply psychological principles to practical problems of education or industry or marketing etc.
252.social psychology: the branch of psychology that studies persons and their relationships with others and with groups and with society as a whole
252.abnormal psychology: the branch of psychology concerned with abnormal behavior
252.psychophysics: the branch of psychology concerned with quantitative relations between physical stimuli and their psychological effects
252.memory: the area of cognitive psychology that studies memory processes
252.problem solving: the area of cognitive psychology that studies the processes involved in solving problems
252.psychometry: any branch of psychology concerned with psychological measurements
252.comparative psychology: the branch of psychology concerned with the behavior of animals
252.psychodynamics: the branch of social psychology that deals with the processes and emotions that determine psychology and motivation
252.developmental psychology: the branch of psychology that studies the social and mental development of children

127.chain reaction: a self-sustaining nuclear reaction; a series of nuclear fissions in which neutrons released by splitting one atom leads to the splitting of others
127.cold fusion: nuclear fusion at or near room temperatures; claims to have discovered it are generally considered to have been mistaken
127.spallation: (physics) a nuclear reaction in which a bombarded nucleus breaks up into many particles
127.exoergic reaction: a nuclear reaction accompanied by the evolution of energy
127.endoergic reaction: a nuclear reaction occurring with absorption of energy
127.beta decay: radioactive decay of an atomic nucleus that is accompanied by the emission of a beta particle
127.fusion: a nuclear reaction in which nuclei combine to form more massive nuclei with the simultaneous release of energy
127.fission: a nuclear reaction in which a massive nucleus splits into smaller nuclei with the simultaneous release of energy
127.thermonuclear reaction: a nuclear fusion reaction taking place at very high temperatures (as in the sun)
127.nuclear reaction: (physics) a process that alters the energy or structure or composition of atomic nuclei
127.carbon cycle: a thermonuclear reaction in the interior of stars
127.decay: the spontaneous disintegration of a radioactive substance along with the emission of ionizing radiation
127.alpha decay: radioactive decay of an atomic nucleus that is accompanied by the emission of an alpha particle

463.shortness: the property of being of short temporal extent
463.curtailment: the temporal property of being cut short
463.briefness: the temporal property of being very short
463.transience: an impermanence that suggests the inevitability of ending or dying
463.continuity: the property of a continuous and connected period of time
463.impermanence: the property of not existing for indefinitely long durations
463.immortality: the quality or state of being immortal
463.continuousness: the quality of something that continues without end or interruption
463.endlessness: the property of being (or seeming to be) without end
463.mortality: the quality or state of being mortal
463.fermata: (music) a prolongation of unspecified length on a note or chord or rest
463.imperishability: the property of being resistant to decay
463.ephemerality: the property of lasting for a very short time
463.fugacity: the lack of enduring qualities (used chiefly of plant parts)
463.lastingness: permanence by virtue of the power to resist stress or force
463.lengthiness: the consequence of being lengthened in duration
463.perdurability: the property of being extremely durable
463.permanence: the property of being able to exist for an indefinite duration
463.temporariness: the property of lasting only a short time
463.perpetuity: the property of being perpetual (seemingly ceaseless)
463.brevity: the attribute of being brief or fleeting
463.tensile strength: the strength of material expressed as the greatest longitudinal stress it can bear without tearing apart

207.samizdat: a system of clandestine printing and distribution of dissident or banned literature

113.birthday card: a card expressing a birthday greeting

676.prettiness: the quality of being appealing in a delicate or graceful way (of a girl or young woman)

676.sultriness: the quality of expressing or arousing sexual desire

528.luster: a quality that outshines the usual
528.dazzle: brightness enough to blind partially and temporarily

1.green lacewing: pale green unpleasant-smelling lacewing fly having carnivorous larvae
1.dobson: large soft-bodied insect having long slender mandibles in the male; aquatic larvae often used as bait
1.mantispid: insect that resembles a mantis; larvae are parasites in the nests of spiders and wasps
1.fish fly: similar to but smaller than the dobsonfly; larvae are used as fishing bait
1.lacewing: any of two families of insects with gauzy wings (Chrysopidae and Hemerobiidae); larvae feed on insect pests such as aphids
1.spongefly: hairy-bodied insect whose larvae feed on freshwater sponges
1.alderfly: dark-colored insect having predaceous aquatic larvae
1.neuropteron: insect having biting mouthparts and four large membranous wings with netlike veins
1.snakefly: predatory insect of western North America having a long necklike prothorax
1.ant lion: winged insect resembling a dragonfly; the larvae (doodlebugs) dig conical pits where they wait to catch e.g. ants

77.endocardium: the membrane that lines the cavities of the heart and forms part of the heart valves
77.mesocolon: mesentery that holds the lower colon to the dorsal abdominal wall
77.parietal pericardium: the tough outermost layer of the pericardium that is attached to the diaphragm and the sternum
77.omentum: a fold of peritoneum supporting the viscera
77.peritoneum: a transparent membrane that lines the abdominal cavity in mammals and covers most of the viscera
77.serous membrane: a thin membrane lining the closed cavities of the body; has two layers with a space between that is filled with serous fluid
77.pleura: the thin serous membrane around the lungs and inner walls of the chest

77.epicardium: the innermost of the two layers of the pericardium
77.mesentery: a double layer of peritoneum that attaches to the back wall of the abdominal cavity and supports the small intestines

694.gasoline gauge: gauge that indicates the amount of gasoline left in the gasoline tank of a vehicle

55.banded purple: North American butterfly with blue-black wings crossed by a broad white band
55.peacock: European butterfly having reddish-brown wings each marked with a purple eyespot

55.butterfly: diurnal insect typically having a slender body with knobbed antennae and broad colorful wings
55.copper: any of various small butterflies of the family Lycaenidae having coppery wings
55.tortoiseshell: brilliantly colored; larvae feed on nettles
55.painted beauty: American butterfly having dark brown wings with white and golden orange spots
55.anglewing: nymphalid butterfly having angular notches on the outer edges of the forewings
55.lycaenid: any of various butterflies of the family Lycaenidae
55.comma: anglewing butterfly with a comma-shaped mark on the underside of each hind wing
55.silverspot: butterfly with silver spots on the underside of the hind wings

564.vapor pressure: the pressure exerted by a vapor; often understood to mean saturated vapor pressure (the vapor pressure of a vapor in contact with its liquid form)
564.compartment pressure: the air pressure maintained in an air-tight compartment (as in an aircraft)
564.head: the pressure exerted by a fluid
564.suction: a force over an area produced by a pressure difference
564.hypertonicity: (of a solution) the extent to which a solution has a higher osmotic pressure than some other
564.pressure: the force applied to a unit area of surface; measured in pascals (SI unit) or in dynes (cgs unit)
564.venous pressure: the pressure exerted on the walls of the veins by the circulating blood
564.sea-level pressure: the atmospheric pressure reduced by a formula to the pressure at sea level
564.blood pressure: the pressure of the circulating blood against the walls of the blood vessels; results from the systole of the left ventricle of the heart; sometimes measured for a quick evaluation of a person's health
564.hypotonicity: (of a solution) the extent to which a solution has a lower osmotic pressure than some other
564.oil pressure: pressure that keeps oil on the moving parts of an internal-combustion engine
564.radiation pressure: the minute pressure exerted on a surface normal to the direction of propagation of a wave
564.gas pressure: the pressure exerted by a gas
564.acoustic radiation pressure: (acoustics) the pressure exerted on a surface normal to the direction of propagation of a sound wave
564.intraocular pressure: pressure exerted by the fluids inside the eyeball; regulated by resistance to the outward flow of aqueous humor
564.arterial pressure: the pressure of the circulating blood on the arteries
564.overpressure: a transient air pressure greater than the surrounding atmospheric pressure
564.diastolic pressure: the blood pressure (as measured by a sphygmomanometer) after the contraction of the heart while the chambers of the heart refill with blood
564.hydrostatic head: the pressure at a given point in a liquid measured in terms of the vertical height of a column of the liquid needed to produce the same pressure
564.sound pressure: the difference between the instantaneous pressure at a point in a sound field and the average pressure at that point
564.barometric pressure: atmospheric pressure as indicated by a barometer
564.osmotic pressure: (physical chemistry) the pressure exerted by a solution necessary to prevent osmosis into that solution when it is separated from the pure solvent by a semipermeable membrane
564.atmospheric pressure: the pressure exerted by the atmosphere
564.systolic pressure: the blood pressure (as measured by a sphygmomanometer) during the contraction of the left ventricle of the heart

199.theory of dissociation: (chemistry) theory that describes aqueous solutions in terms of acids (which dissociate to give hydrogen ions) and bases (which dissociate to give hydroxyl ions); the product of an acid and a base is a salt and water
199.cell theory: (biology) the theory that cells form the fundamental structural and functional units of all living organisms; proposed in 1838 by Matthias Schleiden and by Theodor Schwann
199.Gestalt psychology: (psychology) a theory of psychology that emphasizes the importance of configurational properties
199.uncertainty principle: (quantum theory) the theory that it is impossible to measure both energy and time (or position and momentum) completely accurately at the same time
199.steady state theory: (cosmology) the theory that the universe maintains a constant average density with matter created to fill the void left by galaxies that are receding from each other
199.theory of inheritance: (biology) a theory of how characteristics of one generation are derived from earlier generations
199.special relativity: a physical theory of relativity based on the assumption that the speed of light in a vacuum is a constant and the assumption that the laws of physics are invariant in all inertial systems
199.game theory: (economics) a theory of competition stated in terms of gains and losses among opposing players
199.general relativity: a generalization of special relativity to include gravity (based on the principle of equivalence)
199.relativity: (physics) the theory that space and time are relative concepts rather than absolute concepts
199.nebular hypothesis: (cosmology) the theory that the solar system evolved from a hot gaseous nebula
199.supersymmetry: (physics) a theory that tries to link the four fundamental forces
199.theory of gravitation: (physics) the theory that any two particles of matter attract one another with a force directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them
199.corpuscular theory: (physics) the theory that light is transmitted as a stream of particles
199.germ theory: (medicine) the theory that all contagious diseases are caused by microorganisms
199.Darwinism: a theory of organic evolution claiming that new species arise and are perpetuated by natural selection
199.information theory: (computer science) a statistical theory dealing with the limits and efficiency of information processing
199.planetesimal hypothesis: (cosmology) the theory that the solar system was formed by the gravitational accumulation of planetesimals
199.theory of evolution: (biology) a scientific theory of the origin of species of plants and animals
199.kinetic theory of heat: a theory that the temperature of a body increases when kinetic energy increases
199.big-bang theory: (cosmology) the theory that the universe originated sometime between 10 billion and 20 billion years ago from the cataclysmic explosion of a small volume of matter at extremely high density and temperature
199.kinetic theory: (physics) a theory that gases consist of small particles in random motion
199.scientific theory: a theory that explains scientific observations
199.neo-Darwinism: a modern Darwinian theory that explains new species in terms of genetic mutations
199.Lamarckism: a theory of organic evolution claiming that acquired characteristics are transmitted to offspring
199.functionalism: a psychology based on the assumption that all mental process are useful to an organism in adapting to the environment
199.Bohr theory: (physics) a theory of atomic structure that combined Rutherford's model with the quantum theory; electrons orbiting a nucleus can only be in certain stationary energy states and light is emitted when electrons jump from one energy state to another
199.wave theory: (physics) the theory that light is transmitted as waves
199.organicism: theory that the total organization of an organism rather than the functioning of individual organs is the determinant of life processes
199.atomism: (psychology) a theory that reduces all mental phenomena to simple elements (sensations and feelings) that form complex ideas by association
199.quantum theory: (physics) a physical theory that certain properties occur only in discrete amounts (quanta)
199.associationism: (psychology) a theory that association is the basic principle of mental activity
199.Rutherford atom: first modern concept of atomic structure; all of the positive charge and most of the mass of the atom are contained in a compact nucleus; a number of electrons (equal to the atomic number) occupy the rest of the volume of the atom and neutralize the positive charge
199.Neo-Lamarckism: a modern Lamarckian theory emphasizing the importance of environmental factors in genetic changes and retaining the notion of the inheritance of acquired characters
199.atomic theory: a theory of the structure of the atom
199.punctuated equilibrium: a theory of evolution holding that evolutionary change in the fossil record came in fits and starts rather than in a steady process of slow change
199.Mendelism: the theory of inheritance based on Mendel's laws
199.theory of indicators: (chemistry) the theory that all indicators are either weak acids or weak bases in which the color of the ionized form is different from the color before dissociation

342.dorsiflexion: the act of bending backward (of the body or a body part)

519.Copernican system: (astronomy) Copernicus' astronomical model in which the Earth rotates around the sun

646.fasciculation: muscular twitching of contiguous groups of muscle fibers

357.film clip: a strip of motion picture film used in a telecast

420.tickler coil: a small coil in series with the anode of a vacuum tube and coupled to the grid to provide feedback

14.pelican crossing: an acronym for pedestrian light control; a pedestrian crossing with traffic lights that are controlled by pedestrians

14.crossing: a path (often marked) where something (as a street or railroad) can be crossed to get from one side to the other

411.mixed nuisance: a nuisance that is both a public nuisance and a private nuisance at the same time

411.irritant: something that causes irritation and annoyance

422.crazy quilt: a patchwork quilt without a design

422.patchwork: a quilt made by sewing patches of different materials together

157.ethnocentrism: belief in the superiority of one's own ethnic group
157.unfairness: partiality that is not fair or equitable
157.sectionalism: a partiality for some particular place
157.experimenter bias: (psychology) bias introduced by an experimenter whose expectations about the outcome of the experiment can be subtly communicated to the participants in the experiment
157.bias: a partiality that prevents objective consideration of an issue or situation
157.racism: the prejudice that members of one race are intrinsically superior to members of other races
157.white supremacy: the prejudice that members of the white race are superior to members of other races
157.anti-Semitism: the intense dislike for and prejudice against Jewish people
157.Eurocentrism: belief in the preeminence of Europe and the Europeans
157.taboo: a prejudice (especially in Polynesia and other South Pacific islands) that prohibits the use or mention of something because of its sacred nature
157.partiality: an inclination to favor one group or view or opinion over alternatives
157.homophobia: prejudice against (fear or dislike of) homosexual people and homosexuality
157.anthropocentrism: an inclination to evaluate reality exclusively in terms of human values

261.Old Italian: the Italian language up to the middle of the 16th century
261.Italian: the Romance language spoken in Italy
261.Anglo-French: the French (Norman) language used in medieval England
261.Judeo-Spanish: the Spanish dialect spoken by Sephardic Jews but written in the Hebrew script
261.Ladin: a Rhaeto-Romance dialect of Romansh spoken in southeastern Switzerland
261.Langue d'oc: medieval provincial dialects of French formerly spoken in the south of France
261.Langue d'oil: medieval provincial dialects of French spoken in central and northern France
261.Rhaeto-Romance: Romance dialects spoken in parts of southeastern Switzerland and northern Italy and the Tyrol
261.Tuscan: a dialect of Italian spoken in Tuscany (especially Florence)
261.Galician: a language spoken in Galicia in northwestern Spain; it is between Portuguese and Spanish but closer to Portuguese; sometimes considered a Portuguese or Spanish dialect
261.Walloon: a dialect of French spoken in Belgium and adjacent parts of France
261.Norman-French: the medieval Norman dialect of Old French
261.Catalan: the Romance language spoken in Catalonia in eastern Spain (related to Spanish and Occitan)
261.Friulian: a Rhaeto-Romance dialect spoken in northeastern Italy
261.French: the Romance language spoken in France and in countries colonized by France
261.Provencal: the medieval dialects of Langue d'oc (southern France)
261.Haitian Creole: a creole language spoken by most Haitians; based on French and various African languages
261.Canadian French: the French language as spoken in Quebec, Canada
261.Castilian: the Spanish language as spoken in Castile
261.Romanian: an eastern Romance language spoken in Romania
261.Spanish: the Romance language spoken in most of Spain and the countries colonized by Spain
261.Sardinian: the Italian dialect spoken in Sardinia; sometimes considered a separate language with many loan words from Spanish
261.Mexican Spanish: the dialect of Spanish spoken in Mexico
261.Old French: the earliest form of the French language; 9th to 15th century
261.Portuguese: the Romance language spoken in Portugal and Brazil
261.Romance: the group of languages derived from Latin
261.Romansh: the Rhaeto-Romance language spoken in southeastern Switzerland; it is an official language of Switzerland

547.icing sugar: finely powdered sugar used to make icing
547.caramel: burnt sugar; used to color and flavor food
547.cane sugar: sugar from sugarcane used as sweetening agent
547.sugar: a white crystalline carbohydrate used as a sweetener and preservative
547.brown sugar: unrefined or only partly refined sugar
547.beet sugar: sugar from sugar beets used as sweetening agent
547.demerara: light brown cane sugar; originally from Guyana
547.sugarloaf: a large conical loaf of concentrated refined sugar
547.granulated sugar: sugar in the form of small grains
547.castor sugar: very finely granulated sugar that was formerly sprinkled from a castor
547.powdered sugar: sugar granulated into a fine powder
547.lump sugar: refined sugar molded into rectangular shapes convenient as single servings

612.swan dive: a dive in which the diver arches the back with arms outstretched before entering the water
612.half gainer: a dive in which the diver throws the feet forward and up to complete a half backward somersault and enters the water facing the diving board
612.water sport: sports that involve bodies of water
612.flip: a dive in which the diver somersaults before entering the water
612.surfing: the sport of riding a surfboard toward the shore on the crest of a wave
612.belly flop: a dive in which the abdomen bears the main force of impact with the water
612.gainer: a dive in which the diver throws the feet forward to complete a full backward somersault and enters the water feet first and facing away from the diving board
612.water-skiing: skiing on water while being towed by a motorboat
612.floating: the act of someone who floats on the water
612.skin diving: underwater swimming without any more breathing equipment than a snorkel
612.dead-man's float: a floating position with the face down and arms stretched forward
612.cliff diving: diving into the water from a steep overhanging cliff
612.jackknife: a dive in which the diver bends to touch the ankles before straightening out

611.repression: (psychiatry) the classical defense mechanism that protects you from impulses or ideas that would cause anxiety by preventing them from becoming conscious
611.projection: (psychiatry) a defense mechanism by which your own traits and emotions are attributed to someone else
611.compensation: (psychiatry) a defense mechanism that conceals your undesirable shortcomings by exaggerating desirable behaviors
611.reaction formation: (psychiatry) a defense mechanism in which a person unconsciously develops attitudes and behavior that are the opposite of unacceptable repressed desires and impulses and serve to conceal them
611.regression: (psychiatry) a defense mechanism in which you flee from reality by assuming a more infantile state
611.displacement: (psychiatry) a defense mechanism that transfers affect or reaction from the original object to some more acceptable one
611.denial: (psychiatry) a defense mechanism that denies painful thoughts
611.isolation: (psychiatry) a defense mechanism in which memory of an unacceptable act or impulse is separated from the emotion originally associated with it
611.defense mechanism: (psychiatry) an unconscious process that tries to reduce the anxiety associated with instinctive desires
611.countertransference: the psychoanalyst's displacement of emotion onto the patient or more generally the psychoanalyst's emotional involvement in the therapeutic interaction
611.idealization: (psychiatry) a defense mechanism that splits something you are ambivalent about into two representations--one good and one bad
611.overcompensation: (psychiatry) an attempt to overcome a real or imagined defect or unwanted trait by overly exaggerating its opposite
611.transference: (psychoanalysis) the process whereby emotions are passed on or displaced from one person to another; during psychoanalysis the displacement of feelings toward others (usually the parents) is onto the analyst
611.intellectualization: (psychiatry) a defense mechanism that uses reasoning to block out emotional stress and conflict
611.conversion: (psychiatry) a defense mechanism represses emotional conflicts which are then converted into physical symptoms that have no organic basis
611.rationalization: (psychiatry) a defense mechanism by which your true motivation is concealed by explaining your actions and feelings in a way that is not threatening

243.seizure: a sudden occurrence (or recurrence) of a disease
243.absence: the occurrence of an abrupt, transient loss or impairment of consciousness (which is not subsequently remembered), sometimes with light twitching, fluttering eyelids, etc.; common in petit mal epilepsy
243.raptus hemorrhagicus: seizure caused by a sudden profuse hemorrhage
243.clonus: convulsion characterized by alternating contractions and relaxations
243.petit mal: a seizure of short duration characterized by momentary unconsciousness and local muscle spasms or twitching
243.grand mal: a seizure during which the patient becomes unconscious and has convulsions over the entire body
243.subclinical absence: a transient impairment of cortical function demonstrable only by 3-per-second brainwave spikes
243.complex absence: an absence seizure accompanied by other abnormalities (atonia or automatisms or vasomotor changes)
243.pure absence: an absence seizure without other complications; followed by 3-per-sec brainwave spikes
243.focal seizure: transitory disturbance in motor or sensory function resulting from abnormal cortical activity
